Subsection Title: We have not authorized anyone to provide any information other than that contained in this offering memorandum. We take no responsibility for, and can provide no assurance as to the reliability of, any other information that others may give you.
Subsubsection Text: We are making this offering in reliance on an exemption from registration under the Securities Act for offers and sales of securities that do not involve a public offering. The notes may not be offered or sold except pursuant to an exemption from, or in a transaction not subject to, the registration requirements of the Securities Act and any applicable state securities laws. Laws in certain jurisdictions may restrict the distribution of this offering memorandum and the offer and sale of the notes. Persons into whose possession this offering memorandum or any of the notes are delivered must inform themselves about, and observe, those restrictions. You must comply with all applicable laws and regulations in force in any applicable jurisdiction, and you must obtain any consent, approval or permission required for the purchase, offer or sale by you of the notes under the laws and regulations in force in the jurisdiction to which you are subject or in which you make such purchase, offer or sale, and neither we nor the initial purchasers will have any responsibility therefor. By purchasing the notes, you will be deemed to have made acknowledgments, representations, warranties and agreements as set forth under “Transfer Restrictions.” We and the initial purchasers are not making an offer to sell the notes in any jurisdiction except where an offer or sale is permitted. You should understand that you will be required to bear the financial risks of your investment for an indefinite period of time. This offering memorandum summarizes documents and other information in a manner we believe to be accurate, but we refer you to the actual documents for a more complete understanding of the information we discuss in this offering memorandum. In making an investment decision, you must rely on your own examination of such documents, our business and the terms of the offering and the notes, including the merits and risks involved. ----- By accepting delivery of this offering memorandum, you acknowledge that (1) you have been afforded an opportunity to request and to review all additional information considered by you to be necessary to verify the accuracy of, or to supplement, the information contained in this offering memorandum, (2) you have not relied on the initial purchasers or any person affiliated with the initial purchasers in connection with the investigation of the accuracy of such information or your investment decision, (3) this offering memorandum relates to an offering that is exempt from registration under the Securities Act and (4) no person has been authorized to give information or to make any representations concerning us, this offering or the notes described in this offering memorandum, other than as contained in this offering memorandum, and in information given by our duly authorized officers and employees in connection with an investor’s examination of us and the terms of the offering of the notes. This offering memorandum may not be copied or reproduced in whole or in part, and it may only be distributed and disclosed to the prospective investors to whom it is provided. We make no representation to you that the notes are a legal investment for you. You should not consider any information in this offering memorandum to be legal, business or tax advice. You should consult your own attorney, business advisor and tax advisor for legal, business and tax advice regarding an investment in the notes. Neither the delivery of the offering memorandum nor any sale made pursuant to this offering memorandum implies that any information set forth in this offering memorandum is correct as of any date after the date of this offering memorandum. You should contact the initial purchasers with any questions about this offering or if you require additional information to verify the information contained in this offering memorandum. We reserve the right to withdraw this offering of the notes at any time. We and the initial purchasers also reserve the right to reject any offer to purchase the notes in whole or in part for any reason, to sell less than the entire principal amount of the notes offered in this offering memorandum and to allot to any prospective investor less than the full amount of notes sought by such investor. In connection with this offering, the initial purchasers may effect transactions that stabilize or maintain the market price of the notes at a higher level than the notes might otherwise achieve in the open market. Such stabilizing, if commenced, may be discontinued at any time. For a description of these activities, see the section “Plan of Distribution” in this offering memorandum. The initial purchasers make no representation or warranty, express or implied, as to the accuracy or completeness of the information set forth in this offering memorandum, and nothing contained in this offering memorandum is, nor should you rely upon it as, a promise or representation, whether as to the past or the future. This offering memorandum is strictly confidential and has been prepared by us solely for use in connection with the proposed offering of the notes described in this offering memorandum. This offering memorandum is personal to each offeree and does not constitute an offer to any other person or the public generally to subscribe for or otherwise acquire the notes. Distribution of this offering memorandum to any person other than the offeree and those persons, if any, retained to advise such offeree with respect to this offering memorandum is unauthorized and any disclosure of any of its contents without our prior written consent is prohibited. By accepting delivery of this offering memorandum, you agree to the foregoing and not to make any photocopies, in whole or in part, of this offering memorandum or any documents delivered in connection with this offering memorandum.

Subsection Title: Neither the Securities and Exchange Commission (the “SEC”) nor any state securities commission has approved or disapproved of these securities or determined if this offering memorandum is truthful or complete. Any representation to the contrary is a criminal offense.

Subsubsection Text: ## $650,000,000 Champions Financing, Inc. ## % Senior Secured Notes due 2029 Champions Financing, Inc. (the “Issuer”) is offering $650,000,000 aggregate principal amount of    % Senior Secured Notes due 2029 (the “notes”). The notes will mature on     , 2029. Interest will accrue from     , 2024 and the first interest payment date will be     , 2024. The Issuer will pay interest on the notes on       and       of each year. This offering is part of the financing of the acquisition by the Issuer, which is indirectly owned by certain funds managed by Clearlake Capital Group, L.P. (together with its affiliates, “Clearlake”), of New SK Holdco, Inc., a Delaware corporation (“Service King”), which is also indirectly owned by Clearlake. The Issuer indirectly owns all of the outstanding equity interests of Crash Champions Holdings, LLC, a Delaware limited liability company (“Crash Champions Holdings”), and its subsidiaries. Following the consummation of the Transactions (as defined below), the Issuer will also indirectly own all of the outstanding equity interests of Service King which, directly or indirectly, owns all of the outstanding equity interests of Service King Paint & Body, LLC, a Texas limited liability company, and its subsidiaries. See “The Transactions” for additional information. The Issuer intends to use the proceeds from this offering, together with the proceeds from the New Term Loan Facility (as defined below) and the issuance of the New PIK Preferred Equity (as defined below), to repay the outstanding indebtedness of each of Crash Champions Intermediate, LLC, a Delaware limited liability company and wholly owned subsidiary of Crash Champions Holdings (“Crash Champions Intermediate”), and New SK HoldCo Sub, LLC, a Delaware limited liability company and wholly owned subsidiary of Service King (“New SK HoldCo Sub”), and to pay related transaction fees and expenses. See “Use of Proceeds” for additional information. At any time prior to     , 2026, the Issuer may redeem some or all of the notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the notes plus any accrued and unpaid interest to, but not including, the redemption date and a “make-whole” premium as described herein. In addition, the Issuer may redeem the notes at any time on or after       , 2026 at specified prices as described herein. In addition, until      , 2026, the Issuer may redeem up to 40% of the notes with the cash proceeds of certain equity offerings at par plus the coupon as described herein. Furthermore, at any time prior to     , 2026, the Issuer may redeem up to 10% of the aggregate principal amount of the notes during any 12-month period at a redemption price of 103% of the principal amount thereof, plus any accrued and unpaid interest to, but excluding, the redemption date. If the Issuer experiences specific kinds of changes of control, the Issuer must offer to purchase all outstanding notes at 101% of the principal amount thereof plus accrued and unpaid interest to, but not including, the date of purchase. The obligations under the notes will be guaranteed, jointly and severally, by each of the Issuer’s existing and future, direct and indirect wholly owned U.S. restricted subsidiaries (collectively, the “guarantors”) that are borrowers under (other than the Issuer) or guarantee the obligations under the New Credit Agreement (as defined below) or certain of the Issuer’s other indebtedness or indebtedness of a guarantor (subject to certain customary exceptions). The notes and related guarantees will be secured by first-priority liens, subject to certain exceptions and permitted liens, on all of the Issuer’s and the guarantors’ existing and future assets that secure the obligations under the New Credit Agreement, as described in this offering memorandum. See “Description of the Notes— Security.” The notes and the guarantees (i) will rank senior in right of payment to any of the Issuer’s and the guarantors’ existing and future subordinated indebtedness, (ii) will rank equally in right of payment with all of the Issuer’s and the guarantors’ existing and future senior indebtedness (including indebtedness under the New Credit Agreement), (iii) will be effectively senior to any of the Issuer’s or the guarantors’ obligations that are not secured by a lien on the Collateral (as defined below) or that are secured by a junior priority lien on the Collateral, in each case to the extent of the value of the Collateral, (iv) will be effectively junior to any of the Issuer’s or the guarantors’ obligations under any existing and future indebtedness that are secured by liens on assets that do not constitute a part of the Collateral to the extent of the value of such assets and (v) will be structurally subordinated to all of the existing and future indebtedness, claims of holders of preferred stock and other liabilities of the Issuer’s subsidiaries that do not guarantee the notes. The notes are a new issue of securities, and there is currently no established trading market for the notes. This offering memorandum includes additional information on the terms of the notes, including redemption and repurchase prices, covenants and transfer restrictions.

The financial statements included in this offering memorandum have been prepared in accordance with Generally Accepted Accounting Principles in the United States of America (“GAAP”). This offering memorandum includes certain non-GAAP financial measures, including: - with respect to each of Crash Champions Holdings and Service King, without giving effect to the Transactions, EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, 4-Wall EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA margin and 4-Wall EBITDA margin. We define these non-GAAP financial measures as follows: `o` EBITDA is defined as earnings before interest expense, income tax expense (benefit) and depreciation and amortization; `o` Adjusted EBITDA is defined as EBITDA as adjusted to exclude non-cash adjustments, transaction and integration-related costs, business optimization costs and non-recurring and normalization adjustments; `o` 4-Wall EBITDA is defined as Adjusted EBITDA generated by our facilities, but excluding all corporate-level costs; and `o` Adjusted EBITDA margin and 4-Wall EBITDA margin are defined as the applicable EBITDA figure divided by net sales for the corresponding period; - with respect to Crash Champions Holdings and Service King on a pro forma combined basis after giving effect to the Transaction Accounting Adjustments (as defined below), EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, 4-Wall EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA margin, 4-Wall EBITDA margin and Pro Forma Free Cash Flow. We define these non-GAAP financial measures as follows: `o` EBITDA is defined as earnings before interest expense, income tax expense and depreciation and amortization; `o` Adjusted EBITDA is defined as EBITDA as adjusted to exclude non-cash adjustments, transaction and integration-related costs, business optimization costs and non-recurring and normalization adjustments; `o` 4-Wall EBITDA is defined as Adjusted EBITDA generated by our facilities, but excluding all corporate-level costs; `o` Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA is defined as Adjusted EBITDA as further adjusted to reflect certain “run rate” benefits associated with acquisitions and investments made to expand our business as if they had been consummated as of the first day of the applicable period, cost savings and other adjustments that we will be permitted to include under the terms of the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities and the indenture governing the notes; `o` Adjusted EBITDA margin and 4-Wall EBITDA margin are defined as the applicable EBITDA figure divided by net sales for the corresponding period; and `o` Pro Forma Free Cash Flow is defined as Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA less capital expenditures into existing stores. We believe that presenting these measures may help investors better understand the historical financial performance of Crash Champions Holdings and Service King in connection with their analysis of our business. We believe that EBITDA is useful to assess our ability to generate cash from operations sufficient to pay taxes, to service debt and to undertake capital expenditures. We believe that Adjusted EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA margin are useful financial metrics to assess operating performance from period to period by excluding certain items that we believe are not representative of our core business. In addition, we believe that 4-Wall EBITDA and 4-Wall ----- EBITDA margin are useful financial metrics to assess the contribution of our locations excluding corporate-level costs. We also believe that Pro Forma Free Cash Flow is useful to assess our ability to generate cash. Historically, we have used these metrics for business planning purposes and in measuring performance relative to that of competitors. We present the adjustments to Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, including adjustments to reflect the estimated “run rate” benefits associated with acquisitions and investments made to expand our business as if they had been consummated as of the first day of the applicable period, as well as integration benefits, as they are permitted as adjustments to “Consolidated EBITDA” under the indenture that will govern the notes. In addition to the reasons set forth in the preceding paragraph, we present Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA to enable investors to understand the covenants that will apply to us. Neither Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA nor any related adjustment represents a projection of future results. We may be required to make significant cash expenditures as a result of future unforeseen costs, and these cash costs are not reflected in Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA. Accordingly, you should not view our presentation of this adjustment as a projection that we will achieve similar results in the future. In addition, the indenture governing the notes includes definitions of EBITDA-based metrics that are different from the definitions of EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and 4-Wall EBITDA used herein with respect to Crash Champions Holdings and Service King on a pro forma combined basis after giving effect to the Transaction Accounting Adjustments. We believe that the non-GAAP measures presented above are measures commonly used by securities analysts and investors to evaluate our performance and that of competitors and other leveraged businesses. Such non-GAAP measures are not presentations made in accordance with GAAP and should not be considered as alternatives to net income or net income attributable to non-controlling interest or any other performance measures derived in accordance with GAAP as measures of operating performance or operating cash flows as measures of liquidity. Our use of such non-GAAP measures differs from others in our industry. The presentation of such nonGAAP measures in this offering memorandum should not be construed to imply that our future results will be unaffected by unusual or non-recurring items. These measures have important limitations as analytical tools and you should not consider them in isolation or as substitutes for analysis of results as reported under GAAP. For example, EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, 4-Wall EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Free Cash Flow, whether presented in respect of Crash Champions Holdings, Service King or Crash Champions Holdings and Service King on a pro forma combined basis: - exclude certain tax payments that may represent a reduction in cash available; - do not reflect any cash capital expenditure requirements for the assets being depreciated and amortized that may have to be replaced in the future; - do not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, working capital needs; and - do not reflect the significant interest expense, or the cash requirements necessary to service interest or principal payments, on indebtedness. In addition, Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA, 4-Wall EBITDA and Pro Forma Free Cash Flow, whether presented in respect of Crash Champions Holdings, Service King or Crash Champions Holdings and Service King on a pro forma combined basis: - exclude various additional non-cash adjustments primarily driven by purchase accounting and lease accounting; - exclude certain one-time and non-recurring transaction and integration costs and expenses associated with shop acquisitions; ----- - add back non-recurring professional fees related to system implementations, training and other consulting fees, as well as one-time costs incurred to facilitate the attainment of the procurement synergies; and - reflect various normalization adjustments and adjustments for certain one-time costs in the applicable period. Further, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Free Cash Flow each reflect the estimated “run rate” benefits associated with acquisitions and investments made to expand our business as if they had been consummated as of the first day of the applicable period, as well as integration benefits. See “Summary—Summary Historical Financial Data of Crash Champions,” “Summary—Summary Historical Financial Data of Service King” and “Summary— Summary Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Combined Financial Information” for additional information, as well as reconciliations of these non-GAAP measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measure for the applicable periods. -----

This offering memorandum contains information that may constitute “forward-looking statements.” Generally, the words “believe,” “expect,” “intend,” “estimate,” “anticipate,” “project,” “will,” “plan” and similar expressions identify forward-looking statements, which generally are not historical in nature. However, the absence of these words or similar expressions does not mean that a statement is not forward-looking. All statements that address operating performance, events or developments that we expect or anticipate will occur in the future— including statements relating to volume growth, share of sales, and statements expressing general or specific views about estimated or future operating results—are forward-looking statements. Management believes that these forward-looking statements are reasonable as and when made. However, caution should be taken not to place undue reliance on any such forward-looking statements because such statements are assumptions and are inherently uncertain. We undertake no obligation to publicly update or revise any forwardlooking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise, except as required by law. In addition, forward-looking statements are subject to certain risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from our historical experience and our present expectations or projections. These risks and uncertainties include, but are not limited to: - the impact of competition; - our ability to maintain our relationships with insurance carriers; - increases in labor costs, supply and other operating costs, interest rates and inflation; - supply chain shortages and interruptions and our reliance on key suppliers; - our ability to sustain our historic rates of growth, expand our business and improve our margins; - failure to benefit from future acquisitions; - our ability to protect our reputation; - our ability to comply with various laws and regulations and the costs of such compliance; - the impact of potential litigation; - our ability to attract and retain qualified personnel; - material failure, interruption, security breaches or cyber incidents with respect to our information technology systems; - our insurance coverage may not address all of our potential exposures; - pandemics, epidemics, disease outbreaks and other public health crisis; - our ability to raise capital in the future; - the effect of potential future changes to accounting rules or regulations; - the effect of our substantial indebtedness on our ability to raise additional capital to repay our debt obligations; - the restrictions imposed on our operating flexibility by the restrictive covenants in the indenture that will govern the notes and by the New Credit Agreement; ----- - our inability to generate sufficient cash flows to service all of our indebtedness; - conflicts of interests between affiliates of Clearlake and holders of the notes; - restrictions on your ability to transfer or resell the notes without registration under applicable securities laws; - an active trading market may not develop for the notes; and - risks related to other factors discussed in this offering memorandum, including those described in “Risk Factors.” The information in this offering memorandum is not a complete description of our business or the risks and uncertainties associated with your investment in the notes. You should carefully consider the various risks and uncertainties that impact our business and the other information in this offering memorandum and, in particular, information appearing under the headings “Summary—The Offering,” “Risk Factors,” “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations of Crash Champions,” “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations of Service King” and “Business.”

Certain market, ranking and industry data included in this offering memorandum are based on estimates of our management. These estimates have been derived from our management’s knowledge and experience in the markets in which we operate, as well as information obtained from surveys, reports by market research firms, our customers, distributors, suppliers, trade and business organizations and other contacts in the markets in which we operate, which, in each case, we believe are reliable. While we believe the data from these sources to be accurate and complete, we and the initial purchasers have not independently verified data from these sources or obtained third-party verification of market share data and do not guarantee the accuracy or completeness of this information. In addition, these sources may use different definitions of the relevant markets. Data regarding our industry is intended to provide general guidance, but is inherently imprecise. Market share data is subject to change and cannot always be verified with certainty due to limits on the availability and reliability of raw data, the voluntary nature of the data gathering process and other limitations and uncertainties inherent in any statistical survey of market shares. As a result, you should be aware that market share, ranking and other similar data set forth herein, and estimates and beliefs based on such data, may not be reliable. References herein to our being a leader in a market or service category refers to our belief that we have a leading market share position in each specified market, unless the context otherwise requires. Certain monetary amounts, percentages and other figures included in this offering memorandum have been subject to rounding adjustments. Accordingly, figures shown as totals in certain tables may not be the arithmetic aggregation of the figures that precede them, and figures expressed as percentages in the text may not total 100% or, as applicable, when aggregated, may not be the arithmetic aggregation of the percentages that precede them.

The Issuer is a newly incorporated entity, has had no business transactions or activities to date and had no material assets or liabilities during the periods presented in this offering memorandum. Accordingly, there are no consolidated financial statements of the Issuer for any periods presented in this offering memorandum. In addition, following the completion of the Transactions, the Issuer will have limited assets other than its indirect ownership of the equity interests of Service King and Crash Champions Holdings. In connection with a change of control event whereby Clearlake acquired an indirect majority interest in Crash Champions Holdings (such transaction, the “Crash Acquisition Transaction”), Crash Champions Holdings elected to apply pushdown accounting to its separate financial statements. References to “Crash Successor” relate to the consolidated financial position and results of operations of Crash Champions Holdings subsequent to August 1, ----- 2022, the date when the Crash Acquisition Transaction was completed. References to “Crash Predecessor” relate to the consolidated financial position and results of operations of Crash Champions Holdings for the period January 1, 2022 through July 31, 2022 and the year ended December 31, 2021. The Crash Predecessor and Crash Successor periods have been separated by a vertical line on the face of the consolidated financial statements to highlight the fact that the financial data for such periods has been prepared under two different historical cost bases of accounting and the Crash Successor being presented with assets, liabilities, and a capital structure having carrying values that are not comparable with prior periods. In connection with the out of court financial restructuring of SK Holdco, LLC, a Delaware limited liability company (“SK Holdco”), and its subsidiaries (such restructuring, the “SK Restructuring Transaction”), New SK HoldCo Sub elected to apply pushdown accounting to its separate financial statements. References to “SK Successor” relate to the consolidated financial position and results of operations of New SK HoldCo Sub subsequent to July 14, 2022, the date when the SK Restructuring Transaction was completed. References to “SK Predecessor” relate to the consolidated financial position and results of operations of SK HoldCo, LLC between January 2, 2022 through July 13, 2022, and the fiscal year ended January 1, 2022. The SK Predecessor and SK Successor periods have been separated by a vertical line on the face of the consolidated financial statements to highlight the fact that the financial data for such periods has been prepared under two different historical cost bases of accounting and the SK Successor being presented with assets, liabilities, and a capital structure having carrying values that are not comparable with prior periods. This offering memorandum contains the audited consolidated financial statements of Crash Champions Holdings and its subsidiaries as of and for the years ended December 31, 2022 and December 31, 2021, as well as the audited consolidated financial statements of New SK HoldCo Sub and its subsidiaries as of and for the periods described above. Service King does not have any significant assets, liabilities or operations other than its ownership of the equity of New SK Holdco Sub. References in this offering memorandum to the financial statements of Service King refer to such financial statements of New SK Holdco Sub and its subsidiaries. References in this offering memorandum to the financial statements of Crash Champions refer to the financial statements of Crash Champions Holdings, LLC and its subsidiaries. This offering memorandum also contains the unaudited condensed consolidated financial statements of Crash Champions and its subsidiaries as of September 30, 2023 and for the nine-month periods ended September 30, 2023 and 2022, and the unaudited condensed consolidated financial statements of New SK Holdco Sub and its subsidiaries as of September 30, 2023 and for the nine-month period ended September 30, 2023 and the period from January 2, 2022 to September 30, 2022. This financial data has been prepared in accordance with GAAP. References in this offering memorandum to financial information of New SK Holdco Sub or Service King for the “nine months ended September 30, 2022” and similar references refer to financial information of New SK Holdco Sub for the period from January 2, 2022 to September 30, 2022. The financial statements and other financial information included in this offering memorandum for Service King, including the audited consolidated financial statements and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations of Service King,” reflect the consolidated historical results of operations of New SK Holdco Sub and its subsidiaries, which owns and operates the Service King business, which will be indirectly wholly owned by the Issuer following the consummation of the Transactions. The financial statements and other financial information included in this offering memorandum for Crash Champions Holdings, including the audited consolidated financial statements and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations of Crash Champions,” reflect the consolidated historical results of operations of Crash Champions Holdings and its subsidiaries, which owns and operates the Crash Champions business, which is indirectly wholly owned by the Issuer. Unless otherwise indicated, financial data identified in this offering memorandum as “pro forma” or “on a pro forma combined basis” reflects the pro forma combined financial data of Crash Champions Holdings and Service King after giving effect to the Transaction Accounting Adjustments in the manner described under “Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Combined Financial Information” and the notes thereto as if the Crash Acquisition Transaction, the SK Restructuring Transaction and the Transactions had occurred on January 1, 2022, in the case of statement of operations data, and as of September 30, 2023, in the case of balance sheet data. Financial data identified in this offering memorandum as “combined” or “on a combined basis” reflects an arithmetic combination of (i) Crash Predecessor and Crash Successor data, (ii) SK Predecessor and SK Successor data or (iii) Crash Champions Holdings and New SK HoldCo Sub data, as the context requires, and in each case does not give ----- effect to the Transactions, nor does it reflect certain other adjustments that would be required for pro forma financial data prepared in accordance with Regulation S-X, and references in this offering memorandum to financial data for the “year ended December 31, 2022,” “nine months ended September 30, 2022” and “twelve months ended September 30, 2022” of Crash Champions Holdings or Service King, as applicable, refer to the combined data of the applicable predecessor and successor entities for such periods. Certain financial data in this offering memorandum has been rounded and, as a result, the figures shown as totals in this offering memorandum may vary slightly from the exact arithmetic aggregation of the figures that precede them.

Section Title: NO REVIEW BY THE SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION
Subsubsection Text: The information included in this offering memorandum does not conform to information that would be required if this offering was made pursuant to a registration statement filed with the SEC. This offering memorandum, as well as any other documents in connection with this offering, will not be reviewed by the SEC. There are no registration rights associated with the notes, and we have no intention to offer notes registered under the Securities Act in exchange for the notes offered in this offering or to file a registration statement with respect to the notes. The indenture governing the notes will not be qualified under the Trust Indenture Act of 1939, as amended.

We do not intend our use or display of other companies’ trademarks, trade names or service marks to imply a relationship with, or endorsement or sponsorship of us by, any other companies. -----

Subsection Title: THE DIFFERENCE IS TRUST. This sentiment has served as the cornerstone of our DNA since Crash
Subsubsection Text: Champions’ inception as a single Chicago-area repair facility in 1999. We are the largest founder-owned collision repair platform and one of the fastest growing multiple shop operators (“MSO”) in the United States, offering accident repair services including dent repair and removal, auto painting, bumper and fender damage repair and ancillary scanning and calibration services for internal combustion engine, hybrid and electric vehicles. Our inherently non-discretionary service offering addresses essential vehicle safety and functionality following a vehicle accident. We maintain longstanding relationships with all major insurance carriers, resulting in approximately 97% of our repair revenue for the quarter ended September 30, 2023 coming from insurance-paid customers, of which approximately 90% is driven through Direct Repair Program (“DRP”) relationships, in which partner insurance carriers refer repairs to our shops. Since our founding in 1999, we have strategically expanded across the country through the execution of our national consolidation strategy, scaling to 619 facilities across 37 states as of October 2023. We have built a national presence through highly accretive acquisitions while simultaneously deploying our proven operational playbook to drive consistency of service quality as well as operational performance and efficiencies. We believe that we are uniquely positioned to capitalize on our growing national footprint and drive attractive sales and earnings growth by providing quality service to the growing car parc in a highly resilient and fragmented industry. ----- Our differentiated platform is relentlessly committed to providing a consistent and superior customer experience in every part of the repair process. As a leading collision repair platform, we maintained over 6,700 DRP relationships nationwide and have achieved significant DRP expansion, growing our program count at a 21% CAGR in the year-to-date period ended September 30, 2023. Our DRP relationships prioritize our services due to our (i) expedited turnaround times, (ii) technical expertise and well-invested facilities, which enable us to repair all vehicle types (including those equipped with the latest advanced driver assistance systems (“ADAS”) and electric vehicle (“EV”) technology), (iii) superior customer satisfaction that helps drive policyholder retention for insurance carriers and (iv) ability to deliver lower overall vehicle repair costs. Collision Repair Cycle Under founder and CEO Matt Ebert’s leadership, our platform has achieved significant growth, expanding into 37 states and increasing our footprint by over 260 shops since 2018 (excluding Service King), representing a compound annual growth rate (“CAGR”) of 116% from 2018 to October 2023. This expansion has been a key contributor to our growth, and on a combined basis we have grown our net sales and Adjusted EBITDA by 32% and 173%, respectively, for the twelve months ended September 30, 2023 compared to the twelve months ended September 30, 2022. In addition to increasing the number of locations that we operate, our net sales and Adjusted EBITDA growth has been driven by same store sales growth of 15% for the twelve months ended September 30, 2023 on a combined basis. The U.S. collision repair industry represents an estimated $44.8 billion non-discretionary and re-occurring revenue opportunity. The market is characterized by several long-term secular tailwinds, including steady car parc growth over the past decade, a consistent upward trend in vehicle miles traveled (“VMT”), and increasing accident severity driven by underlying increases in vehicle complexity. The U.S. collision repair industry is highly fragmented, with approximately 35,000 repair shops across the country, which are predominantly operated by regional, local and independent operators that lack the scale or resources to invest in the latest equipment and training required to repair the modern vehicle. The accelerating adoption of advanced vehicle technology is driving increased insurance carrier preference to refer repairs to national MSO platforms with the ability to invest in the ----- critical resources, including original equipment (“OE”) certifications and scanning and calibration services, required to repair the modern vehicle. MSO share of DRP appraised volume has increased from 11% in 2008 to 46% in 2022, according to CCC Intelligent Solutions Inc. In this highly fragmented industry, we believe that our combination of strategic organic growth investments and acquisition strategy uniquely positions us to expand our leadership as a national MSO platform.

Subsection Title: Industry Overview: The Large, Recession-Resistant and Highly Fragmented Automotive Collision Repair Industry
Subsubsection Text: We operate in the large, growing and highly fragmented U.S. collision repair industry, which is part of the broader $477.6 billion U.S. automotive aftermarket industry. Having grown at a 5.1% CAGR from 2017 to 2022, the U.S. collision repair industry has a long track record of consistent growth, according to the Autocare Association Factbook 2024. The non-discretionary nature of collision repairs has insulated the industry from economic cycles and driven long-term, stable growth. In addition, vehicle insurance coverage is mandatory for all drivers in the U.S., further supporting the non-discretionary nature of collision repair demand. The drivers of industry growth are increasing VMT and traffic congestion, growing car parc, collision frequency and collision severity. Source: Romans Report. Despite significant advancements in safety technology, collision levels have increased 3% per year as miles driven have steadily increased, according to data published by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. In addition, accident severity continues to accelerate collision repair service expenditures. Since 2010, the average total cost of repairs has increased at a 5% CAGR to approximately $4,300 per accident, and most recently at a 10% CAGR from 2020 to 2022. Increasing vehicle complexity results in the significantly higher average cost of repairs, with repair costs being driven by an increase in the number of parts replaced per claim, increased labor hours per claim, rising parts costs and increased demand for calibration and scanning services. Specifically, the average number of parts replaced and average labor hours per claim increased at a 4.3% and 1.5% CAGR, respectively, between 2011 and 2022. ----- Source: 2023 CCC Intelligent Solutions Report. The automotive collision repair industry remains highly fragmented with the majority of facilities managed by independent operators, creating a compelling opportunity for consolidation. We are one of only three companyoperated platforms with a national footprint. Currently, these top three players in the industry comprise only 9% of all U.S. collision repair shops. We belong to a limited tier of scaled providers, which is demonstrated by the fact that our platform has approximately 2.5 times the number of shops as the next largest provider. Source: Public filings and 2024 Auto Care Factbook. Our customers view the repair process as an extension of their relationship with their insurance provider. Given the impact a positive experience with a collision repair operator can have on a customer’s likelihood of renewing their automotive insurance policy, insurance carriers have developed DRPs to better manage auto body repair claims by simplifying the process of dispatching estimate requests and implementing quality standards and customer satisfaction measurement for collision repair facility operators. DRPs’ relationships with MSOs have ----- proven to save significant time in the repair process by standardizing the estimation process through a preestablished repair framework, while simultaneously increasing customer satisfaction and reducing repair costs. Over the past 20 years, MSOs have meaningfully increased their market share over independent collision repair facility operators as a result of significant operational and economic advantages. Insurance carriers continue referring more work to their national MSO partners, resulting in an over 1,100 basis point market share gain from 2018 to 2022. Source: 2023 CCC Intelligent Solutions Report based on CCC National Industry Annual Uploaded DRP Appraisal Count.

Subsubsection Title: Market Leader with Scale Advantages Driving Entrenched Relationships with Insurance Carriers in a Highly Fragmented Collision Repair Industry
Subsubsection Text: We are the largest founder-led collision repair platform and one of the largest national players with 619 facilities across 37 states. As a top three national player, our scale benefits yield superior shop-level performance relative to the average independent facility operator, driven by investments in advanced technology and a deep bench of highly qualified technicians, driving attractive cycle times and repair-versus-replace metrics that underpin our value proposition for insurance carriers. We believe our superior performance and relentless commitment to trust and customer satisfaction has led to longstanding, diversified relationships with leading insurance carriers. ----- Our comprehensive high-touch carrier management strategy incorporates central corporate relationships, as well as within each operating region and at the individual shop-level. Our strategy of focusing on insurance carriers at the corporate, regional and shop-level is designed to position us to be a better partner while also empowering our shop managers to have continuous dialogue with local carrier contacts, which supports a more efficient claims and repair process. This approach to carrier relationships creates a virtuous cycle, whereby (i) we receive additional repair referrals due to strong performance, (ii) higher volumes enable improved throughput that yields higher profitability, (iii) higher profitability enables increased platform investment to support additional capacity and (iv) increased capacity facilitates further carrier referrals. As the collision repair sector continues to consolidate, national carriers rely on scaled MSOs that provide better customer satisfaction, help with policyholder retention and deliver lower total repair costs for the insurer. As we have scaled, we have demonstrated the ability to grow with carriers into new markets based on local market capacity needs. As a trusted partner to our insurance carriers, we have developed an attractive carrier mix that is highly diversified and is expected to continue to drive overall volume, sales and earnings growth. Today, we average 11 DRPs per shop, while continuing to pursue channels to expand DRP relationships at new and existing shops, which should drive more predictable and increased revenue.

Subsubsection Title: Best-In-Class Operations Playbook Drives Compelling Unit Economics
Subsubsection Text: Our strong track record stems from our robust operating infrastructure supported by strong process planning and execution focused on standardization, repeatability and scalability. We take a standardized approach that promotes high performance standards across the platform to ensure compliance with carriers’ operating metrics. We have engineered highly repeatable processes that are designed to drive enhanced shop productivity, increase shop capacity to handle volume growth from DRP expansion and expand our service offerings to include our captive scanning and calibration business, Automotive Technology Experts (“ATE”), to capture the full repair value. Our data-driven approach to monitor real-time performance metrics allows us to continuously refine our operations. We utilize dashboards to closely track KPIs and any variances in financial and operational performance through metrics such as carrier assignments, capture rate, and work-in-progress, for visibility into the consistency of referrals, and sales-per-day and body technician retention and productivity for insight into current throughput. Our uncompromising focus on real-time data driven analytics is reflected in our leading performance metrics. As a result, our shops delivered an industry-leading average unit volume (“AUV”) of $4.3 million on an annualized basis for the quarter ended September 30, 2023, compared to the industry average of approximately $1.3 million for the same period. Our well-established operations playbook and data focused approach have resulted in attractive unit economics. Throughout our platform, we utilize our expertise by leveraging operating, financial, training, leadership and vendor management best practices to achieve efficiency at scale. We have streamlined regional support and overhead costs by instilling best practices and operational consistency across our network while improving overall shop-level execution. As a leading MSO, we benefit from scale procurement benefits, which afford us higher margins relative to independent operators. Specifically, we recognize procurement benefits across non-labor costs including paint and parts which, combined with greater volume, drive attractive unit economics across all our shops. We believe there is significant earnings potential embedded in our platform as we continue to realize scale benefits across our footprint and reinvest future excess cash flow into further platform expansion and efficiencies.

Subsubsection Title: Superior Service Levels Supported by Industry Leading Metrics
Subsubsection Text: Service is at the epicenter of what we do at Crash Champions. Our approach to continued operational improvement has resulted in superior service metrics relative to the industry. Outperformance relative to other operators allows us to further strengthen and expand our relationships with insurance carriers. For the periods noted below, our average length of rental was 16.6 days, compared to the industry average of 18.1, and our average total cost of repair was $4,076, compared to the industry average of $4,232, resulting in a significant cost saving for carriers. Furthermore, compared to industry averages, we consistently repair a higher volume of damaged parts relative to those we replace, and our total cost of repair is lower than the industry averages, underscoring our operational excellence. We expect to continue to be a preferred partner for insurance carriers given our successful execution against our playbook and maintenance of superior operational metrics relative to the broader industry. ----- (1) Crash Champions represents average of four quarters from Q4 2022 to Q3 2023. Industry figures based on Collisionweek data, calculated as an average of four quarters from Q4 2022 to Q3 2023. (2) Average of quarterly data for year ended December 31, 2022 per 2023 CCC Intelligent Solutions report. Labor sales mix is defined as percentage of total cost of repair attributed to body technicians. (3) Average of quarterly data for year ended December 31, 2022 per 2023 CCC Intelligent Solutions report. Industry figures represent average for DRP claims and estimates.

Subsubsection Title: Proven Growth Model Backed by Accretive M&A and Strategic Shop Investments
Subsubsection Text: We have fortified our platform and expanded our footprint through highly accretive M&A. Since 2018, we have completed more than 115 acquisitions, with each consisting of approximately two shops on average (excluding Service King). We are committed to completing acquisitions with disciplined underwriting and realization of operational improvements. We have developed a consistent acquisition and integration process predicated on high performance standards across the platform, repeatable processes designed to handle increases in volume, and scalable operating, financial, training, leadership and vendor management best practices. Our actionable and disciplined underwriting identifies highly synergistic targets by focusing on an array of key market and facility characteristics, including population demographics, proximity to our existing footprint, facility quality and incremental capacity, and quality of existing operational practices. As cohorts are integrated into our platform, we have recognized increases in both net sales and 4-Wall EBITDA margin based on our ability to (i) grow revenue by increasing DRPs and capturing ancillary service revenue from ATE, and (ii) optimize margins through procurement synergies, front of shop labor optimization, and fixed cost operating leverage. As illustrated in the table below, all of our cohorts of shops have significantly improved both revenue and 4-Wall EBITDA compared to the annual shop performance pre-acquisition for the respective periods. ----- Note: “Q3 2023 Annualized” included for comparative purposes and represents results for the quarter ended September 30, 2023 multiplied by four In addition to highly accretive M&A, our growth model is supported by strategic growth investment in existing facilities with attractive returns on invested capital (“ROI”). These high ROI projects target increasing throughput, which yields improved fixed cost operating leverage and enhances shop financial performance. Examples of these investments include adding production square footage, increasing paint booth capacity, increasing lift count and adding advanced equipment. In addition, we are committed to continuing to invest in our ATE business, which offers scanning and calibration services. These two services are natural extensions of the repair process that represent incremental revenue we are able to capture, compared to less well-equipped operators who are forced to outsource these services and sacrifice margins, as well as increasing overall cycle times. Currently, we offer ATE’s services in 44% of our shops, with plans to expand to over 80% of our shops by the end of 2024 given our recent capital investments. Through additional investments in our existing footprint, we believe we are well positioned to drive greater volume and 4-wall profitability.

Subsubsection Title: Robust Alignment and Rigorous Focus Through Differentiated Team Structure
Subsubsection Text: At Crash Champions, we have an established management incentive plan that extends all the way to the General Manager of every facility, which helps foster strong organizational alignment. We have a deep bench of talent throughout the organization and believe that our entrepreneurial mindset and deeply instilled commitment to training and employee development leads to greater retention, superior service and the best possible customer experience. Our highly integrated team structure places a strong emphasis on operational improvement and accountability at all levels, extending from Senior Vice Presidents, who manage large geographic footprints, to General Managers, who oversee daily shop operations and interact with customers. Our experienced leadership team is led by founder and Chief Executive Officer, Matt Ebert, who started in the business approximately 25 years ago as a mechanic and single shop operator. Matt and the leadership team are supported by experienced board members who have decades of experience as executives at leading carriers and service providers such as Safelite and Progressive. Our leadership team is highly committed to the business and its long-term growth plans and currently has over $100 million invested in the business. In addition, we conduct regular leadership training and development programming for our General Managers, which promotes best practices across the organization. Historically, we have achieved a very high retention rate for managers who attend these programs. Our emphasis on developing strong customer service is characterized by trust, transparency and communication at every step of the repair process.

Subsubsection Title: Drive Sales and Volume Through Existing Shops
Subsubsection Text: Our approach to quality assurance, efficient turnaround times and innovative service offerings has positioned us as a leader in the collision repair industry. Given our ability to deliver industry leading service metrics, we remain a preferred partner of the leading insurance carriers and see additional opportunities to grow our DRP network with insurance carriers. We have a strong track record of adding DRP relationships to our platform which, as of September 30, 2023, number over 6,700, an average of 11 per shop. Additionally, we continue to pursue high ROI investments in our shops to expand capacity and add body technicians to facilitate increased throughput, resulting in same store sales growth. In the twelve months ended September 30, 2023, we delivered 15% year-overyear same store sales growth combined across Crash Champions and Service King. Additionally, as we expand our ATE business throughout most of our shops, we expect scanning and calibration to be another lever of attractive growth. We see attractive opportunities to continue to drive same store sales growth by investing in our shops to facilitate further DRP growth, add body technicians and increase penetration of our ATE service, all resulting in increased shop throughput. -----

Subsubsection Title: Continue to Realize Significant Embedded Growth from Service King Integration and Other Recent Acquisitions
Subsubsection Text: In July 2022 and August 2022, respectively, Service King completed the SK Restructuring Transaction and Crash Champions completed the Crash Acquisition Transaction. Following such transactions, while remaining separate legal entities, we integrated Service King’s operations into our Crash Champions platform to form the third largest national collision repair platform. Since the combination with Crash Champions, Service King has undergone a significant operational transformation, underscoring our commitment to enhance efficiency and sustainable growth consistent with Crash Champions’ history. We immediately aligned leadership under Crash Champions’ management team and deployed our proven operational playbook. We executed several operational improvements aimed at streamlining corporate functions, enhancing talent recruitment and retention, and enhancing shop-level performance through increased shop throughput. In addition to bringing talent back to the shops, we spent significant time with our carrier partners on a national, regional and local level to onboard more DRP programs, as well as to realize rate increases more commensurate with rising repair costs. We consolidated our procurement organizations to leverage our combined scale and enhance our gross margins and further augmented our 4-Wall EBITDA margins by right-sizing our frontof-shop labor and in-sourcing high-margin scanning and calibration services through ATE. We streamlined our corporate cost structure with Service King utilizing Crash Champions’ operations, human resources, business development, finance and IT functions to unlock significant annualized cost savings, and we harmonized our critical IT infrastructure by integrating our key systems. Finally, we are nearing completion of rebranding Service King shops as Crash Champions locations. Our successful integration execution has driven significant outperformance over and above the $45 million of underwritten synergies, with additional opportunities to realize meaningful embedded growth based on operational improvements and recruitment of technicians, exercising advantages of being a larger platform and capitalizing on compelling trends for larger, well-integrated MSOs. Since integrating Service King with Crash Champions in 2022, we have achieved 4-Wall EBITDA margin improvement at integrated Service King shops in excess of 350 basis points for the quarter ended September 30, 2023. We continue to take action to advance both top and bottom-line performance through initiatives that we believe will continue to create earnings uplift with a target to improve our overall 4-Wall EBITDA margins from fiscal year 2023 margins by up to an additional 300 basis points over the medium term, the most important of which is increasing technician count to drive greater throughput. We are optimizing staffing levels through our recruitment programs and by developing talent internally through our Skills Training Education Program apprentice program. As we work towards reaching full staffing of technicians across our network where we have ample room for additional technicians, we expect to improve throughput at existing shops and drive additional fixed cost operating leverage to further improve 4-Wall EBITDA margins. Our successful integration of Service King has been a significant driver of earnings growth which we believe still presents a significant opportunity. -----

Subsubsection Title: Expand Footprint Through Accretive M&A and Greenfield/Brownfield Development
Subsubsection Text: We are committed to pursuing accretive M&A opportunities coupled with targeted greenfield and brownfield development. From the date of the Crash Acquisition Transaction through October 31, 2023, we added 89 shops through acquisitions and new developments. The collision repair industry remains highly fragmented and by focusing on accretive acquisitions with attractive unit economics and synergies, we expect to continue to drive attractive long-term returns. While acquisitions often require larger initial capital outlays than greenfield and brownfield developments, acquired units bring immediate cash flow through an established labor force and customer base that we are able to augment via increased DRP volumes. Through our long history of successful M&A, we have developed a defined Crash Champions playbook that takes new facilities from pre-acquisition announcement through their first 30 days, bringing acquired locations seamlessly into the Crash Champions ecosystem through implementation of best practices and standardization with existing shops with our Quick Response Force. From small-scale, single-facility acquisitions to our transformative merger with Service King, we believe that our ability to successfully acquire and integrate new facilities provides us with a competitive advantage. By leveraging the improvements enabled by our operating playbook as well as the revenue growth through the addition of DRPs, we historically have recognized significant multiple buy-down within 24 months following an acquisition. Our underwriting of the 2020 and 2021 cohorts, inclusive of cost synergies, indicates a 4.8x and 5.5x multiple,[1] respectively, on acquired shops with an opportunity to realize greater upside over a longer period. For the quarter ended September 30, 2023, estimated annualized EBITDA for the same cohorts indicates a 2.7x and 4.3x multiple, respectively. [2] As of September 30, 2023, we have exceeded our underwriting models for both cohorts, demonstrating our ability to execute on realizing cost synergies and to create value through meaningful volume increases at acquired shops within 24 months. Additionally, selective greenfield and brownfield development enables us to infill existing markets and build density. The addition of greenfield and brownfield units allows us to (i) leverage our strong carrier partnerships to drive immediate volume, (ii) capitalize on our scale procurement, and (iii) leverage our existing regional infrastructure. Our ability to pursue greenfield and brownfield development, complemented by our M&A track record, puts us in a leading position to scale our platform in an accretive manner.

Subsubsection Title: Drive Adoption of High Margin ATE Offering in Existing Footprint
Subsubsection Text: The increased prevalence of ADAS in new vehicle models is driving accelerating demand for scanning and calibration services. Between the first quarter of 2017 and the fourth quarter of 2022, as a percentage of repairable appraisals, scanning increased from 3% to 57%, and calibration frequency increased from 1% to 12%, highlighting the expansive growth opportunity that lies in scanning and calibration services. We launched ATE in 2019 and subsequently expanded nationwide, including deploying significant growth capital expenditures in 2023. We currently offer services at 44% of our locations with the ability to expand to over 80% of our shops by the end of 2024 based on our recent growth investment. We continue to invest in scanning and calibration technologies, which are becoming increasingly important and valued when servicing new models with complex electronic system components, including ADAS, which we believe will be a driver of future sales and earnings growth.

Subsubsection Title: Enhance Margins Through Productivity Initiatives and Operating Leverage
Subsubsection Text: As our business grows, we intend to continue utilizing our scale to drive operating leverage. Collision repair shops have certain fixed and semi-fixed costs, resulting in enhanced operating leverage for larger, more productive shops. Our ongoing implementation of the Crash Champions playbook in acquired shops enables these shops to efficiently process greater volumes. We plan to drive incremental throughput by investing in shop 1 Represents acquisition cohort median of enterprise value divided by Underwriting Model EBITDA (modeled annual EBITDA including cost synergies). 2 Represents acquisition cohort median of enterprise value divided by annualized Q3 2023 EBITDA (including synergies). Annualized figures are calculated by multiplying the corresponding results for the three-month period ending September 30, 2023, by four. For additional information, see “Risk Factors – Risks Related to the Transactions.” ----- optimization and renovations to take advantage of our carrier relationships and continue to drive higher assignment volume relative to independents. Throughout our facilities, we are also expanding ATE to capture greater volume of scanning and calibration revenue. We consistently utilize our internally developed training and leadership development programs to instill best-practices across our network and align our employees with the Crash Champions operating playbook. Through our consistent operational excellence, we are able to drive greater sales volume and operating leverage to generate improving margins and significant free cash flow.

On or about the issue date of the notes, the Issuer, a newly incorporated Delaware company, will enter into contribution agreements (the “Contribution Agreements”) with Carnelian Point Holdings, L.P. (“Carnelian”), a Delaware limited partnership controlled by affiliates of Clearlake, and certain wholly owned subsidiaries of Carnelian. The Contribution Agreements will provide that, among other things, and on the terms and subject to the conditions of the Contribution Agreements, (i) Carnelian will contribute all of its equity interests in Service King, which constitutes all of the issued and outstanding equity interests of Service King, to Champions Parent, Inc., a Delaware corporation and an indirect parent of the Issuer (“Parent”), (ii) Parent will contribute all of its equity interests in Service King to Champions Holdco, Inc., a Delaware corporation and the direct parent of the Issuer (“Champions Holdco”), (iii) Champions Holdco will contribute all of its equity interests in Service King to the Issuer, (iv) the Issuer will contribute all of its equity interests in Service King to Champions Purchaser, Inc., a Delaware corporation (“Champions Purchaser”), (v) Parent will contribute all of its equity interests in Crash Champions Blocker LP, a Delaware limited partnership (“Champions Blocker”) to Champions Holdco, (vi) Champions Holdco will contribute all of its equity interests in Champions Blocker to the Issuer, and (vii) the Issuer will contribute all of its equity interests in Champions Blocker to Champions Purchaser (such transactions, collectively, the “Reorganization”). Upon consummation of the Reorganization, the Issuer will indirectly hold all of the equity interests of Service King and Crash Champions Holdings.

Subsubsection Title: Entry into the New Credit Agreement
Subsubsection Text: Concurrently with the Reorganization, the Issuer expects to enter into a new senior secured credit agreement (the “New Credit Agreement”) with Bank of America, N.A., as administrative agent and collateral agent, and the lenders party thereto, providing for (i) a five-year $650 million term loan facility (the “New Term Loan Facility”) and a five-year $250 million revolving credit facility (the “New Revolving Credit Facility” and together with the New Term Loan Facility, the “New Senior Secured Credit Facilities”). See “Description of Other Indebtedness” for a description of the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities.

Subsubsection Title: Issuance of New PIK Preferred Equity
Subsubsection Text: Concurrently with the Reorganization, Parent expects to issue approximately $350 million of new nonconvertible, non-voting redeemable perpetual preferred stock (the “New PIK Preferred Equity”) to our existing equity holders, including Clearlake and members of our management team. We expect the issuance of the New PIK Preferred Equity to close concurrently with the completion of this offering of notes.

The Issuer intends to use the proceeds of this offering of notes, together with the proceeds from the New Term Loan Facility and the New PIK Preferred Equity, to repay the outstanding indebtedness of each of Crash Champions Intermediate and New SK HoldCo Sub, and to pay related transaction fees and expenses. See “Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Combined Financial Information” for additional information regarding the Transactions. -----
The following transactions will be completed prior to or concurrently with the issuance, by the Issuer, of the notes offered hereby (collectively, the “Transactions”).

We intend to use the proceeds from this offering, together with the proceeds from the New Term Loan Facility and the issuance of the New PIK Preferred Equity, to repay the outstanding indebtedness of each of Crash Champions Intermediate and New SK HoldCo Sub, and to pay related transaction fees and expenses. Actual amounts will vary from estimated amounts depending on several factors, including changes in the actual amount of expenses related to the Transactions.

In October 2023, we closed on our acquisition of regional Alabama-based MSO Auto Craft Collision Centers, a platform that allows us to better serve the greater Mobile, Alabama markets through its three facilities. This acquisition facilitated our entry into our 37[th] state, as we continue to expand our national footprint. In November 2023, we closed on our acquisition of Queen City Auto Rebuild, located in Redmond, Washington, to strengthen our leading collision repair platform in the Pacific Northwest. In December 2023, we closed on our acquisition of Adams Collision, adding four additional facilities to our Chicago-area footprint.

Service King had previously procured paint from Axalta Coating Systems, LLC (“Axalta”). In 2018, the legacy Service King platform agreed to an uneconomical contract with Axalta to secure a paint pre-bate given limited access to traditional financing. Following the integration with Crash Champions, in June 2023, Service King entered into a newly negotiated paint procurement contract with BASF Corporation (“BASF”), and in August 2023 commenced the transition of all Service King location paint booths from Axalta to BASF (the “Paint Conversion”). As of December 31, 2023, we had transitioned paint booths at Service King locations representing in excess of 80% of Service King’s revenue to be consistent with paint booths at Crash Champions locations. The one-time costs associated with terminating the contract with Axalta and converting these facilities were $17.1 million, which comprises the majority of the EBITDA adjustments included in business optimization costs in the twelve months ended September 30, 2023. We incurred the final costs associated with this transition in November 2023, which costs comprise the majority of the EBITDA adjustments included in business optimization costs for the quarter ended December 31, 2023. See “—Summary Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Combined Financial Information” for additional information regarding these adjustments. We believe that the conversion of our Service King locations’ paint booths to be commensurate with those in Crash Champions existing shops will continue to drive increased profitability.

(1) The unaudited pro forma condensed combined statement of operations data has been adjusted to give effect to the Transaction Accounting Adjustments as if they had been completed on January 1, 2022. For a discussion of the adjustments applicable to items (i) through (viii), see note (1) in “—Summary Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Combined Financial Information.” (2) For the quarter ended December 31, 2023, we estimate that, on a combined basis, our net sales were between $645 million and $650 million, gross profit was between $267 million and $269 million and selling, general and administrative expenses were between $219 million and $221 million. Although we continue evaluating certain components of our preliminary results, we expect to report an operating loss and net loss for the quarter ended December 31, 2023 on both a combined basis and on a GAAP basis for each of Crash Champions and Service King. ----- (3) Calculated by subtracting the unaudited pro forma statements of operations data for the nine months ended September 30, 2023 from the unaudited pro forma statements of operations data for the twelve months ended September 30, 2023. See “—Summary Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Combined Financial Information.” We are continuing to recognize the benefit of our concentrated efforts to improve the combined Crash Champions and Service King business financially and operationally, and our Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA profile continues to improve. On a pro forma combined basis, we estimate that EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA increased from $7.1 million and $27.3 million in the quarter ended December 31, 2022 to between $42.0 million and $44.0 million and between $57.0 million and $59.0 million in the quarter ended December 31, 2023, respectively, as we saw a meaningful decrease in integration-related expenses, as well as increased earnings from the continued ramp up of our growth investments in acquisitions, greenfield (“GF”) and brownfield (“BF”) facilities and ATE. In addition to certain non-cash items, the difference between EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA in the quarter ended December 31, 2023 was driven primarily by (i) $2.0 million in costs that were accrued in respect of the Transactions and (ii) $1.9 million in costs related to the conversion of paint booths at Service King locations, as further discussed below, to improve profitability. Furthermore, pro forma fully ramped acquisitions includes an incremental $3.2 million of EBITDA contribution due to acquisitions completed during the quarter ended December 31, 2023. As a result, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA is expected to be between $254.0 million and $256.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2023. Additionally, pro forma adjustments as a percentage of the total Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA decreased to approximately 24.0% for the year ended December 31, 2023 as compared to 35.0% for the twelve months ended September 30, 2023.

Champions Financing, Inc., a Delaware corporation incorporated on December 28, 2023, will be the issuer of the notes offered hereby and, after giving effect to the Transactions, will indirectly hold all of the equity interests of Service King and Crash Champions Holdings. Our principal executive offices are located at 601 Oakmont Lane, Suite 400, Westmont, IL 60559. -----

The following chart summarizes our organizational structure expected to be in place after giving effect to the consummation of the Transactions. This chart is for illustrative purposes only and does not represent all legal entities of the Company or all obligations of such entities. See “The Transactions,” “—The Offering,” “Description of Other Indebtedness” and “Description of the Notes,” for more information regarding the terms of the notes offered hereby and our other indebtedness following the consummation of the Transactions.

Clearlake Capital Group, L.P. is an investment firm founded in 2006 operating integrated businesses across private equity, credit, and other related strategies. With a sector-focused approach, the firm seeks to partner with experienced management teams by providing patient, long-term capital to dynamic businesses that can benefit from Clearlake’s operational improvement approach, O.P.S.[®] The firm’s core target sectors are industrials, technology, and consumer. Clearlake currently has over $70 billion of assets under management and its senior investment principals have led or co-led over 400 investments. The firm is headquartered in Santa Monica, CA with affiliates in Dallas, TX, London, UK, Dublin, Ireland, and Singapore. -----

The notes will be guaranteed on the issue date by each of our present and future, direct and indirect wholly owned U.S. restricted subsidiaries that are borrowers under (other than the Issuer) or guarantee our obligations under the New Credit Agreement. Ranking ....................................................................... The notes will be our and the guarantors’ general senior secured obligations and will: - rank senior in right of payment to any of our and the guarantors’ existing and future subordinated indebtedness; - rank equally in right of payment with all of our and the guarantors’ existing and future senior indebtedness (including indebtedness under the New Credit Agreement); - be effectively senior to any of our or the guarantors’ obligations that are not secured by a lien on the Collateral or that are secured by a junior priority lien on the Collateral, in each case to the extent of the value of the Collateral; - be effectively junior to any of our or the guarantors’ obligations under any existing and future indebtedness that are secured by liens on assets that do not constitute a part of the Collateral to the extent of the value of such assets; and ----- - be structurally subordinated to all of the existing and future indebtedness, claims of holders of preferred stock and other liabilities of our subsidiaries that do not guarantee the notes. On a pro forma basis after giving effect to the Transactions, as of September 30, 2023, we would have had approximately $1,300 million aggregate principal amount of senior secured debt outstanding, $650 million of which is comprised of borrowings under the New Term Loan Facility, which ranks pari _passu with the notes._ As of the issue date, all of our subsidiaries will guarantee the notes. Optional Redemption .................................................. On or after     , 2026, we may redeem the notes, in whole or in part, at any time at the redemption prices listed in the “Description of the Notes— Optional Redemption,” plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to, but not including, the redemption date. We may also redeem some or all of the notes before     , 2026 at the price of 100% of the principal amount of the notes being redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to, but not including, the redemption date, plus a “make-whole” premium. In addition, at any time before   , 2026, we may redeem up to 40% of the aggregate principal amount of the notes, using the net proceeds from certain equity issuances. Furthermore, at any time before     , 2026, we may redeem up to 10% of the aggregate principal amount of the notes during any 12-month period at a redemption price of 103% of the principal amount of the notes being redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to, but not including, the redemption date. See “Description of the Notes— Optional Redemption.” Change of Control Offer ............................................. Upon a change of control, we must offer to purchase the notes at a purchase price equal to 101% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest to, but not including, the purchase date. If holders of not less than 90% of the principal amount of the outstanding notes accept a change of control offer, we will have the right to redeem all of the notes then outstanding at a purchase price equal to 101% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest to, but not including, the redemption date. Our ability to purchase the notes upon a change of control may be limited by the terms of our debt agreements, including the New Credit Agreement. We cannot assure you that we will have the financial resources to purchase the notes in such circumstances. See “Description of the Notes—Change of Control.” ----- Asset Sales .................................................................. If we sell certain assets and do not utilize the net proceeds in compliance with the indenture governing the notes, we will be required to make an offer to use such proceeds to repurchase the notes at a price equal to 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest to, but not including, the date of repurchase.
