Section Title: UNAUDITED PRO FORMA CONDENSED COMBINED FINANCIAL INFORMATION
UNAUDITED PRO FORMA CONDENSED COMBINED FINANCIAL INFORMATION
Subsubsection Text: New SK Holdco Sub was formed on July 5, 2022 and is wholly owned by Service King, also formed on July 5, 2022. Service King is wholly owned by Carnelian, its ultimate parent. On May 27, 2022, SK Holdco and certain of its subsidiaries entered into an agreement for an out-of-court financial restructuring of SK Holdco and its subsidiaries. Pursuant to the SK Restructuring Transaction, which closed on July 14, 2022, SK Holdco transferred all of the assets and obligations of Service King Paint & Body, LLC and its wholly owned subsidiaries to New SK Holdco Sub in exchange for a 100% equity interest in New SK Holdco Sub. In connection with the change in control event, New SK Holdco Sub elected to apply pushdown accounting, in which the estimated fair values of assets acquired and liabilities assumed by Carnelian, as well as the goodwill resulting from the excess of the consideration transferred over the net assets acquired was recognized by New SK Holdco Sub in its standalone financial statements. On August 1, 2022, Crash Champions Holdings completed a change of control event, which included the exit of its previous controlling interest holder, and Champions Purchaser, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Carnelian, acquiring the majority interest in Crash Champions Holdings and effecting a merger that included the Company's non-controlling interest holders contributing net assets to Champions Purchaser or Carnelian, and extinguishing debt and certain other obligations. In connection with the change in control event, Crash Champions Holdings elected to apply pushdown accounting, in which the estimated fair values of assets acquired and liabilities assumed by Champions Purchaser, as well as the goodwill resulting from the excess of the consideration transferred over the net assets acquired was recognized by Crash Champions Holdings in its standalone financial statements. The following unaudited pro forma condensed combined balance sheet as of September 30, 2023 and unaudited pro forma condensed combined income statements for the year ended December 31, 2022, the nine months ended September 30, 2023, and the twelve months ended September 30, 2023 are based on the individual historical consolidated financial statements, respectively, of Crash Champions Holdings and New SK Holdco Sub included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. The unaudited pro forma condensed combined statements of operations give effect to the Crash Acquisition Transaction, the SK Restructuring Transaction, and the Transactions contemplated in this offering memorandum and described under the section entitled “Summary—The Transactions” (collectively, the “Transaction Accounting Adjustments”) as if they had occurred on January 1, 2022, and the unaudited pro forma condensed combined balance sheet gives effect to the Transaction Accounting Adjustments as if they had occurred on September 30, 2023. In this section, references to the use of the proceeds of the Transactions to repay indebtedness of Crash Champions Holdings refers to the repayment of the outstanding indebtedness of Crash Champions Intermediate, a wholly owned subsidiary of Crash Champions Holdings, which indebtedness is reflected in consolidated the financial statements of Crash Champions Holdings. The Transaction Accounting Adjustments set forth in the unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial information were made to effect: - Such transactions, collectively referred to in this offering memorandum as the Reorganization, which result in the Issuer indirectly holding all of the equity interests of Service King and Crash Champions Holdings. Such transactions have all been determined to occur under the common control of Clearlake for accounting purposes. - Adjustments to reflect the pushdown accounting applied as an effect of the Crash Acquisition Transaction and the SK Restructuring Transaction. - The issuance of the notes in this offering and the Issuer’s entry into the New Term Loan Facility, and the use of the proceeds thereof for the repayment of the outstanding indebtedness of both Crash Champions Holdings and New SK HoldCo Sub. - The contribution of proceeds from the issuance of New PIK Preferred Equity by Parent to the Issuer, and the use of such proceeds for the repayment of the outstanding indebtedness of both Crash Champions Holdings and New SK HoldCo Sub. 67 ----- The unaudited pro forma condensed combined balance sheet as of September 30, 2023 does not include the Transaction Accounting Adjustments reflecting the pushdown accounting applied as a result of the Crash Acquisition Transaction and the SK Restructuring Transaction as such pushdown accounting is already reflected in the historical consolidated balance sheets of Crash Champions Holdings and New SK Holdco Sub, respectively. The Transaction Accounting Adjustments are based upon available information and certain preliminary assumptions that Crash Champions Holdings and Service King management believe are reasonable under the circumstances. The unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial information is presented for informational purposes only and does not purport to represent what the results of operations or financial condition would have been had the Crash Acquisition Transaction, the SK Restructuring Transaction and the Transactions contemplated in this offering memorandum actually occurred on the dates indicated, nor do they purport to project the results of operations or financial condition for any future period or as of any future date. The unaudited pro forma condensed combined balance sheet and the unaudited pro forma condensed combined statement of operations as of and for the nine months ended September 30, 2023 have been derived from: - the historical unaudited interim consolidated financial statements of Crash Champions Holdings as of and for the nine months ended September 30, 2023, and the notes thereto included elsewhere in this offering memorandum; and - the historical unaudited interim consolidated financial statements of New SK Holdco Sub as of and for the nine months ended September 30, 2023, and the notes thereto included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. The unaudited pro forma condensed combined statement of operations for the year ended December 31, 2022 has been derived from: - the historical audited annual consolidated financial statements of Crash Champions Holdings as of and for the year ended December 31, 2022, and the notes thereto included elsewhere in this offering memorandum; and - the historical audited annual consolidated financial statements of New SK Holdco Sub as of and for the year ended December 31, 2022, and the notes thereto included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. The unaudited pro forma condensed combined statement of operations for the twelve months ended September 30, 2023 have been derived from: - the historical unaudited interim consolidated financial statements of Crash Champions Holdings as of and for the nine months ended September 30, 2023 and 2022, and the notes thereto included elsewhere in this offering memorandum; and - the historical unaudited interim consolidated financial statements of New SK Holdco Sub as of and for the nine months ended September 30, 2023 and 2022, and the notes thereto included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. - the historical audited annual consolidated financial statements of Crash Champions Holdings as of and for the year ended December 31, 2022, and the notes thereto included elsewhere in this offering memorandum; and - the historical audited annual consolidated financial statements of New SK Holdco Sub as of and for the year ended December 31, 2022, and the notes thereto included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. 68 ----- The unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial information should be read in conjunction with the sections entitled “Summary—The Transactions,” “Summary —Sources and Uses,” “Summary —Summary Historical Financial Data of Crash Champions,” “Summary —Summary Historical Financial Data of Service King,” “Risk Factors,” “Use of Proceeds,” “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations of Crash Champions” and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations of Service King,” as well as the audited and unaudited historical financial statements of Crash Champions Holdings and Service King and related notes appearing elsewhere in this offering memorandum. Assumptions underlying the Transaction Accounting Adjustments are described in the accompanying notes, which should be read in conjunction with the unaudited pro forma condensed combined financial information. 69 -----

Section Title: NOTES TO UNAUDITED PRO FORMA CONDENSED COMBINED FINANCIAL INFORMATION
Subsection Title: Adjustments to Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Combined Balance Sheet
Subsubsection Text: (a) Represents the net proceeds from this offering, and the New Senior Secured Credit Facilities, offset by their respective financing costs, as well as the contribution to the Issuer by Champions Parent, Inc. of proceeds from the issuance of the New PIK Preferred Equity, and the use of such proceeds for the repayment of the outstanding indebtedness of both Crash Champions Holdings and New SK HoldCo Sub. We expect to receive approximately $650 million of gross proceeds in connection with this offering. We account for certain incremental costs directly attributable to this offering by capitalizing them and offsetting such costs against the gross proceeds of the offering. Such costs are comprised of accounting and advisory fees, underwriting discounts, legal fees, and other professional fees, and totaled $6.5 million. The New Senior Secured Credit Facilities are comprised of the New Term Loan Facility and the New Revolving Credit Facility. We expect to incur approximately $650 million principal amount of new indebtedness related to the New Term Loan Facility. Debt issuance costs of $26 million incurred in connection with obtaining the New Term Loan Facility are offset against the carrying amount of the debt, and will be amortized on a straight-line basis over the 5 year term of the New Term Loan Facility as a component of interest expense. The New Term Loan Facility is assumed to bear interest at a rate of SOFR plus 5% and requires annual principal payments equal to 1% of the original principal amount. For the New Revolving Credit Facility, debt issuance costs of $5.0 million are capitalized and recorded in other assets and will be amortized over the term of the Revolving Credit Facility on a straight-line basis as a component of interest expense. The New Revolving Credit Facility is assumed to bear interest at SOFR plus 5%. The New Revolving Credit Facility is expected to remain undrawn immediately subsequent to the Transactions. In addition, we expect to receive approximately $341.5 million as an equity contribution to the Issuer of the net proceeds from the issuance of the New PIK Preferred Equity by Parent. The gross issuance amount of $350 million is presented net of financing costs of $8.5 million incurred by Parent. The proceeds will be used for the repayment of approximately $1,543 million of the outstanding indebtedness of both Crash Champions Holdings and New SK HoldCo Sub, which includes the repayment of accrued interest as of September 30, 2023 of $1.0 million and $3.1 million related to the historical indebtedness of Crash Champions Holdings and New SK HoldCo Sub, respectively. The proceeds will also be used to pay call premiums of approximately $39.7 million associated with the historical debt of Crash Champions Holdings and New SK HoldCo Sub, respectively, as well as an estimated $10.0 million of non-capitalizable professional services, other advisory fees and transaction costs incurred in connection with the Reorganization. For purposes of this pro forma presentation, the net issuance proceeds from the offering, the financing and debt issuance costs have been applied to the pro forma condensed consolidated balance sheet assuming they had occurred on September 30, 2023. Cash and cash equivalents includes the following cash inflows and cash outflows (in thousands): 74 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF CRASH CHAMPIONS
Subsubsection Text: The Crash Acquisition Transaction is treated as a business combination under ASC 805, Business Combinations, using the acquisition method of accounting, with Carnelian identified as the accounting acquirer. The 77 ----- Company has opted to apply pushdown accounting in its standalone financial statements. In this MD&A, references to “Successor” and “Successor Period” relate to the consolidated financial position and results of operations of Crash Champions Holdings from August 1, 2022 onward, following the completion of the Crash Acquisition Transaction, while references to “Predecessor” and “Predecessor Period” relate to the consolidated financial position and results of operations of Crash Champions Holdings for the period between January 1, 2022 and July 31, 2022, and the year ended December 31, 2021. The year ended December 31, 2022 (the “Combined Annual Period”) includes the results of operations for the Successor during the period of August 1, 2022 through December 31, 2022 and the results of operations for the Predecessor during the period January 1, 2022 through July 31, 2022. The nine months ended September 30, 2022 (the “Combined Nine Month Period”) includes the results of operations for the Successor during the period of August 1, 2022 through September 30, 2022 and the results of operations for the Predecessor during the period from January 1, 2022 through July 31, 2022. A vertical line in the consolidated financial statements and this MD&A delineates the separation between Predecessor and Successor Periods. This emphasizes that financial information for these periods is prepared using two distinct historical cost bases of accounting, with the Successor presenting assets, liabilities and a capital structure carrying values that are not comparable to prior periods in the financial statements. In the accompanying discussion, references to the “Company” pertain to both Successor and Predecessor for the applicable periods.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF CRASH CHAMPIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are a leading collision repair services platform and one of the fastest growing MSOs in the United States. We provide services primarily to insured motorists and claimants under automobile insurance policies. The Company is headquartered in Westmont, Illinois, and operated 278 vehicle collision repair facilities throughout the United States immediately prior to the Crash Acquisition Transaction. Our non-discretionary service offering includes dent repair and removal, auto painting, bumper and fender damage repair, and ancillary scanning and calibration services for internal combustion engine, hybrid and electric vehicles. The Company’s unwavering commitment to superior customer service is characterized by trust, transparency and communication at every step of the repair process. On August 1, 2022, the Company completed a change of control transaction, referred to as the “Crash Acquisition Transaction,” which included the exit of the controlling interest holder. As a result of the transaction, Crash Champions’ ultimate parent became Carnelian, with Carnelian acquiring a majority interest in the Company through its subsidiary, Champions Purchaser. Pursuant to the Crash Acquisition Transaction and the SK Restructuring Transaction completed by Service King, both Crash Champions and Service King became indirect subsidiaries of Clearlake. Following such transactions, while remaining separate legal entities, we integrated Service King’s operations into our Crash Champions platform. Since the combination with Service King, our management has been highly focused on the execution of several operational improvements to optimize shop-level performance and increase shop throughput. During the nine months ended September 30, 2023, Crash Champions same store sales increased by $84.9 million, to $647.3 million, compared to $562.5 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. Service King facilities same store sales increased by $96.6 million, to $1,045.7 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2023, compared to $949.1 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. The 15.1% and 10.2% increases in same store sales across Crash Champions and Service King shops, respectively, were primary due to increased throughput as well as increased average repair pricing. Ever since the opening of our initial collision repair center, our commitment to providing reliable and excellent repair services has remained unwavering. This dedication has not only boosted customer experience and satisfaction but has also established us as a preferred option for both insurance carriers and our customers.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF CRASH CHAMPIONS
Subsubsection Text: The highly competitive nature of the automotive collision and repair industry puts pressure on businesses to invest more capital to stay competitive. Larger competitors may have a greater scale and expertise, allowing them to provide services at lower costs, while smaller competitors may find it challenging to match the level of service quality and pricing. As a result, collision and repair businesses must allocate increased resources to operational efficiency to sustain a competitive advantage. The main competitive factors are scale, infrastructure, location, price, service, quality, customer satisfaction, insurance carrier relationships and adherence to various insurance key performance indicators.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF CRASH CHAMPIONS
Subsubsection Text: Advances and changes in automotive technology and automobile design, including, but not limited to, changes in the materials used for the construction of structural components and body panels, changes in the types of paints and coatings used for automobiles, and increased prevalence of collision avoidance technology as well as selfdriving vehicles and shared mobility, may reduce collisions, or change the equipment required to repair vehicles and increase our cost of providing repair services. In general, increasing vehicle complexity due to advances in technology has increased the cost associated with collision repair and benefited scaled MSOs who are able to invest in technology and training, resulting in additional opportunities to generate revenue; however, we are not always able to pass these cost increases on to insurance carriers in the form of higher prices.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF CRASH CHAMPIONS
Subsubsection Text: Maintaining a positive reputation is crucial for businesses in the automotive collision and repair industry. Failure to adhere to ethical and safety standards, as well as legal regulations, can result in negative publicity and damage the reputation of the business with the public and with insurance carriers, potentially leading to a loss of insurance carrier loyalty. In addition, adverse incidents, including accidents due to substandard repair work, can result in legal liabilities and financial penalties, further impacting the reputation and financial health of the business. 78 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF CRASH CHAMPIONS
Subsubsection Text: Based on our longstanding relationships with all of the major insurance carriers, approximately 90% of our customer repair revenue is driven through DRP relationships, in which partner insurance carriers refer repairs to our shops. Our goal with all carriers is to maintain relationships that are proportionate to their respective market share; however, that is not currently the case. As a result, the underlying performance of a given carrier to whom we are more or less exposed relative to the overall market could cause our performance and growth to differ from that of the overall market.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF CRASH CHAMPIONS
Subsubsection Text: Historically, we have fortified our platform and expanded our footprint through highly accretive acquisitions. As a leading collision repair growth platform, we are committed to completing acquisitions with disciplined modeling and realization of operational improvements. We continue to rely on acquisitions to drive a substantial portion of our growth, and to the extent we cannot continue to execute on highly accretive acquisitions our growth will likely decelerate.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF CRASH CHAMPIONS
Subsubsection Text: During 2021, although demand remained high, supply chain and labor shortages limited our ability to turn work-in-process into realized revenue. During 2022, the majority of our locations were fully operational. The future impact of COVID-19 or any other pandemic, epidemic or other disease outbreak is uncertain. See “Risk Factors Risks Related to Our Business—Pandemics, epidemics, disease outbreaks and other public health crises have disrupted our business and operations, and future public health crises could adversely impact our business, financial condition, liquidity and results of operations.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF CRASH CHAMPIONS
Subsubsection Text: We believe that the growth of our business and future success depends on a number of factors that present significant opportunities but also pose risks and challenges. The key factors that have impacted our business during the periods addressed in this MD&A and that are expected to impact our business going forward are discussed below.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF CRASH CHAMPIONS
Subsection Title: Key Components of Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: The Company derives its revenue primarily from repairing collision damage to customer owned automobiles. During the Successor Period, the Company recognizes revenue at the point in time when the repair work is completed and the repaired vehicle is available for pick up by the customer. Direct materials, labor and services are deferred as work-in-process inventory until the applicable repair work is completed. Direct materials, labor and services are recorded as cost of sales at the time the repair work is completed. During the Predecessor Period, the Company recognized revenue over time and the Company used the input method based on the labor hours on the repair orders as a percentage of total labor hours at the time of order completion to estimate revenue on the in-process vehicles. The impact of the change in revenue recognition policy was immaterial for all periods presented in the consolidated financial statements included in this offering memorandum due to the short duration of repair orders. Revenue is recorded net of discounts, sales incentives and rebates, sales taxes and estimated allowances.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF CRASH CHAMPIONS
Subsection Title: Key Components of Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Cost of sales is primarily comprised of direct materials costs (including the cost of parts, paint and other expenses such as waste disposals, shop supplies and towing costs), direct labor and services that are sublet to specialty providers. 79 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF CRASH CHAMPIONS
Subsection Title: Key Components of Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Selling, general and administrative expenses include overhead costs, indirect labor and related facilities costs, advertising costs, self-insurance costs, telecommunication costs, repair center and corporate rent expense and other miscellaneous administrative costs.

Subsection Title: Successor** **Predecessor For the Period August 1, 2022 through September 30, 2022 For the Period January 1, 2022 to July 31, 2022 Period** **$ Change** **% Change Combined Nine Month (Dollars in thousands) For the Nine Month Ended September 30, 2023
Subsubsection Text: For the nine months ended September 30, 2023, net sales increased by $331.3 million, or 57.6%, to $906.9 million when compared to $575.5 million for the Combined Nine Month Period ended September 30, 2022. The increase was primarily due to the strong demand for our services. Furthermore, the rise in vehicle complexity has driven increased parts requirements, increased pricing for parts and increased labor requirements, which all have led to higher bill rates and, consequently, an increase in the average repair pricing. Additionally, shop count grew through acquisitions of 16 shops during the Combined Nine Month Period. Same store sales increased by $84.9 million, to $647.3 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2023, compared to $562.5 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. This represents a 15.1% increase, primarily due to increased throughput at our facilities as well as increasing repair costs and vehicle complexity. The 80 ----- nine months ended September 30, 2023 recognized one less selling and production day when compared to the same period of the prior year and would have yielded a 15.7% with the additional selling and production day.

Cost of sales as a percentage of net sales for the nine months ended September 30, 2023 was relatively consistent as compared to the Combined Nine Month Period ended September 30, 2022.

As part of the Crash Acquisition Transaction, the Company’s then-existing debt was repaid, and the Company entered into a Successor credit agreement with various financial institutions maturing on August 1, 2029, consisting of an initial term loan, delayed draw term loans and a revolving credit facility. The increase in interest expense is primarily due to amounts accrued on the outstanding principal of such initial term loan and delayed draw term loans, the proceeds of which were used to fund the Crash Acquisition Transaction, as well as amounts accrued on the outstanding principal of such additional term loan, the proceeds of which were used to fund acquisitions and capital expenditures in the successor period.

Subsubsection Text: The table below sets out the results of Crash Champions’ operations for the years ended December 31, 2022 and 2021.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF CRASH CHAMPIONS
Subsection Title: Successor** **Predecessor For the Period January 1, 2022 to July For the Year Ended December Combined Annual For the Period August 1, 2022 to December (Dollars in thousands)** **Period** **31, 2022** **31, 2022** **31, 2021** **$ Change** **% Change
Subsubsection Text: For the Combined Annual Period ended December 31, 2022, net sales increased by $498.7 million, or 152.5%, to $825.8 million when compared to $327.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. The increase was primarily due to the strong demand for our services. Furthermore, the rise in vehicle complexity has driven increased parts requirements, increased pricing for parts and increased labor requirements, which all have led to higher bill rates and, consequently, an increase in the average repair pricing. Additionally, shop count grew significantly through acquisitions of 94 shops during the Combined Annual Period. Same store sales increased by $108.0 million to $422.2 million during the Combined Annual Period ended December 31, 2022, compared to $314.2 million during the year ended December 31, 2021. This represents a 34.4% increase, primarily due to increased demand for our services due to ongoing market recovery, increased throughput at our facilities and higher repair costs.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF CRASH CHAMPIONS

Subsubsection Text: Cost of sales increased by $315.1 million, or 164.6%, to $506.5 million for the Combined Annual Period ended December 31, 2022, compared to $191.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, due to the increase in sales resulting from strong demand recovery. Cost of sales as a percentage of net sales increased to 61.3% during the Combined Annual Period ended December 31, 2022, from 58.5% in the year ended December 31, 2021, primarily due to labor market pressures, including rising labor costs and increased parts, sublet and material costs. 82 -----

Subsection Title: Non-GAAP Financial Measures and Key Performance Indicators
Subsubsection Text: We present “same store sales,” which compares revenue for a particular period with the corresponding period in the prior year, excluding the impact of sales from newly opened or closed collision repair centers. Our same store sales are comprised of revenue from collision repair center operating for at least thirteen months and remaining open throughout the period. A collision repair center which is closed permanently, such as upon 83 ----- termination of the lease, is immediately removed from the same store sales computation. Acquired collision repair centers are included in the same store sales calculation on a rolling-monthly basis after operating for twelve months. Our calculation of same store sales may differ from the calculation of this metric as presented by others.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF CRASH CHAMPIONS
Subsection Title: Non-GAAP Financial Measures and Key Performance Indicators
Subsubsection Text: We use EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA for operational, strategic and financial decision making, including the preparation of our annual and long-term operating plan and evaluation of our overall business performance. We believe presenting these non-GAAP financial measures provides additional information to facilitate comparison of our historical operating results and trends in our underlying operating results and provides additional transparency on how we evaluate our business. Presenting EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA allows investors to view our performance using the same measures that we use in evaluating our financial and business performance and trends. We further believe that EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA are frequently used by securities analysts, investors and other interested parties in their evaluation of companies, many of which present EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA measures when reporting their results. Adjusted EBITDA is not a recognized term under GAAP and should not be considered a substitute for net income, cash flows from operating activities, or other income or cash flow statement data. See the “Non-GAAP Financial Measures” section of this offering memorandum for additional information. Below are the reconciliations of EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA to net income (loss), the most closely comparable financial measure calculated in accordance with GAAP, for the periods presented in this MD&A.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF CRASH CHAMPIONS
Subsubsection Text: As of September 30, 2023, the Company had outstanding floating and fixed rate debt with varying maturities for an aggregate principal amount of $739.5 million, with $7.8 million payable within twelve months. Principal installments began in the first quarter of 2023, and interest is payable quarterly. All unpaid principal amounts are due at maturity. In addition, our existing revolving credit facility allows borrowings of up to $60.0 million, until the earlier of (i) August 1, 2028 and (ii) the date of termination of such senior secured revolving credit facility, with no outstanding borrowings as of September 30, 2023. In connection with this offering and the other Transactions contemplated in this offering memorandum and described under the section entitled “Summary—The Transactions,” the Issuer, a newly formed Delaware corporation that will become the indirect parent of the Company, is expected to incur approximately $1.3 billion aggregate principal amount of new indebtedness in the form of the New Term Loan Facility and the notes. Additionally, Champions Parent, Inc., the indirect parent of the Issuer, is expected to contribute the net proceeds from the issuance of New PIK Preferred Equity contemplated in this offering memorandum and described under the section entitled “Summary—The Transactions” to the Issuer. The proceeds from the New Term Loan Facility, the notes and the New PIK Preferred Equity will be used for, among other things, the repayment of $729.6 million aggregate principal amount of the Company’s outstanding indebtedness, including accrued interest. The proceeds will also be used to pay call premiums, debt issuance costs, and non-capitalizable professional services, other advisory fees and transaction costs incurred in connection with the Transactions. See “Use of Proceeds” for additional information. The interest rates applicable to these contemplated debt obligations have yet to be determined. Based on an assumed annual interest rate of SOFR plus 5.0%, as well as amortization of debt issuance costs, we would expect the annual interest expense of the Issuer to be approximately $121.6 million. It is estimated that a one-eighth percentage change in the annual interest rate on the Issuer’s variable rate obligations would change annual interest expense by $0.8 million. In April 2023, the Company entered into two separate interest rate swap arrangements, each with a notional amount of $200.0 million, to mitigate the interest rate risk associated with interest rate payments related to its variable debt. The two swap arrangements have fixed rates of 4.03% and 4.06%, respectively. The two swap arrangements require quarterly settlements of the difference between the stated fixed rate and current variable rate, and mature on April 30, 2025. As of September 30, 2023, the fair value of these swap arrangements was in an asset position of $7.2 million. The Company expects to maintain these interest rate swap arrangements after the consummation of this offering and the Transactions.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF CRASH CHAMPIONS

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF CRASH CHAMPIONS
Subsubsection Title: Impairment of goodwill and other indefinite-lived intangible assets
Subsubsection Text: Goodwill is considered and indefinite-lived intangible asset, evaluated for impairment when triggers are present and annually. The Company accounts for goodwill as the excess of the purchase price over the net amount of identifiable assets acquired and liabilities assumed in a business combination measured at fair value. Goodwill is not subject to amortization; rather, the Company tests goodwill for impairment annually on October 1 and whenever events occur or changes in circumstances indicate that impairment may have occurred. Impairment testing is performed by first assessing qualitative factors to see if further testing of goodwill is required. If the Company concludes that it is more likely than not that a reporting unit’s fair value is less than its carrying amount based on the qualitative assessment, then a quantitative test is required. For the quantitative test on goodwill, the income approach (discounted cash flow and market approach) is primarily used. Management makes significant assumptions regarding future sales trends, growth rates, expenses, tax considerations and discount rates. The guideline public company method is also employed, involving the selection of comparable companies and application of valuation multiples. Indefinite-lived intangible assets are not amortized but assessed for impairment annually and when an event occurs, or circumstances change such that it is more likely than not that an impairment may exist. The annual testing date is October 1. Regarding trade name intangible assets, a quantitative test is performed using the income approach. Key assumptions include future sales trends and discount rates applied to forecasted revenue streams. However, there is inherent uncertainty in forecasting future results, especially considering the reliance on economic conditions. Any decline in customer traffic or average repair order could reduce sales and impact overall profitability. This could affect the Company’s future cash flows.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF CRASH CHAMPIONS
Subsubsection Text: The Company uses the acquisition method for accounting for acquired businesses, including the Company’s acquisition by Carnelian, for which management opted to apply pushdown accounting in its own financial statements. Under the acquisition method, assets and liabilities are recorded at estimated fair values at the acquisition date, and any excess of the purchase price over the fair values is recorded as goodwill. Estimating the fair value, especially for intangible assets, involves significant judgment, often requiring third-party valuation specialists for significant acquisitions. Real property and intangible assets, such as trade names, are valued based on historical information, expectations and assumptions about the future from the perspective of marketplace participants. In the case of acquired leases, a right-of-use (ROU) asset and lease obligations are recorded at the present value of remaining lease payments, adjusted for market terms. Despite believing expectations and assumptions about the future are reasonable, inherent uncertainty exists, and unforeseen events may impact the accuracy and validity of estimates.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF CRASH CHAMPIONS
Subsubsection Text: Purchased property, plant and equipment are recorded at cost and property, plant and equipment acquired as part of a business acquisition are recorded at fair value. Both are presented net of accumulated depreciation and 89 ----- amortization. Buildings include property we have acquired under build-to-suit arrangements and finance lease arrangements. Long-lived assets at the location level are evaluated for recoverability whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that its carrying amount may not be recoverable. The estimates we use when assessing the recoverability of assets are consistent with those we use in our internal planning. The variability of these factors depends on a number of conditions and, thus, our accounting estimates may change from period to period. The impairment analyses involve estimates due to the inherent judgment in forecasting cash flows and determining the assets’ ultimate useful lives and fair values. Actual results differing from these estimates could significantly impact the impairment assessment.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF CRASH CHAMPIONS
Subsubsection Text: The preparation of the Company’s financial statements in conformity with GAAP requires management to make estimates, assumptions and judgments influencing reported asset and liability amounts, disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities as of the financial statement date and reported revenue and expenses during the reporting period. Management engages in subjective estimates and assumptions concerning future events, significantly impacting revenues, fair value determinations and the recognition of interest income on financing receivables. 88 ----- The Company adheres to a policy of regular evaluation of its estimates, assumptions and judgments, basing them on historical experience and factors deemed reasonable under the circumstances. The outcomes of these evaluations involve judgments about the carrying values of assets and liabilities not readily apparent from other sources. Any alterations in the Company’s assumptions or conditions may lead to actual results differing significantly from these estimates. While the Company believes the estimates and assumptions underpinning its consolidated financial statements are reasonable and supportable, the uncertainty surrounding current economic conditions, increasing interest rates and the performance of the Company’s business renders these estimates less certain than they would be in the absence of these conditions.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF CRASH CHAMPIONS
Subsubsection Text: _The following discussion and analysis is intended to help the reader understand the business, financial condition, results of operations, liquidity and capital resources of Crash Champions Holdings, and should be read in conjunction with Crash Champions Holdings’ audited annual consolidated financial statements and unaudited consolidated financial statements and related notes included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. This discussion contains forward-looking statements reflecting our current expectations, estimates and assumptions concerning events and financial trends that may affect our future operating results or financial position. Actual results and the timing of events may differ materially from those contained in these forward-looking statements due to a number of factors, including those discussed in the sections entitled “Risk Factors” and “Cautionary Note Regarding Forward-Looking Statements” appearing elsewhere in this offering memorandum. The following discussion and analysis covers periods prior to the consummation of the Transactions. Accordingly, the discussion and analysis of historical periods does not reflect the impact of the Transactions. For purposes of this management’s discussion and analysis of financial condition and results of operations (this “MD&A”), references to “Crash Champions,” “the Company,” “us,” “we,” and “our” refer to Crash Champions Holdings, LLC and its consolidated subsidiaries without giving effect to the Transactions. References to the “year ended December 31, 2022” and similar references refer to the Combined Annual Period (as defined below) and references to the “nine months ended September 30, 2022” and similar references refer to the Combined Nine Month Period (as defined below)._

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Text: The SK Restructuring Transaction is treated as a business combination under ASC 805, Business Combinations, using the acquisition method of accounting, with Carnelian identified as the accounting acquirer. The Company has opted to apply pushdown accounting in its standalone financial statements. In this MD&A, references to “Successor” and “Successor Period” relate to the consolidated financial position and results of operations of New SK HoldCo Sub, LLC from July 14, 2022 onward, following the completion of the SK Restructuring Transaction, while references to “Predecessor” and “Predecessor Period” relate to the consolidated financial position and results of operations of SK HoldCo for the period between January 2, 2022 and July 13, 2022, as well as the year ended January 1, 2022. The year ended December 31, 2022 (the “Combined Annual Period”) includes the results of operations for the Successor during the period of July 14, 2022 through December 31, 2022 and the results of operations for the Predecessor during the period from January 2, 2022 through July 13, 2022. The nine months ended September 30, 2022 (the “Combined Nine Month Period”) includes the results of operations for the Successor during the period of 91 ----- July 14, 2022 through September 30, 2022 and the results of operations for the Predecessor during the period from January 2, 2022 through July 13, 2022. A vertical line in the consolidated financial statements and this MD&A delineates the separation between Predecessor and Successor Periods. This emphasizes that financial information for these periods is prepared using two distinct historical cost bases of accounting, with the Successor presenting assets, liabilities and a capital structure carrying values that are not comparable to prior periods in the financial statements. In the accompanying discussion, references to the “Company” pertain to both Successor and Predecessor for the applicable periods.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Text: We are one of the largest owners and operators of collision repair centers in the United States. Service King was founded in 1976 and has grown from a single location in Dallas, Texas, to 332 locations across 24 states and the District of Columbia with approximately 5,050 employees as of September 30, 2023. The majority of our repair volumes are driven by our long-term relationships with insurance carriers that partner with us because of our best-in-class operations. On May 27, 2022, SK Holdco and certain of its subsidiaries entered into a Transaction Service Agreement (“TSA”), which provided for the financial restructuring of SK Holdco and its subsidiaries, referred to as the “SK Restructuring Transaction.” Pursuant to the SK Restructuring Transaction, which was consummated on July 14, 2022, SK Holdco transferred all of the assets and obligations of Service King Paint & Body, LLC and its wholly owned subsidiaries to New SK Holdco Sub in exchange for a 100% equity interest in New SK Holdco Sub. The Company, a Delaware limited liability company, was formed on July 5, 2022, pursuant to the terms of the TSA. The Company is wholly owned by New SK Holdco, Inc., a Delaware corporation, which is wholly owned by Carnelian, the Company’s ultimate parent.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Text: The highly competitive nature of the automotive collision and repair industry puts pressure on businesses to invest more capital to stay competitive. Larger competitors may have a greater scale and expertise, allowing them to provide services at lower costs, while smaller competitors may find it challenging to match the level of service quality and pricing. As a result, collision and repair businesses must allocate increased resources to operational efficiency to sustain a competitive advantage. The main competitive factors are scale, infrastructure, location, price, service, quality, customer satisfaction, insurance carrier relationships and adherence to various insurance key performance indicators.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Text: Advances and changes in automotive technology and automobile design, including, but not limited to, changes in the materials used for the construction of structural components and body panels, changes in the types of paints and coatings used for automobiles, and increased prevalence of collision avoidance technology as well as selfdriving vehicles and shared mobility, may reduce collisions, or change the equipment required to repair vehicles and increase our cost of providing repair services. In general, increasing vehicle complexity due to advances in technology has increased the cost associated with collision repair and benefited scaled MSOs who are able to invest in technology and training, resulting in additional opportunities to generate revenue; however, we are not always able to pass these cost increases on to insurance carriers in the form of higher prices.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Text: Maintaining a positive reputation is crucial for businesses in the automotive collision and repair industry. Failure to adhere to ethical and safety standards, as well as legal regulations, can result in negative publicity and damage the reputation of the business with the public and with insurance carriers, potentially leading to a loss of insurance carrier loyalty. In addition, adverse incidents, including accidents due to substandard repair work, can result in legal liabilities and financial penalties, further impacting the reputation and financial health of the business.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Text: Based on our longstanding relationships with all of the major insurance carriers, approximately 90% of our customer repair revenue is driven through DRP relationships, in which partner insurance carriers refer repairs to our shops. Our goal with all carriers is to maintain relationships that are proportionate to their respective market share; however, that is not currently the case. As a result, the underlying performance of a given carrier to whom we are more or less exposed relative to the overall market could cause our performance and growth to differ from that of the overall market. 92 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Text: Historically, we have fortified our platform and expanded our footprint through highly accretive acquisitions. As a leading collision repair growth platform, we are committed to completing acquisitions with disciplined modeling and realization of operational improvements. We continue to rely on acquisitions to drive a substantial portion of our growth, and to the extent we cannot continue to execute on highly accretive acquisitions our growth will likely decelerate.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Text: During 2021, although demand remained high, supply chain and labor shortages limited our ability to turn work-in-process into realized revenue. During 2022, the majority of our locations were fully operational. The future impact of COVID-19 or any other pandemic, epidemic or other disease outbreak is uncertain. See “Risk Factors— Risks Related to Our Business—Pandemics, epidemics, disease outbreaks and other public health crises have disrupted our business and operations, and future public health crises could adversely impact our business, financial condition, liquidity and results of operations.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Text: We believe that the growth of our business and future success depends on a number of factors that present significant opportunities but also pose risks and challenges. The key factors that have impacted our business during the periods addressed in this MD&A and that are expected to impact our business going forward are discussed below.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsection Title: Key Components of Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: The Company derives its revenue primarily from repairing collision damage to automobiles. Direct materials, labor and services are deferred as work-in-process inventory until the applicable repair work is completed. Payments received for work not yet completed are deferred until the work is finished. When the repair work is completed and the repaired automobile is available for pick up by the customer, revenue is recognized and direct materials, labor and services are recorded as cost of sales. The Company presents revenue net of sales taxes.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsection Title: Key Components of Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Cost of sales is primarily comprised of direct materials costs (including the cost of parts, paint and other repair materials and supplies), direct labor and related benefit costs.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsection Title: Key Components of Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Selling, general and administrative expenses include shop-level overhead costs, indirect labor and related benefits costs, advertising costs, self-insurance costs, telecommunication costs, shop and corporate rent expense and other miscellaneous administrative costs. Selling, general and administrative expenses are presented net of sublease rental income from the subleasing of space in certain body shop facilities, primarily to rental car agencies and insurance carriers.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsection Title: Successor** **Predecessor For the Period July 14, 2022 to September 30, 2022 For the Period January 2, 2022 to July 13, 2022 Combined Nine Month Period Ended September 30, 2022** **$ Change** **% Change (Dollars in thousands) For the Nine Months Ended September 30, 2023
Subsubsection Text: Net sales increased by $95.4 million, or 10.0%, during the nine months ended September 30, 2023 to $1,047.8 million, compared to $952.4 million for the Combined Nine Month Period ended September 30, 2022. The increase was primarily due to the strong demand for our services. Furthermore, the rise in vehicle complexity has driven increased parts requirements, increased pricing for parts and increased labor requirements, which all have led to higher bill rates and, consequently, an elevation in the average repair pricing. Same store sales increased by $96.6 million, to $1,045.7 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2023, compared to $949.1 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. This represents a 10.2% increase, primarily due to increased throughput at our facilities as well as increasing repair costs and vehicle complexity. The nine months ended September 30, 2023 recognized one less selling and production day when compared to the same period of the prior year and would have yielded a 10.8% with the additional selling and production day. Finally, the increase is also due to enhancements to our management structure following the integration of our operations into the Crash Champions platform, resulting in increased throughput, improved insurance carrier relations, higher body tech headcount and improved productivity across a majority of markets.

Cost of sales as a percentage of net sales for the nine months ended September 30, 2023 was relatively consistent as compared to the Combined Nine Month Period ended September 30, 2022. 94 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsection Title: Non-GAAP Financial Measures and Key Performance Indicators
Subsubsection Text: We present “same store sales,” which compares revenue for a particular period with the corresponding period in the prior year, excluding the impact of sales from newly opened or closed collision repair centers. Our same store sales are comprised of revenue from collision repair centers operating for at least thirteen months and remaining open throughout the period. A collision repair center which is closed permanently, such as upon termination of the lease, is immediately removed from the same store sales computation. Acquired collision repair centers are included in the same store sales calculation on a rolling-monthly basis after operating for twelve months. Our calculation of same store sales may differ from the calculation of this metric as presented by others.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsection Title: Non-GAAP Financial Measures and Key Performance Indicators
Subsubsection Text: We use EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA for operational, strategic and financial decision making, including the preparation of our annual and long-term operating plan and evaluation of our overall business performance. We believe presenting these non-GAAP financial measures provides additional information to facilitate comparison of our historical operating results and trends in our underlying operating results and provides additional transparency on how we evaluate our business. Presenting EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA allows investors to view our performance using the same measures that we use in evaluating our financial and business performance and trends. We further believe that EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA are frequently used by securities analysts, investors and other interested parties in their evaluation of companies, many of which present EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA measures when reporting their results. Adjusted EBITDA is not a recognized term under GAAP and should not be considered a substitute for net income, cash flows from operating activities, or other income or cash flow statement data. See the “Non-GAAP Financial Measures” section of this offering memorandum for additional information. Below are the reconciliations of EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA to net income (loss), the most closely comparable financial measure calculated in accordance with GAAP, for the periods presented in this MD&A: 97 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Text: As of September 30, 2023, the Company had outstanding floating and fixed rate debt with varying maturities for an aggregate principal amount of $809.5 million, with $8.0 million payable within twelve months. In addition, our existing revolving credit facility allows borrowings of up to $57.0 million, with no outstanding borrowings as of September 30, 2023. In connection with this offering and the other Transactions contemplated in this offering memorandum and described under the section entitled “Summary—The Transactions,” the Issuer, a newly formed Delaware corporation that will become the indirect parent of the Company, is expected to incur approximately $1.3 billion aggregate principal amount of new indebtedness in the form of the New Term Loan Facility and the notes. Additionally, Champions Parent, Inc., the indirect parent of the Issuer, is expected to contribute the net proceeds from the issuance of New PIK Preferred Equity contemplated in this offering memorandum and described under the section entitled “Summary—The Transactions” to the Issuer. The proceeds from the New Term Loan Facility, the notes and the New PIK Preferred Equity will be used for, among other things, the repayment of the Company’s $809.5 million aggregate principal amount of outstanding indebtedness as of September 30, 2023, including accrued interest. The proceeds will also be used to pay call premiums, debt issuance costs and transaction costs incurred in connection with the Transactions. See “Use of Proceeds” for additional information. The interest rates applicable to these contemplated debt obligations have yet to be determined. Based on an assumed annual interest rate of SOFR plus 5.0%, as well as amortization of debt issuance costs, we would expect the annual interest expense of the Issuer to be approximately $121.6 million. It is estimated that a one-eighth percentage change in the annual interest rate on the Issuer’s variable rate obligations would change annual interest expense by $0.8 million.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Text: Goodwill is evaluated for impairment when triggers are present and annually. The Company accounts for goodwill as the excess of the purchase price over the net amount of identifiable assets acquired and liabilities assumed in a business combination measured at fair value. Goodwill is not subject to amortization; rather, the Company tests goodwill for impairment annually on October 1 and whenever events occur or changes in circumstances indicate that impairment may have occurred. Impairment testing is performed by first assessing qualitative factors to see if further testing of goodwill is required. If the Company concludes that it is more likely than not that a reporting unit’s fair value is less than its carrying amount based on the qualitative assessment, then a quantitative test is required. For the quantitative test on goodwill, the income approach (discounted cash flow and market approach) is primarily used. Management makes significant assumptions regarding future sales trends, growth rates, expenses, tax considerations and discount rates. The guideline public company method is also employed, involving the selection of comparable companies and application of valuation multiples. However, there is inherent uncertainty in forecasting future results, especially considering the reliance on economic conditions. Any decline in customer traffic or average repair order could reduce sales and impact overall profitability. This could affect the Company’s future cash flows.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Text: The Company uses the acquisition method for accounting for the Company’s acquisition by Carnelian, for which management opted to apply pushdown accounting in its own financial statements. Under the acquisition method, assets and liabilities are recorded at estimated fair values at the acquisition date, and any excess of the purchase price over the fair values is recorded as goodwill. Estimating the fair value, especially for intangible assets, involves significant judgment, including the use of third-party valuation specialists. Real property and intangible assets, such as trade names, are valued based on historical information, expectations and assumptions about the future from the perspective of marketplace participants. In the case of acquired leases, a right-of-use (ROU) asset and lease obligations are recorded at the present value of remaining lease payments, adjusted for market terms. Despite believing expectations and assumptions about the future are reasonable, inherent uncertainty exists, and unforeseen events may impact the accuracy and validity of estimates.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Text: Purchased property, plant and equipment are recorded at cost and property, plant and equipment acquired as part of a business acquisition are recorded at fair value. Both are presented net of accumulated depreciation and amortization. Buildings include property we have acquired under build-to-suit arrangements and finance lease arrangements. Long-lived assets at the location level are evaluated for recoverability whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that its carrying amount may not be recoverable.. The estimates we use when assessing the recoverability of assets are consistent with those we use in our internal planning. The variability of these factors depends on a number of conditions and, thus, our accounting estimates may change from period to period.  The Company performed an impairment assessment of long-lived assets as of October 1, 2023. As a result of the assessment, long-lived assets were deemed recoverable. The impairment analyses involve estimates due to the inherent judgment in forecasting cash flows and determining the assets’ ultimate useful lives and fair values. Actual results differing from these estimates could significantly impact the impairment assessment. 102 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Text: The preparation of the Company’s financial statements in conformity with GAAP requires management to make estimates, assumptions and judgments influencing reported asset and liability amounts, disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities as of the financial statement date and reported revenue and expenses during the reporting period. Management engages in subjective estimates and assumptions concerning future events, significantly impacting revenues and fair value determinations. The Company adheres to a policy of regular evaluation of its estimates, assumptions and judgments, basing them on historical experience and factors deemed reasonable under the circumstances. The outcomes of these evaluations involve judgments about the carrying values of assets and liabilities not readily apparent from other sources. Any alterations in the Company’s assumptions or conditions may lead to actual results differing significantly from these estimates. 101 ----- While the Company believes the estimates and assumptions underpinning its consolidated financial statements are reasonable and supportable, the uncertainty surrounding current economic conditions, increasing interest rates and the performance of the Company’s business renders these estimates less certain than they would be in the absence of these conditions.
