Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsection Title: BUSINESS THE DIFFERENCE IS TRUST. This sentiment has served as the cornerstone of our DNA since Crash
Subsubsection Text: Champions’ inception as a single Chicago-area repair facility in 1999. We are the largest founder-owned collision repair platform and one of the fastest growing MSOs in the United States, offering accident repair services including dent repair and removal, auto painting, bumper and fender damage repair and ancillary scanning and calibration services for internal combustion engine, hybrid and electric vehicles. Our inherently non-discretionary service offering addresses essential vehicle safety and functionality following a vehicle accident. We maintain longstanding relationships with all major insurance carriers, resulting in approximately 97% of our repair revenue for the quarter ended September 30, 2023 coming from insurance-paid customers, of which approximately 90% is driven through Direct Repair Program relationships, in which partner insurance carriers refer repairs to our shops. Since our founding in 1999, we have strategically expanded across the country through the execution of our national consolidation strategy, scaling to 619 facilities across 37 states as of October 2023. We have built a national presence through highly accretive acquisitions while simultaneously deploying our proven operational playbook to drive consistency of service quality as well as operational performance and efficiencies. We believe that we are uniquely positioned to capitalize on our growing national footprint and drive attractive sales and earnings growth by providing quality service to the growing car parc in a highly resilient and fragmented industry. Our differentiated platform is relentlessly committed to providing a consistent and superior customer experience in every part of the repair process. As a leading collision repair platform, we maintained over 6,700 DRP relationships nationwide and have achieved significant DRP expansion, growing our program count at a 21% CAGR in the year-to-date period ended September 30, 2023. Our DRP relationships prioritize our services due to our (i) expedited turnaround times, (ii) technical expertise and well-invested facilities, which enable us to repair all vehicle types (including those equipped with the latest advanced driver assistance systems and electric vehicle technology), (iii) superior customer satisfaction that helps drive policyholder retention for insurance carriers and (iv) ability to deliver lower overall vehicle repair costs. 104 ----- Collision Repair Cycle Under founder and CEO Matt Ebert’s leadership, our platform has achieved significant growth, expanding into 37 states and increasing our footprint by over 260 shops since 2018 (excluding Service King), representing a CAGR of 116% from 2018 to October 2023. This expansion has been a key contributor to our growth, and on a combined basis we have grown our net sales and Adjusted EBITDA by 32% and 173%, respectively, for the twelve months ended September 30, 2023 compared to the twelve months ended September 30, 2022. In addition to increasing the number of locations that we operate, our net sales and Adjusted EBITDA growth has been driven by same store sales growth of 15% for the twelve months ended September 30, 2023 on a combined basis. The U.S. collision repair industry represents an estimated $44.8 billion non-discretionary and re-occurring revenue opportunity. The market is characterized by several long-term secular tailwinds, including steady car parc growth over the past decade, a consistent upward trend in vehicle miles traveled, and increasing accident severity driven by underlying increases in vehicle complexity. The U.S. collision repair industry is highly fragmented, with approximately 35,000 repair shops across the country, which are predominantly operated by regional, local and independent operators that lack the scale or resources to invest in the latest equipment and training required to repair the modern vehicle. The accelerating adoption of advanced vehicle technology is driving increased insurance carrier preference to refer repairs to national MSO platforms with the ability to invest in the critical resources, including OE certifications and scanning and calibration services, required to repair the modern vehicle. MSO share of DRP appraised volume has increased from 11% in 2008 to 46% in 2022, according to CCC Intelligent Solutions Inc. In this highly fragmented industry, we believe that our combination of strategic organic growth investments and acquisition strategy uniquely positions us to expand our leadership as a national MSO platform.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsection Title: Industry Overview: The Large, Recession-Resistant and Highly Fragmented Automotive Collision Repair Industry
Subsubsection Text: We operate in the large, growing and highly fragmented U.S. collision repair industry, which is part of the broader $477.6 billion U.S. automotive aftermarket industry. Having grown at a 5.1% CAGR from 2017 to 2022, the 105 ----- U.S. collision repair industry has a long track record of consistent growth, according to the Autocare Association Factbook 2024. The non-discretionary nature of collision repairs has insulated the industry from economic cycles and driven long-term, stable growth. In addition, vehicle insurance coverage is mandatory for all drivers in the U.S., further supporting the non-discretionary nature of collision repair demand. The drivers of industry growth are increasing VMT and traffic congestion, growing car parc, collision frequency and collision severity. Source: Romans Report. Despite significant advancements in safety technology, collision levels have increased 3% per year as miles driven have steadily increased, according to data published by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. In addition, accident severity continues to accelerate collision repair service expenditures. Since 2010, the average total cost of repairs has increased at a 5% CAGR to approximately $4,300 per accident, and most recently at a 10% CAGR from 2020 to 2022. Increasing vehicle complexity results in the significantly higher average cost of repairs, with repair costs being driven by an increase in the number of parts replaced per claim, increased labor hours per claim, rising parts costs and increased demand for calibration and scanning services. Specifically, the average number of parts replaced and average labor hours per claim increased at a 4.3% and 1.5% CAGR, respectively, between 2011 and 2022. Source: 2023 CCC Intelligent Solutions Report. 106 ----- The automotive collision repair industry remains highly fragmented with the majority of facilities managed by independent operators, creating a compelling opportunity for consolidation. We are one of only three companyoperated platforms with a national footprint. Currently, these top three players in the industry comprise only 9% of all U.S. collision repair shops. We belong to a limited tier of scaled providers, which is demonstrated by the fact that our platform has approximately 2.5 times the number of shops as the next largest provider. Source: Public filings and 2024 Auto Care Factbook. Our customers view the repair process as an extension of their relationship with their insurance provider. Given the impact a positive experience with a collision repair operator can have on a customer’s likelihood of renewing their automotive insurance policy, insurance carriers have developed DRPs to better manage auto body repair claims by simplifying the process of dispatching estimate requests and implementing quality standards and customer satisfaction measurement for collision repair facility operators. DRPs’ relationships with MSOs have proven to save significant time in the repair process by standardizing the estimation process through a preestablished repair framework, while simultaneously increasing customer satisfaction and reducing repair costs. Over the past 20 years, MSOs have meaningfully increased their market share over independent collision repair facility operators as a result of significant operational and economic advantages. Insurance carriers continue referring more work to their national MSO partners, resulting in an over 1,100 basis point market share gain from 2018 to 2022. 107 ----- Source: 2023 CCC Intelligent Solutions Report based on CCC National Industry Annual Uploaded DRP Appraisal Count.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Title: Market Leader with Scale Advantages Driving Entrenched Relationships with Insurance Carriers in a Highly Fragmented Collision Repair Industry
Subsubsection Text: We are the largest founder-led collision repair platform and one of the largest national players with 619 facilities across 37 states. As a top three national player, our scale benefits yield superior shop-level performance relative to the average independent facility operator, driven by investments in advanced technology and a deep bench of highly qualified technicians, driving attractive cycle times and repair-versus-replace metrics that underpin our value proposition for insurance carriers. We believe our superior performance and relentless commitment to trust and customer satisfaction has led to longstanding, diversified relationships with leading insurance carriers. Our comprehensive high-touch carrier management strategy incorporates central corporate relationships, as well as within each operating region and at the individual shop-level. Our strategy of focusing on insurance carriers at the corporate, regional and shop-level is designed to position us to be a better partner while also empowering our shop managers to have continuous dialogue with local carrier contacts, which supports a more efficient claims and repair process. This approach to carrier relationships creates a virtuous cycle, whereby (i) we receive additional 108 ----- repair referrals due to strong performance, (ii) higher volumes enable improved throughput that yields higher profitability, (iii) higher profitability enables increased platform investment to support additional capacity and (iv) increased capacity facilitates further carrier referrals. As the collision repair sector continues to consolidate, national carriers rely on scaled MSOs that provide better customer satisfaction, help with policyholder retention and deliver lower total repair costs for the insurer. As we have scaled, we have demonstrated the ability to grow with carriers into new markets based on local market capacity needs. As a trusted partner to our insurance carriers, we have developed an attractive carrier mix that is highly diversified and is expected to continue to drive overall volume, sales and earnings growth. Today, we average 11 DRPs per shop, while continuing to pursue channels to expand DRP relationships at new and existing shops, which should drive more predictable and increased revenue.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Title: Best-In-Class Operations Playbook Drives Compelling Unit Economics
Subsubsection Text: Our strong track record stems from our robust operating infrastructure supported by strong process planning and execution focused on standardization, repeatability and scalability. We take a standardized approach that promotes high performance standards across the platform to ensure compliance with carriers’ operating metrics. We have engineered highly repeatable processes that are designed to drive enhanced shop productivity, increase shop capacity to handle volume growth from DRP expansion and expand our service offerings to include our captive scanning and calibration business, ATE, to capture the full repair value. Our data-driven approach to monitor realtime performance metrics allows us to continuously refine our operations. We utilize dashboards to closely track KPIs and any variances in financial and operational performance through metrics such as carrier assignments, capture rate, and work-in-progress, for visibility into the consistency of referrals, and sales-per-day and body technician retention and productivity for insight into current throughput. Our uncompromising focus on real-time data driven analytics is reflected in our leading performance metrics. As a result, our shops delivered an industryleading AUV of $4.3 million on an annualized basis for the quarter ended September 30, 2023, compared to the industry average of approximately $1.3 million for the same period. Our well-established operations playbook and data focused approach have resulted in attractive unit economics. Throughout our platform, we utilize our expertise by leveraging operating, financial, training, leadership and vendor management best practices to achieve efficiency at scale. We have streamlined regional support and overhead costs by instilling best practices and operational consistency across our network while improving overall shop-level execution. As a leading MSO, we benefit from scale procurement benefits, which afford us higher margins relative to independent operators. Specifically, we recognize procurement benefits across non-labor costs including paint and parts which, combined with greater volume, drive attractive unit economics across all our shops. We believe there is significant earnings potential embedded in our platform as we continue to realize scale benefits across our footprint and reinvest future excess cash flow into further platform expansion and efficiencies.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Title: Superior Service Levels Supported by Industry Leading Metrics
Subsubsection Text: Service is at the epicenter of what we do at Crash Champions. Our approach to continued operational improvement has resulted in superior service metrics relative to the industry. Outperformance relative to other operators allows us to further strengthen and expand our relationships with insurance carriers. For the periods noted below, our average length of rental was 16.6 days, compared to the industry average of 18.1, and our average total cost of repair was $4,076, compared to the industry average of $4,232, resulting in a significant cost saving for carriers. Furthermore, compared to industry averages, we consistently repair a higher volume of damaged parts relative to those we replace, and our total cost of repair is lower than the industry averages, underscoring our operational excellence. We expect to continue to be a preferred partner for insurance carriers given our successful execution against our playbook and maintenance of superior operational metrics relative to the broader industry. 109 ----- (1) Crash Champions represents average of four quarters from Q4 2022 to Q3 2023. Industry figures based on Collisionweek data, calculated as an average of four quarters from Q4 2022 to Q3 2023. (2) Average of quarterly data for year ended December 31, 2022 per 2023 CCC Intelligent Solutions report. Labor sales mix is defined as percentage of total cost of repair attributed to body technicians. (3) Average of quarterly data for year ended December 31, 2022 per 2023 CCC Intelligent Solutions report. Industry figures represent average for DRP claims and estimates.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Title: Proven Growth Model Backed by Accretive M&A and Strategic Shop Investments
Subsubsection Text: We have fortified our platform and expanded our footprint through highly accretive M&A. Since 2018, we have completed more than 115 acquisitions, with each consisting of approximately two shops on average (excluding Service King). We are committed to completing acquisitions with disciplined underwriting and realization of operational improvements. We have developed a consistent acquisition and integration process predicated on high performance standards across the platform, repeatable processes designed to handle increases in volume, and scalable operating, financial, training, leadership and vendor management best practices. Our actionable and disciplined underwriting identifies highly synergistic targets by focusing on an array of key market and facility characteristics, including population demographics, proximity to our existing footprint, facility quality and incremental capacity, and quality of existing operational practices. As cohorts are integrated into our platform, we have recognized increases in both net sales and 4-Wall EBITDA margin based on our ability to (i) grow revenue by increasing DRPs and capturing ancillary service revenue from ATE, and (ii) optimize margins through procurement synergies, front of shop labor optimization, and fixed cost operating leverage. As illustrated in the table below, all of our cohorts of shops have significantly improved both revenue and 4-Wall EBITDA compared to the annual shop performance pre-acquisition for the respective periods. 110 ----- Note: “Q3 2023 Annualized” included for comparative purposes and represents results for the quarter ended September 30, 2023 multiplied by four In addition to highly accretive M&A, our growth model is supported by strategic growth investment in existing facilities with attractive ROI. These high ROI projects target increasing throughput, which yields improved fixed cost operating leverage and enhances shop financial performance. Examples of these investments include adding production square footage, increasing paint booth capacity, increasing lift count and adding advanced equipment. In addition, we are committed to continuing to invest in our ATE business, which offers scanning and calibration services. These two services are natural extensions of the repair process that represent incremental revenue we are able to capture, compared to less well-equipped operators who are forced to outsource these services and sacrifice margins, as well as increasing overall cycle times. Currently, we offer ATE’s services in 44% of our shops, with plans to expand to over 80% of our shops by the end of 2024 given our recent capital investments. Through additional investments in our existing footprint, we believe we are well positioned to drive greater volume and 4-wall profitability.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Title: Robust Alignment and Rigorous Focus Through Differentiated Team Structure
Subsubsection Text: At Crash Champions, we have an established management incentive plan that extends all the way to the General Manager of every facility, which helps foster strong organizational alignment. We have a deep bench of talent throughout the organization and believe that our entrepreneurial mindset and deeply instilled commitment to training and employee development leads to greater retention, superior service and the best possible customer experience. Our highly integrated team structure places a strong emphasis on operational improvement and accountability at all levels, extending from Senior Vice Presidents, who manage large geographic footprints, to General Managers, who oversee daily shop operations and interact with customers. Our experienced leadership team is led by founder and Chief Executive Officer, Matt Ebert, who started in the business approximately 25 years ago as a mechanic and single shop operator. Matt and the leadership team are supported by experienced board members who have decades of experience as executives at leading carriers and service providers such as Safelite and Progressive. Our leadership team is highly committed to the business and its long-term growth plans and currently has over $100 million invested in the business. In addition, we conduct regular leadership training and development programming for our General Managers, which promotes best practices across the organization. Historically, we have achieved a very high retention rate for managers who attend these programs. Our emphasis on developing strong customer service is characterized by trust, transparency and communication at every step of the repair process.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Title: Drive Sales and Volume Through Existing Shops
Subsubsection Text: Our approach to quality assurance, efficient turnaround times and innovative service offerings has positioned us as a leader in the collision repair industry. Given our ability to deliver industry leading service metrics, we remain a preferred partner of the leading insurance carriers and see additional opportunities to grow our DRP network with insurance carriers. We have a strong track record of adding DRP relationships to our platform which, as of September 30, 2023, number over 6,700, an average of 11 per shop. Additionally, we continue to pursue high ROI investments in our shops to expand capacity and add body technicians to facilitate increased throughput, resulting in same store sales growth. In the twelve months ended September 30, 2023, we delivered 15% year-overyear same store sales growth combined across Crash Champions and Service King. Additionally, as we expand our ATE business throughout most of our shops, we expect scanning and calibration to be another lever of attractive growth. We see attractive opportunities to continue to drive same store sales growth by investing in our shops to facilitate further DRP growth, add body technicians and increase penetration of our ATE service, all resulting in increased shop throughput. 111 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Title: Continue to Realize Significant Embedded Growth from Service King Integration and Other Recent Acquisitions
Subsubsection Text: In July 2022 and August 2022, respectively, Service King completed the SK Restructuring Transaction and Crash Champions completed the Crash Acquisition Transaction. Following such transactions, while remaining separate legal entities, we integrated Service King’s operations into our Crash Champions platform to form the third largest national collision repair platform. Since the combination with Crash Champions, Service King has undergone a significant operational transformation, underscoring our commitment to enhance efficiency and sustainable growth consistent with Crash Champions’ history. We immediately aligned leadership under Crash Champions’ management team and deployed our proven operational playbook. We executed several operational improvements aimed at streamlining corporate functions, enhancing talent recruitment and retention, and enhancing shop-level performance through increased shop throughput. In addition to bringing talent back to the shops, we spent significant time with our carrier partners on a national, regional and local level to onboard more DRP programs, as well as to realize rate increases more commensurate with rising repair costs. We consolidated our procurement organizations to leverage our combined scale and enhance our gross margins and further augmented our 4-Wall EBITDA margins by right-sizing our frontof-shop labor and in-sourcing high-margin scanning and calibration services through ATE. We streamlined our corporate cost structure with Service King utilizing Crash Champions’ operations, human resources, business development, finance and IT functions to unlock significant annualized cost savings, and we harmonized our critical IT infrastructure by integrating our key systems. Finally, we are nearing completion of rebranding Service King shops as Crash Champions locations. Our successful integration execution has driven significant outperformance over and above the $45 million of underwritten synergies, with additional opportunities to realize meaningful embedded growth based on operational improvements and recruitment of technicians, exercising advantages of being a larger platform and capitalizing on compelling trends for larger, well-integrated MSOs. Since integrating Service King with Crash Champions in 2022, we have achieved 4-Wall EBITDA margin improvement at integrated Service King shops in excess of 350 basis points for the quarter ended September 30, 2023. We continue to take action to advance both top and bottom-line performance through initiatives that we believe will continue to create earnings uplift with a target to improve our overall 4-Wall EBITDA margins from fiscal year 2023 margins by up to an additional 300 basis points over the medium term, the most important of which is increasing technician count to drive greater throughput. We are optimizing staffing levels through our recruitment programs and by developing talent internally through our Skills Training Education Program apprentice program. As we work towards reaching full staffing of technicians across our network where we have ample room for additional technicians, we expect to improve throughput at existing shops and drive additional fixed cost operating leverage to further improve 4-Wall EBITDA margins. Our successful integration of Service King has been a significant driver of earnings growth which we believe still presents a significant opportunity. 112 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Title: Expand Footprint Through Accretive M&A and Greenfield/Brownfield Development
Subsubsection Text: We are committed to pursuing accretive M&A opportunities coupled with targeted greenfield and brownfield development. From the date of the Crash Acquisition Transaction through October 31, 2023, we added 89 shops through acquisitions and new developments. The collision repair industry remains highly fragmented and by focusing on accretive acquisitions with attractive unit economics and synergies, we expect to continue to drive attractive long-term returns. While acquisitions often require larger initial capital outlays than greenfield and brownfield developments, acquired units bring immediate cash flow through an established labor force and customer base that we are able to augment via increased DRP volumes. Through our long history of successful M&A, we have developed a defined Crash Champions playbook that takes new facilities from pre-acquisition announcement through their first 30 days, bringing acquired locations seamlessly into the Crash Champions ecosystem through implementation of best practices and standardization with existing shops with our Quick Response Force. From small-scale, single-facility acquisitions to our transformative merger with Service King, we believe that our ability to successfully acquire and integrate new facilities provides us with a competitive advantage. By leveraging the improvements enabled by our operating playbook as well as the revenue growth through the addition of DRPs, we historically have recognized significant multiple buy-down within 24 months following an acquisition. Our underwriting of the 2020 and 2021 cohorts, inclusive of cost synergies, indicates a 4.8x and 5.5x multiple,[3] respectively, on acquired shops with an opportunity to realize greater upside over a longer period. For the quarter ended September 30, 2023, estimated annualized EBITDA for the same cohorts indicates a 2.7x and 4.3x multiple, respectively. [4] As of September 30, 2023, we have exceeded our underwriting models for both cohorts, demonstrating our ability to execute on realizing cost synergies and to create value through meaningful volume increases at acquired shops within 24 months. Additionally, selective greenfield and brownfield development enables us to infill existing markets and build density. The addition of greenfield and brownfield units allows us to (i) leverage our strong carrier partnerships to drive immediate volume, (ii) capitalize on our scale procurement, and (iii) leverage our existing regional infrastructure. Our ability to pursue greenfield and brownfield development, complemented by our M&A track record, puts us in a leading position to scale our platform in an accretive manner.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Title: Drive Adoption of High Margin ATE Offering in Existing Footprint
Subsubsection Text: The increased prevalence of ADAS in new vehicle models is driving accelerating demand for scanning and calibration services. Between the first quarter of 2017 and the fourth quarter of 2022, as a percentage of repairable appraisals, scanning increased from 3% to 57%, and calibration frequency increased from 1% to 12%, highlighting the expansive growth opportunity that lies in scanning and calibration services. We launched ATE in 2019 and subsequently expanded nationwide, including deploying significant growth capital expenditures in 2023. We currently offer services at 44% of our locations with the ability to expand to over 80% of our shops by the end of 2024 based on our recent growth investment. We continue to invest in scanning and calibration technologies, which are becoming increasingly important and valued when servicing new models with complex electronic system components, including ADAS, which we believe will be a driver of future sales and earnings growth.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Title: Enhance Margins Through Productivity Initiatives and Operating Leverage
Subsubsection Text: As our business grows, we intend to continue utilizing our scale to drive operating leverage. Collision repair shops have certain fixed and semi-fixed costs, resulting in enhanced operating leverage for larger, more productive shops. Our ongoing implementation of the Crash Champions playbook in acquired shops enables these shops to efficiently process greater volumes. We plan to drive incremental throughput by investing in shop 3 Represents acquisition cohort median of enterprise value divided by Underwriting Model EBITDA (modeled annual EBITDA including cost synergies). 4 Represents acquisition cohort median of enterprise value divided by annualized Q3 2023 EBITDA (including synergies). Annualized figures are calculated by multiplying the corresponding results for the three-month period ending September 30, 2023, by four. For additional information, see “Risk Factors – Risks Related to the Transactions.” 113 ----- optimization and renovations to take advantage of our carrier relationships and continue to drive higher assignment volume relative to independents. Throughout our facilities, we are also expanding ATE to capture greater volume of scanning and calibration revenue. We consistently utilize our internally developed training and leadership development programs to instill best-practices across our network and align our employees with the Crash Champions operating playbook. Through our consistent operational excellence, we are able to drive greater sales volume and operating leverage to generate improving margins and significant free cash flow.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Text: The majority of our customers are individual vehicle owners who are referred to us by insurance carriers operating under DRPs, which grant “preferred vendor” status to collision repair facilities in exchange for preferred pricing arrangements and established service levels. We believe that our strategic focus on establishing robust partnerships with insurance carriers has positioned us as a trusted and preferred service provider within the industry. Insurance carriers are able to evaluate the quality of the service provided by the collision repair facility through proprietary and third-party software integrations, which monitor key performance indicators that quantify factors such as the cost of total repair, alternative part mix, repair percentage of body labor, customer satisfaction and delivery time. Insurance carriers value DRP relationships as collision repair facilities are a valuable point of contact between the customer and the insurance carrier that can simultaneously reduce costs while increasing customer satisfaction to drive improved policyholder retention. Our commitment to delivering high-quality collision repair services, coupled with a thorough understanding of the insurance landscape, underscores our dedication to meeting the industry’s rigorous standards and providing the best customer service to both our carriers and their policy holders.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Text: The collision repair business is highly fragmented and competitive. We compete against a number of competitors in each market, and while the size and strength of competitors varies widely from region to region, most of the competition are “mom and pop” operators. The main competitive differentiators are scale and density within a given market, shop location, service quality, customer satisfaction, insurance carrier relationships and adherence to various insurance key performance indicators. Although competition exists mainly on a local basis, we also compete with a small number of other large MSOs in the markets in which we operate.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Text: We use a wide variety of materials in our business, including paint, new and aftermarket replacement parts, and other repair materials, resulting in a highly diversified mix of vendors. After our combination with Service King, we have entered into new strategic agreements with parts and paint suppliers to optimize procurement. Our national, platform-level deal with LKQ for aftermarket parts as well as ‘best-of-both’ pricing from OEM parts providers has driven improved parts margin, with additional upside as our purchasing increases. Additionally, we entered into a new national paint contract with BASF in June 2023, which is expected to deliver meaningful cost savings upon full implementation. As a large MSO, we enjoy scale procurement benefits, driving favorable paints and parts margins relative to independents.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Text: As of September 30, 2023, we employed approximately 9,900 full-time employees on a combined basis. None of these employees are covered by a collective bargaining agreement. We consider our relations with our employees to be good. Our human capital resources objectives include, as applicable, identifying, recruiting, retaining, incentivizing and integrating our existing and prospective employees. The principal purposes of our incentive plans are to attract, retain and motivate selected employees, executive officers and directors through the granting of stock-based compensation awards and cash-based performance bonus awards. We strive for exceptional performance and results and we provide employees the opportunity to grow and to be rewarded based on results. 114 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Text: We own or have the rights to use certain trademarks, service marks and trade names that are registered with the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office or other foreign trademark registration offices or exist under common law in the United States, including “Crash Champions”, “Crash Champions Collision Repair Team” and “Automotive Technology Experts.” We also own domain names, including our primary domain “www.crashchampions.com.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Text: Seasonal changes may moderately impact the demand for our collision repair services. For example, in certain areas, mild and/or dry weather conditions may result in fewer accidents, resulting in the need for fewer collision repairs, whereas periods of inclement or prolonged winter weather may result in more accidents and drive increases in volume and revenue. Historically, seasonality has had a limited impact on our business due to our large geographical footprint across the United States.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Text: As of September 30, 2023, we had 619 company-operated locations on a combined basis. We held leases covering the building and/or land for 617 of our locations, and two offices and training centers in the United States, including our corporate headquarters located in Westmont, Illinois. The leases generally have initial expiration dates ranging from ten to 15 years, with multiple renewal options available. We believe that the properties are suitable and adequate for our business.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Text: Both Crash Champions Holdings and Service King are party to routine legal proceedings that arise in the ordinary course of our business. Except for commercial contract proceedings, many of these proceedings are generally covered under each company’s existing insurance programs to the extent any loss exceeds the deductible or self-insured retention. We are not aware of any existing, pending, or threatened contingent liabilities that are reasonably expected to have a material impact on either Crash Champions Holdings’ or Service King’s ongoing operations, or that have not been reflected, or adequately reserved for, in their respective financial statements. Additionally, neither Crash Champions Holdings nor Service King has a history of material litigation or litigation expenses, and management is not aware of any material current or pending legal issues. We are, from time to time, involved in other unresolved legal actions that arise in the normal course of business. Although it is not possible to predict with certainty the outcome of these unresolved legal actions, we do not believe that these actions will individually or in the aggregate have a material adverse effect on our results of operations, financial position or liquidity.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsection Title: Government Regulations and Other Regulatory Matters
Subsubsection Text: Our operations are subject to numerous federal, state and local laws and regulations in areas such as consumer protection, occupational licensing, environmental protection, data privacy, labor and employment, tax, permitting, and other laws and regulations. In certain jurisdictions, we must obtain licenses or permits in order to comply with standards governing employee selection, training and business conduct. We are not aware of any federal, state, local or other laws or regulations that are likely to materially alter or impact our revenues, cash flow or competitive position, or result in any material capital expenditures. However, we cannot predict the effect on our operations of any pending or future legislation or regulations or the future interpretation of any existing laws, including any newly enacted laws, that may impact us. 115 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Text: Below are the names, positions and a brief account of the business and experience of the individuals who we expect will serve as the executive officers of the Company at the closing of the Transactions. Following the closing of the Transactions, our board of directors will consist of seven directors, including Matthew Ebert, Thomas Feeney, Michael Sieger and other members designated by Clearlake.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Title: Matthew Ebert is the founder and Chief Executive Officer of Crash Champions and has overseen the rapid
Subsubsection Text: expansion of the brand from a single shop in Illinois into the third-largest multi-shop collision repair operator (MSO) in the United States, operating more than 600 high-quality collision repair centers in 37 states and Washington D.C. He was named a winner of the Ernst & Young (EY) Entrepreneur of the Year Midwest Award in 2023 and the MSO Executive of the Year by Bodyshop Business magazine in 2022.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Title: Eric Pitt has served as Chief Financial Officer since August 2023. Prior to joining Crash Champions, Mr.
Subsubsection Text: Pitt served as the Chief Financial Officer at HGreg, a new and used vehicle dealership group with more than 30 locations across the United States and Canada. Prior to his role with HGreg, Mr. Pitt served six years as Vice President of Investor Relations and Treasurer at Lithia Motors, Inc., a Fortune 500 company and the largest automotive retailer by new vehicle sales. He is a licensed CPA and holds a B.S. in Business Administration as well as an MBA from Southern Oregon University.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Title: Alan Saviano has served as Chief Operating Officer since joining Crash Champions in February 2020.
Subsubsection Text: Prior to Crash Champions, Mr. Saviano served 15 years in roles of expanding operations leadership at Service King, including as Senior Vice President of Operations. Before joining the collision repair industry, Mr. Saviano served ten years as a Navy SEAL. Mr. Saviano holds an MBA from the Marshall School of Business at the University of Southern California, as well as a bachelor’s degree in finance from Old Dominion University.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Title: Rachel Huftless has served as Chief Client Officer since 2020. In her role, Ms. Huftless secures and fosters
Subsubsection Text: strategic business partnerships, while also overseeing call center operations and central review. Ms. Huftless has 15 years of experience in the collision repair industry, primarily in business development, marketing, and account management with several of the nation’s leading automotive insurance carriers. Ms. Huftless holds a Master of Science in Industrial and Organizational Psychology from Grand Canyon University, and a Bachelor of Science in Psychology from Arizona State University.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Title: Bill Davidson has served as Chief Human Resources Officer since 2023. In his role, Mr. Davidson oversees
Subsubsection Text: our human resources department and the implementation of our ‘people’ strategy. Mr. Davidson has more than 20 years of experience in human resources across multiple industries, including as Senior Vice President and Chief People Officer at Insurance Auto Auctions (IAA). Mr. Davidson holds an MBA from the Krannert School of Management at Purdue University, a Master’s Certificate in Human Resources Management from Villanova University and a BBA from Strayer University. He is also a 21-year veteran of the U.S. Marine Corps. 116 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Title: Thomas Feeney has served as a member of the Board of Directors since 2023. Mr. Feeney has more than
Subsubsection Text: 45 years of leadership experience, primarily in the automotive services industry, including 14 years as President and Chief Executive Officer of Safelite Group. Prior to serving as President and Chief Executive Officer, Mr. Feeney served as Vice President and Chief Client Officer of Safelite. Mr. Feeney holds a B.S. in Accounting and Finance from La Salle University.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Title: Michael Sieger has served as a member of the Board of Directors since 2022. Mr. Sieger has over 30 years
Subsubsection Text: of experience in the automotive industry, primarily in claims and growth strategy, most recently serving as Claims President of Progressive Corporation. Mr. Sieger holds a B.S. in Electrical Engineering from Case Western Reserve University and an MBA from the University of Chicago. 117 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsection Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS The Reorganization
Subsubsection Text: On or about the issue date of the notes, the Issuer will enter into the Contribution Agreements with Carnelian and certain wholly owned subsidiaries of Carnelian. The Contribution Agreements will provide that, among other things, and on the terms and subject to the conditions of the Contribution Agreements, (i) Carnelian will contribute all of its equity interests in Service King, which constitutes all of the issued and outstanding equity interests of Service King, to Parent, (ii) Parent will contribute all of its equity interests in Service King to Champions Holdco, (iii) Champions Holdco will contribute all of its equity interests in Service King to the Issuer, (iv) the Issuer will contribute all of its equity interests in Service King to Champions Purchaser, (v) Parent will contribute all of its equity interests in Champions Blocker to Champions Holdco, (vi) Champions Holdco will contribute all of its equity interests in Champions Blocker to the Issuer, and (vii) the Issuer will contribute all of its equity interests in Champions Blocker to Champions Purchaser. Upon consummation of the Reorganization, the Issuer will indirectly hold all of the equity interests of Service King and Crash Champions Holdings.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Text: We have entered into Management and Monitoring Services Agreements (the “Management Services Agreements”), effective as of August 1, 2022, with affiliates of Clearlake and certain other equity investors (including members of management), pursuant to which we are obligated to pay such parties, on a pro rata basis based on their equity interest in Carnelian, an aggregate annual management fee equal to the greater of (i) 5% of Four Quarter Consolidated EBITDA (as defined in Crash Champions Intermediate’s senior secured credit agreement) and (ii) $3,400,000. In addition, the Management Services Agreements include certain expense reimbursement and customary indemnification provisions.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS OF SERVICE KING
Subsubsection Text: We have entered into agreements with affiliates and employees to provide certain corporate services and to provide certain services to our customers, including calibration and towing services. All such agreements were entered into at prevailing market rates. For additional information, refer to the Related Party notes to the historical financial statements of Crash Champions Holdings and New SK HoldCo Sub included elsewhere in this offering memorandum.

All such leases were entered into at prevailing market rates.
