Subsubsection Text: We are currently not subject to the periodic reporting and other informational requirements of the Exchange Act. Under the terms of the indenture relating to the notes, we will agree that for so long as any of the notes remain outstanding, we will furnish to the trustee and holders of the notes the information specified therein. In addition, for so long as any of the notes remain outstanding, we have agreed to make available to holders and prospective purchasers of notes who certify that they are qualified institutional buyers, upon request, the information required to be delivered by Rule 144A(d)(4) under the Securities Act. This offering memorandum contains summaries of certain of our agreements. The descriptions contained in this offering memorandum of these agreements do not purport to be complete and are subject to, or qualified in their entirety by reference to, the definitive agreements. You may obtain a copy of any of these documents at no cost, by writing or telephoning us at the following address: 601 Oakmont Lane, Suite 400, Westmont, IL 60559 or (877) 846-9500. We maintain an Internet site at www.crashchampions.com. Our website and the information contained on that site, or connected to that site, are not incorporated into and are not a part of this offering memorandum. -----

Subsection Title: Crash Champions Holdings, LLC and Subsidiaries Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (In thousands of U.S. dollars, unless otherwise specified) Note 1. Organization and Summary of Significant Accounting Policies a. Organization
Subsubsection Text: Crash Champions Holdings, LLC and its Subsidiaries (the �Company� or �HoldCo�) provide collision repair services primarily to auto insurers including GEICO, State Farm, Progressive and Allstate. Crash Champions Holdings LLC was formed on July 19, 2019, as a Delaware limited liability company, and owns one hundred percent of the membership interest in Crash Champions Intermediate, LLC (�Intermediate�). The Company is headquartered in Westmont, Illinois, and operates 174 vehicle collision repair facilities throughout the United States. The following table reflects the number of vehicle collision repair facilities by state and the District of Columbia, refer to Note 2 for additional information. California 32 Colorado 8 District of Columbia 1 Florida 27 Iowa 1 Idaho 5 Illinois 17 Kansas 7 Maryland 9 Missouri 13 Montana 5 North Carolina 2 Nebraska 6 New Jersey 1 New Mexico 4 Ohio 16 Pennsylvania 10 Washington 1 Wisconsin 9 Total 174

Subsection Title: b. Summary of Significant Accounting Policies
Subsubsection Text: The Company operates on a fiscal year ending December 31. The accompanying Consolidated Financial Statements and notes have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America (�U.S. GAAP�). The Consolidated Financial Statements include the assets, liabilities and results of operations of the Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries, including Crash Champions, Intermediate, LLC, Prestige Too Holdings, Inc, their commonly wholly-owned subsidiary Crash Champions Midco, LLC and its wholly-owned subsidiaries, Crash Champions, LLC and its subsidiary Fountain Valley Bodyworks, Inc., 7900 Firestone Auto Body, LLC, Automotive Technology Experts, LLC, Elite Group Collision Center, LLC, Mullahey Chevrolet, LLC, MT Collision Centers, LLC, Pacific Elite, LLC, Prestige Too Auto Body, LLC and TM Collision Centers, LLC. All material intercompany transactions and balances have been eliminated in consolidation.

Subsection Title: b. Summary of Significant Accounting Policies
Subsubsection Text: Certain reclassifications have been made to prior year financial statements to conform to classifications used in the current year. These reclassifications had no impact on net income (loss), members� equity or cash flows as previously reported. F-36 -----

Subsection Title: b. Summary of Significant Accounting Policies
Subsubsection Text: The preparation of financial statements in conformity with U.S. GAAP requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period. Management�s estimates and assumptions are evaluated on an ongoing basis and are based on historical experience, current conditions, and available information. Actual results may differ from estimated amounts. Estimates are revised as additional information becomes available.

Subsection Title: b. Summary of Significant Accounting Policies
Subsubsection Text: The Company derives its revenue primarily from automotive collision repair services and uses the five-step model for contracts with customers as follows: �Identify the contract with a customer �Identify the performance obligations in the contract �Determine the transaction price, which is the total consideration provided by the customer �Allocate the transaction price among the separate performance obligations within the contract �Recognize revenue when the performance obligations are satisfied Sales to customers are primarily from Direct Repair Programs with various insurance companies. Revenue from three insurance companies constitutes approximately 51% and 51% of the Company�s revenue during the year ended December 31, 2021 and 2020, respectively. From time to time, the company collects cash from self-pay customers upon completion of services, no payment terms are offered. Sales are recorded net of discounts, sales incentives and rebates, sales taxes, and estimated allowances. The Company estimates the reduction to sales and cost of sales for allowances based on current sales levels and our historical experience. Such amounts are immaterial to the consolidated financial statements. The Company recognizes revenue over time and uses the input method based on the labor hours on the repair orders as a percentage of total labor hours at the time of order completion to estimate the revenue on the in-process vehicles. The Company recognizes revenue ratably because the company�s performance enhances a customer-controlled asset. The Company�s contracts are generally noncancelable. The Company also recognizes contract assets, primarily relating to the ratable consideration for services completed for the in-process vehicles, that are not billed at the reporting date. Contract assets are classified as receivables when the Company has the right to invoice the customer. The Company, from time to time, receives prepayments from insurance companies for repair orders that are open at the end of a financial period where customers have not yet taken possession of their vehicle. The amounts are recorded as customer deposits and are reported in current liabilities in the Consolidated Financial Statements. The Company�s costs incurred in the fulfillment of the repair services included labor, parts, and paint costs, and other expenses such as waste disposals, shop supplies and towing costs. The Company capitalizes costs incurred to fulfill the repair services since they are directly related to the contracts that can be specifically identified, incurred to generate, or enhance the resources that will be used in satisfying performance obligations in the future, and expected to be recovered. The Company accounts for vendor rebates as a reduction of the cost of products purchased. The Company provides warranty for labor for all the vehicles the Company services, as parts warranty is generally provided by manufacturers. Warranty claims are minimal based on historical data, and therefore the Company has not recognized a liability as of December 31, 2021 and 2020.

Subsection Title: b. Summary of Significant Accounting Policies
Subsubsection Text: The Company considers cash and highly liquid investments with an original maturity of three months or less to be cash and cash equivalents. Cash and cash equivalents are stated at cost, which approximates or equals fair value due to their short-term nature.

Subsection Title: b. Summary of Significant Accounting Policies
Subsubsection Text: The Company routinely assesses the financial strength of its customers and believes that its trade receivables credit risk exposure is limited. An allowance for doubtful accounts is provided for known and anticipated credit losses and disputed amounts, as determined F-37 ----- customer�s financial condition and credit history, as well as current economic conditions. Amounts are written-off if and when they are determined to be uncollectible.

Subsection Title: b. Summary of Significant Accounting Policies
Subsubsection Title: Financial instruments and concentrations of credit risk
Subsubsection Text: The carrying amounts of financial instruments, including cash, trade receivables, line-of-credit, and accounts payable and accrued expenses approximate fair value due to the relatively short duration of these instruments. The estimated fair value of the term loan is based primarily on borrowing rates currently available to the Company for similar debt issues and as such approximates the carrying value of long-term debt. The Company�s assets that are exposed to credit risk consist primarily of cash and cash equivalents and trade receivables. Cash and cash equivalents are deposited with high-credit, quality financial institutions and at times, balances may exceed federally insured limits. The Company has not experienced any losses.

Subsection Title: b. Summary of Significant Accounting Policies
Subsubsection Text: Inventories primarily consist of paint and parts. Inventories are valued at the lower of cost and net realizable value using the first-in, first-out (�FIFO�) method. Parts are order-to-match; parts inventories are from open repair orders with minimum balances.

Subsection Title: b. Summary of Significant Accounting Policies
Subsubsection Text: Property, plant, and equipment acquired as part of business combinations are recorded at fair value and stated net of accumulated depreciation. The fair value of property and equipment, at acquisition, is estimated using a hybrid of cost and market valuation methodologies. All other purchases are stated at cost, net of accumulated depreciation. Construction in progress is also recorded at cost. Depreciation is computed using the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the assets. Leasehold improvements are recorded at cost and depreciated over the standard life of the type of asset or the remaining life of the lease, whichever is shorter. Equipment held under capital leases is stated at the lower of the fair value of the asset or the net present value of the future minimum lease payments at the inception of the lease. For equipment held under capital leases, depreciation is computed using the straight-line method over the shorter of the estimated useful lives of the leased assets or the related lease term and is included within depreciation expense. The following represents the estimated lives of property, plant, and equipment: Land Indefinite Building 30 years Leasehold improvement Lesser of lease or useful life of the asset Machinery and equipment 3 � 15 years Computers and office equipment 3 � 5 years Vehicles 3 � 5 years Maintenance and repairs are charged to expense as incurred. Property, plant, and equipment is evaluated for impairment at the asset group level. If a triggering event suggests that a potential impairment has occurred, recoverability of these assets is assessed by evaluating whether or not future estimated undiscounted net cash flows are less than the carrying amount of the assets. If the estimated cash flows are less than the carrying amount, the assets are written down to their fair value through an impairment loss recognized as a non-cash component of �Operating income (loss)� within the Consolidated Statements of Operations. The Company did not record an impairment charge for the years ended December 31, 2021, or 2020.

Subsection Title: b. Summary of Significant Accounting Policies
Subsubsection Text: The Company�s policy of intangible assets alternative includes not recognizing and measuring customer related intangible assets (unless capable of being sold or licensed independent from the other assets of the acquired business) and non-compete agreements. Amortizable intangible assets consists of Trade Names. The Company does not have any indefinite lived intangible assets other than goodwill. The intangible assets are being amortized on straight-line basis over the estimated useful life of twenty years, reflecting the pattern in which the economic benefits are consumed. The Company evaluates whether events or circumstances have occurred that warrant a revision to F-38 ----- intangible assets are amortized over the revised remaining useful lives. The Company evaluates amortizable intangible assets for potential impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amounts of the assets may not be fully recoverable. If a triggering event suggests that a potential impairment has occurred, recoverability of these assets is assessed by evaluating the probability that future estimated undiscounted net cash flows will be less than the carrying amount of the long-lived assets. If the estimated cash flows are less than the carrying amount of the long-lived assets, the assets are written down to their fair value through an impairment loss recognized as a non-cash component of �Operating income (loss)� within the Consolidated Statements of Operations. The Company did not record an impairment charge for the years ended December 31, 2021, or 2020. Refer to Note 5 for additional information.

Subsection Title: b. Summary of Significant Accounting Policies
Subsubsection Text: The Company accounts for goodwill as the excess of the purchase price over the net amount of identifiable assets acquired and liabilities assumed in a business combination measured at fair value. In addition, as the result of the Company�s intangible assets alternative accounting policy, intangible assets such as customer relationships and non-compete arrangements are subsumed into goodwill. As a requirement of this accounting policy, the Company amortizes goodwill on a straight-line basis over a ten-year period, and tests for impairment at the entity level instead of the reporting unit level. The carrying amount of goodwill is reviewed for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount may not be recoverable. If the carrying amount is determined as not recoverable, the Company conducts impairment testing at the entity level. If the estimated fair value of the entity exceeds the carrying value, the Company considers that goodwill is not impaired. If the carrying value exceeds estimated fair value, there is an impairment of goodwill and an impairment loss is recognized. The Company calculates the impairment loss by comparing the fair value of the entity less the carrying amount, including goodwill. Goodwill impairment would be limited to the carrying value of the goodwill. There were no impairment charges for the years ended December 31, 2021 or 2020. Refer to Note 5 for additional information.

Subsection Title: b. Summary of Significant Accounting Policies
Subsubsection Text: During the year ended December 31, 2020, the Company entered into a sale-leaseback lease transaction. Total gain on the sale-leaseback transaction of $1,084 was deferred and is being amortized over the life of the lease. The future minimum commitments under the saleleaseback operating lease is included in Note 11.

Subsection Title: b. Summary of Significant Accounting Policies
Subsubsection Text: During the year ended December 31, 2020, the Company entered into a build-to-suit transaction, due to the involvement of improvements and assumed construction risk, which involved transferring a Company owned piece of land to the lessor. The transaction does not meet the conditions of a sale under U.S. GAAP due to provisions included in the agreement under which the Company may be obligated to repurchase the land if certain conditions are not met and has committed to fund overrun costs of construction. The transaction is accounted for under the financing method in which the land is not derecognized from the Company�s balance sheet and proceeds received from the lessor are included as a financing obligation.

Subsection Title: b. Summary of Significant Accounting Policies
Subsubsection Text: The Company has recorded deferred financing costs incurred in conjunction with its debt obligations. The Company amortizes debt issuance costs over the remaining life of the related debt using the effective interest method. Deferred financing costs are recorded as a reduction of �Long-term debt � less current portion� in the Consolidated Balance Sheets. Refer to Note 6 for additional information.

Subsection Title: b. Summary of Significant Accounting Policies
Subsubsection Text: New store opening costs are charged to expense in the fiscal year when incurred. During the year ended December 31, 2021, there was one store closing with associated closing expenses of $0.2 million. During the year ended December 31, 2020, no store locations closed

Subsection Title: b. Summary of Significant Accounting Policies
Subsubsection Text: The cost of advertising is charged to expense when incurred and are included in �Operating Expenses� within the Consolidated Statements of Operations. Total advertising expenses were approximately $1.8 million and $0.5 million for the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2020, respectively. F-39 -----

Subsection Title: b. Summary of Significant Accounting Policies
Subsubsection Text: Income taxes are provided on income reported for financial statement purposes, adjusted for permanent differences between financial statement reporting and income tax regulations. A valuation allowance is established whenever management believes that it is more likely than not that deferred tax assets may not be realizable. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured using enacted tax rates expected to apply to taxable income in the year in which the deferred tax assets or liabilities are expected to be realized or settled. The realization of the net deferred tax assets is primarily dependent on estimated future taxable income. A change in the Company�s estimate of future taxable income may require an increase or decrease in the valuation allowance. A liability for uncertain tax positions is recorded whenever management believes it is not more-likely than-not the position will be sustained on examination based solely on its technical merits. Interest and penalties related to underpayment of income taxes are classified as income tax expense. It is inherently difficult and subjective to estimate such amounts, as the Company has to determine the probability of various possible outcomes. The Company reevaluates these uncertain tax positions on a quarterly basis. This evaluation is based on factors including, but not limited to, changes in facts or circumstances, changes in tax law, effectively settled issues under audit, voluntary settlements, and new audit activity. Such a change in recognition or measurement would result in the recognition of a tax benefit or an additional charge to the tax provision. Crash Champions Intermediate, LLC is a single-member disregarded entity. HoldCo has elected to be treated as a Limited Liability Corporation under the Internal Revenue Code, which provides that, in lieu of corporate income taxes, the members separately account for their pro rata share of the Company's items of income, deductions, losses, and credits. As of December 31, 2021, for federal income tax purposes the Company was comprised of the following regarded entities: Crash Champions Midco, LLC (�MidCo LLC�), Prestige Too Holdings, Inc. (�Prestige Inc.�), and Fountain Valley Bodyworks, Inc. (�Fountain Valley Inc.�). MidCo LLC is a multimember LLC taxed as a partnership for federal tax purposes and files a federal Form 1065 and state and local LLC income tax returns in jurisdictions where Midco LLC has income tax nexus. Prestige Inc. and Fountain Valley Inc. are C corporations that file federal Form 1120s and California C corporation income tax returns. During 2021, the Company completed asset acquisitions. The acquired assets are wholly-owned by MidCo LLC and are subject to various pass through entity taxes, however, the income and losses of these entities are flowed through to the members of Midco. The Company recognizes the tax benefit associated with the tax positions taken for tax return purposes when it is more-likely-than-not that the position will be sustained. The Company does not believe there are any material uncertain tax positions and accordingly it has not recognized any liability for unrecognized tax benefits and as such has not recorded any interest and penalties for the year ended December 31, 2021 and period ended December 31, 2020.

Subsection Title: b. Summary of Significant Accounting Policies
Subsubsection Text: In August 2021, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (�FASB�) issued Accounting Standard Update (�ASU�) No. 2021-08, _Accounting for Contract Assets and Contract Liabilities from Contracts with Customers. The amendments in this Update require that_ an entity (acquirer) recognize and measure contract assets and contract liabilities acquired in a business combination in accordance with Topic 606. At the acquisition date, an acquirer should account for the related revenue contracts in accordance with Topic 606 as if it had originated the contracts. To achieve this, an acquirer may assess how the acquiree applied Topic 606 to determine what to record for the acquired revenue contracts. Generally, this should result in an acquirer recognizing and measuring the acquired contract assets and contract liabilities consistent with how they were recognized and measured in the acquiree�s financial statements (if the acquiree prepared financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles [GAAP]). However, there may be circumstances in which the acquirer is unable to assess or rely on how the acquiree applied Topic 606, such as if the acquiree does not follow GAAP, if there were errors identified in the acquiree�s accounting, or if there were changes identified to conform with the acquirer�s accounting policies. In those circumstances, the acquirer should consider the terms of the acquired contracts, such as timing of payment, identify each performance obligation in the contracts, and allocate the total transaction price to each identified performance obligation on a relative standalone selling price basis as of contract inception (that is, the date the acquiree entered into the contracts) or contract modification to determine what should be recorded at the acquisition date. The amendments in this Update also provide certain practical expedients for acquirers when recognizing and measuring acquired contract assets and contract liabilities from revenue contracts in a business combination. For public business entities, the amendments in this Update are effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2022, including interim periods within those fiscal years. For all other entities, the amendments are effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2023, including interim periods within those fiscal years. The amendments in this Update should be applied prospectively to business combinations occurring on or after the effective date of the amendments. Early adoption of F-40 ----- amendments (1) retrospectively to all business combinations for which the acquisition date occurs on or after the beginning of the fiscal year that includes the interim period of early application and (2) prospectively to all business combinations that occur on or after the date of initial application. The Company early adopted this ASU on January 1, 2021, and it did not have a material impact on its Consolidated Financial Statements. In March 2021, the FASB issued ASU No. 2021-03, Accounting Alternative for Evaluating Triggering Events. The amendments in this Update provide private companies and not-for-profit entities with an accounting alternative to perform the goodwill impairment triggering event evaluation as required in Subtopic 350-20 as of the end of the reporting period, whether the reporting period is an interim or annual period. An entity that elects this alternative is not required to monitor for goodwill impairment triggering events during the reporting period but, instead, should evaluate the facts and circumstances as of the end of each reporting period to determine whether a triggering event exists and, if so, whether it is more likely than not that goodwill is impaired. An entity that does not elect the accounting alternative for amortizing goodwill and that performs its annual impairment test as of a date other than the annual reporting date should perform a triggering event evaluation only as of the end of the reporting period. The amendments in this Update are effective on a prospective basis for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2019. Early adoption is permitted for both interim and annual financial statements that have not yet been issued or made available for issuance as of March 30, 2021. An entity should not retroactively adopt the amendments in this Update for interim financial statements already issued in the year of adoption. The adoption of the standard did not have a material impact on the Company�s Consolidated Financial Statements.

Subsection Title: b. Summary of Significant Accounting Policies
Subsubsection Text: In December 2019, the FASB issued ASU No. 2019-12, Income Taxes (Topic 740)�Simplifying the Accounting for Income Taxes. This standard simplifies the accounting for income taxes by removing certain exceptions to general principles in Topic 740 and clarifying and amending existing guidance. For public entities, the amendments in this ASU are effective for fiscal years, and interim periods within those fiscal years, beginning after December 15, 2020. For all other entities, the amendments are effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2021, and interim periods within fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2022. Early adoption of the amendments is permitted, including adoption in any interim period for (1) public business entities for periods for which financial statements have not yet been issued and (2) all other entities for periods for which financial statements have not yet been made available for issuance. An entity that elects to early adopt the amendments in an interim period should reflect any adjustments as of the beginning of the annual period that includes that interim period. Additionally, an entity that elects early adoption must adopt all the amendments in the same period. The amendments are applied on a prospective or retrospective basis, depending upon the amendment adopted within this ASU. The Company is currently evaluating the impact this adoption will have on its Consolidated Financial Statements. In June 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-13, _Financial Instruments�Credit Losses (Topic 326), and issued subsequent amendments to the initial guidance in May 2019 within ASU No. 2019-05 and in November 2019 within ASU Nos. 2019-10 and 201911. This standard sets forth an expected credit loss model which requires the measurement of expected credit losses for financial instruments based on historical experience, current conditions, and reasonable and supportable forecasts. This replaces the existing incurred loss model and is applicable to the measurement of credit losses on financial assets measured at amortized cost, and certain offbalance sheet credit exposures. For public entities, the updated standard is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2019, including interim periods within those fiscal years. All other entities (private companies, not-for-profit organizations, and employee benefit plans) for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2021, including interim periods within those fiscal years. Early adoption is permitted, and the standard is adopted using a modified retrospective transition method through a cumulative-effect adjustment to retained earnings as of the beginning of the first reporting period in which the guidance is effective. The Company is currently evaluating the impact the adoption of this standard will have on its Consolidated Financial Statements. In February 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-02, Leases (Topic 842), and issued subsequent amendments to the initial guidance in September 2017 within ASU No. 2017-13, in January 2018 within ASU No. 2018-01, in July 2018 within ASU Nos. 2018-10 and 2018-11, in December 2018 within ASU No. 2018-20, in March 2019 within ASU No. 2019-01, in November 2019 within ASU No. 2019-10, in June 2020 within ASU No. 2020-05, and in September 2021 in ASU No. 2021-09. This standard requires lessees to present right-of-use assets and lease liabilities on the balance sheet. For public entities, the updated standard is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2018. This standard is effective for the Company for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2021 and interim periods within fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2022, with early adoption permitted. This standard provides the option to adopt through a cumulative-effect adjustment to the opening balance of retained earnings in the period of adoption, instead of applying the new guidance retrospectively for each prior reporting period presented. The Company is currently evaluating the adoption impact of all ASUs on its Consolidated Financial Statements. F-41 -----

The Company acquired 120 vehicle collision repair facilities on various dates through the year ending December 31, 2021, including certain acquired assets, and assumed liabilities for an aggregate purchase price of approximately $333.3 million, subject to customary post-closing working capital adjustments. The vehicle collision repair facilities are located throughout the United States and provide vehicle collision repair services. The Company acquired 100% interests in all acquisitions. The results of operations have been included in the Consolidated Financial Statements since the respective acquisition dates. The Company financed the acquisitions with cash funded by debt financing under the Credit Agreement and Senior Notes. Certain acquisitions were financed by HoldCo issuance of Class A units measured at fair value estimated using a hybrid of income and market approach methodologies and cash funded by debt financing under the Credit Agreement. Total Class A units issued to the sellers were 4,977. In addition, certain acquisitions as part of consideration included contingent consideration in the aggregate of $7.5 million, measured at fair value using the income approach. The future earnouts are estimated as meeting or exceeding a forecasted gross sales target threshold over a certain post acquisition period, and expected to be earned and paid within a twenty-four- or thirty-six-month period post acquisition date. At each respective acquisition date, the Company evaluated the probability of future payments by comparing the forecasted gross sales to the contractual earnout requirements, and determined the amount and likelihood of payment based on information available at this point in time. The one-time payments are fixed and not linear, and range from $0.5 million to $5.0 million. At each subsequent reporting period end until either payment occurs or the future earnout period expires, the Company will reassess the probability of future payments and measure at fair value accordingly. The acquisitions were accounted for as a business combination under Accounting Standards Codification (�ASC�) ASC 805 Business _Combinations. Tangible and identifiable intangible assets acquired and liabilities assumed were recorded at their respective fair values._ Goodwill represents the excess of consideration transferred resulting from the acquisition less the fair value of all acquired identified assets and liabilities assumed. In addition, due to the Company�s intangible assets alternative accounting policy, intangible assets such as customer relationships and non-compete arrangements were subsumed into goodwill. Goodwill is expected to be partially deducted for U.S. tax purposes. F-43 ----- The Company acquired 54 collision repair shops on various dates through the year ending December 31, 2020, including certain assets, and assumed liabilities for a total purchase price of approximately $135.9 million, subject to customary post-closing working capital adjustments. The collision repair shops are located throughout the United States and provide vehicle collision repair services. The Company acquired 100% interests in all acquisitions. The results of operations have been included in the Consolidated Financial Statements since the respective acquisition dates. The Company primarily financed the acquisitions with cash funded by debt financing under the Credit Agreement. Certain acquisitions were financed by HoldCo issuance of Class A units measured at fair value estimated using a hybrid of income and market approach methodologies and cash funded by debt financing under the Credit Agreement. Total Class A units issued to the sellers were 4,271. The acquisitions were accounted for as a business combination under ASC 805 _Business Combinations. Tangible and identifiable intangible assets acquired and liabilities assumed were recorded at their respective fair values. Goodwill represents the excess of consideration transferred resulting from the acquisition less the fair value of all acquired identified assets and assumed liabilities. In addition, due to the Company�s intangible assets alternative accounting policy, intangible assets such as customer relationships and noncompete arrangements were subsumed into goodwill. Goodwill is expected to be partially deducted for U.S. tax purposes. The Company has a Credit Agreement with various financial institutions maturing on August 5, 2025, consisting of Term Loans, Delayed Draw Term Loans (�DDTL�) and a Revolving Credit Facility, bearing interest at Base Rate plus a spread between 3.50% to 4.25%, or LIBOR Rate plus a spread between 4.50% to 5.25%, corresponding to the applicable Total Net Debt to EBITDA Ratio. The Revolving Credit Facility provides for maximum aggregate borrowings of up to $10.0 million. As of December 31, 2020, the effective interest rates for the Term Loans, the DDTLs and the Revolving Credit Facility was 6.00%. The Term Loan and the DDTL require quarterly principal payments totaling 0.25% of the outstanding principal balances. Interest is payable quarterly. The Credit Agreement is secured by substantially all of the assets of the Company. The Credit Agreement requires that the Company meet certain financial covenants including total net debt to EBITDA covenant. Two of the lenders who are parties to the Revolving Credit Facility each have approximately less than 1% ownership in HoldCo as of December 31, 2020. On May 13, 2021, July 30, 2021, and December 3, 2021, the Company modified its Credit Agreement (�Amended Agreements�) with various financial institutions maturing on August 5, 2025, consisting of an additional Term Loan of $50.0 million and DDTLs in the aggregate of $242.5 million. Interest is calculated at Base Rate plus a spread between 3.75% to 4.25%, or LIBOR Rate plus a spread between 4.75% to 5.25%, corresponding to the applicable Total Net Debt to EBITDA Ratio under the Amended Agreements.  As of December 31, 2021, the effective interest rates for the Term Loans and DDTLs was between 5.0% - 7.25%. The additional Term Loan and DDTLs require quarterly principal payments totaling 0.25% of the outstanding principal balances. Interest is payable quarterly. The proceeds from borrowings under the Amended Agreements were used to fund (i) acquisitions and (ii) capital improvements. Total interest expense recognized was $13.2 million and $6.0 million for the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2020, respectively.

The Company entered into a term loan credit agreement (�Initial Term Loan� or �Loan�) with various financial institutions on March 29, 2021, maturing on March 29, 2026, and amended the Loan with an Incremental Term Loan, (together, �Amended Loans�) on July 29, 2021 with various financial institutions maturing on March 29, 2026. The Company pays interest on the unpaid principal amount of each Amended Loans for the period commencing on the date of such Amended Loans until such Amended Loans is paid in full at a rate per annum equal to ten and one-half percent (10.5%) in payment in kind interest (�PIK Interest�), payable each fiscal quarter and at maturity. Any unpaid interest is added to the principal balance. The Amended Loans can be prepaid in whole or in part without premium or penalty and in an amount equal to $250,000 or a higher integral multiple of $100,000. The proceeds from borrowings under the Amended Loans were used to fund (i) acquisitions and (ii) capital improvements. Total interest expense recognized was $4.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2021.

The Company is governed by the Second Amended and Restated Limited Liability Company Agreement, effective February 28, 2020. The certificate of formation permits two classes of membership units: Class A and Class B, and the Company has the authority to issue an unlimited number of Class A units and Class B units. No member is required to make additional capital contributions except as required by any subscription agreement, and no interest is paid to any member on any capital contributions. Distribution and liquidation rights for Class A units rank senior to all other units issued and outstanding by their terms which expressly provide that they are junior to Class A units or which do not specify their rank. In addition, Class A units accrue dividends at a rate of 8% per annum, accrue day to day, compound annually, regardless of whether declared are cumulative. Class A unit members have preemptive rights in the event the Company issues new securities. As of December 31, 2021 and 2020, the cumulative dividends were $20.3 million and $10.1 million, respectively. The dividends were not declared and not recorded by the Company. F-47 ----- Class B units are Incentive Units issued to employees, consultants or service providers of the Company in consideration for services provided under the Company�s equity inceptive plan. Class B units shall not participate in any distributions unless and until the aggregate amount of distributions paid by the Company from and after the issuance of such Class B units is at least equal to the participation threshold. Class B units only participate in distributions in excess of the applicable participation threshold. No distributions shall be made on unvested Class B units. Refer to Note 8 for additional information.

Crash Champions Holdings, LLC adopted the 2019 Equity Incentive Plan (�Plan�) during 2019. The purpose of the Plan is to encourage and enable the officers, employees, directors, managers, consultants and other key persons of the Company and its Subsidiaries, upon whose judgment, initiative, and efforts the Company largely depends for the successful conduct of its business, to acquire a proprietary interest in the Company. The Incentive Units reserved for issuance under the Plan shall be Class B Units of Crash Champions Holdings, LLC. The maximum number of Units reserved and available for issuance under the Plan shall be 3,176 Class B Units. The Units underlying any Awards that are forfeited, canceled, reacquired by prior to vesting, or otherwise terminated shall be added back to the Units available for issuance under the Plan. A �Participation Threshold� is established with respect Incentive Units that are issued. Class B Units are second priority distribution of available cash and in liquidation and receipt of tax distributions. A Class B Unit shall not participate in any distributions unless and until the aggregate amount of distributions paid by HoldCo from and after the issuance of such Class B Unit is at least equal to the Participation Threshold for such Class B Unit and, after such time, such Class B Units shall only participate in distributions in excess of the applicable Participation Threshold. No distributions shall be made on unvested Class B Units. Since the Incentive Units generally vest over five years on various vesting schedules and upon meeting the Performance Threshold as defined in each grant, the Company recognizes compensation expense when the achievement of the performance condition is considered probable of achievement. No compensation cost was recognized during the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2020, since there is no probable achievement of the Performance Threshold. The unrecognized compensation expense as of December 31, 2021 and 2020 was $1.2 million and $0.6 million, respectively. Subsubsection Text: Non-vested units as of December 31, 2020 1,817 $ 317 $ 576 Granted 1,764 333 587 Exercised � � � Cancelled/Forfeited (411) 380 � Expired � � � Outstanding and unvested as of December 31, 2021 3,170 $ 367 $ 1,163 F-48 ----- follows (in thousands except unit amounts): Non-vested units as of December 31, 2019 719 $ 123 $ 88 Granted 1,215 426 518 Exercised � � � Cancelled/Forfeited (117) 171 � Expired � � � Outstanding and unvested as of December 31, 2020 1,817 $ 317 $ 576 The Company estimates the fair value of the Class B Incentive Units using the Monte Carlo simulation. In the Monte Carlo simulation, the Class B Units price is assumed to follow a Geometric Brownian Motion. Geometric Brownian Motion formula was utilized to estimate the monthly Class B Units until the change of control event. Management projected that the Company is expected to undergo a change of control event in approximately five years from July 31, 2019. The model checks for the vesting conditions at the time of liquidity event and calculates the distributions accordingly. The simulation model requires the Company to make assumptions and judgments about the variables used in the calculation. These variables and assumptions include the weighted-average period of time that the Incentive Units granted are expected to be outstanding, the volatility of the Class B Units, the risk-free interest rate. Since its stock has no trading history, the Company used the simplified calculation of expected term, and the Company estimated its stock volatility based on an average of the historical volatilities of several entities with characteristics similar to the Company. The risk-free interest rate is based on U.S. Treasury securities.
