Subsection Title: (In thousands of U.S. dollars, unless otherwise specified)
Subsubsection Text: Crash Champions Holdings, LLC and its Subsidiaries (the “Company”) provide collision repair services primarily to auto insurers. The Company was formed on July 19, 2019, as a Delaware limited liability company, and owns one hundred percent of the membership interest in Crash Champions Intermediate, LLC (“Intermediate”). The Company is headquartered in Westmont, Illinois, and operates 278 vehicle collision repair facilities as of September 30, 2023 (Successor) throughout the United States. On August 1, 2022, the Company completed a change of control event ("Significant Transaction"), which included the exit of the controlling interest holder, and Champions Purchaser, Inc. ("Purchaser") acquiring the majority interest in the Company and effecting a merger that included the Company's non-controlling interest holders contributing net assets to Purchaser or Carnelian Point Holdings, L.P. ("Carnelian"), and extinguishing debt and certain other obligations. Total consideration of the merger was $1,113.6 million, comprised of equity and debt financing. As a result of the change of control event, Carnelian is the ultimate parent of the Company. Refer to Note 2 and Note 9 for further information.

Subsection Title: (In thousands of U.S. dollars, unless otherwise specified)
Subsubsection Text: The Significant Transaction is considered a business combination under Accounting Standards Codification ("ASC") 805, _Business Combinations,_ and was accounted for using the acquisition method of accounting as Carnelian was determined to be the accounting acquirer. The Company, as a subsidiary of Carnelian, elected to apply pushdown accounting to its separate financial statements. References to "Successor" or "Successor Period" relate to the consolidated financial position and results of operations of the Company subsequent to August 1, 2022, the date when the Significant Transaction was completed. References to "Predecessor" or "Predecessor Period" relate to the consolidated financial position and results of operations of the Company prior to August 1, 2022. The Successor and Predecessor periods have been separated by a vertical line on the face of the condensed consolidated financial statements to highlight the fact that the financial information for such periods has been prepared under two different historical cost bases of accounting, and the Successor being presented with assets, liabilities, and a capital structure having carrying values not comparable with prior periods to the financial statements.

Subsection Title: (In thousands of U.S. dollars, unless otherwise specified)
Subsubsection Text: The Company operates on a fiscal year ending December 31. The accompanying unaudited condensed consolidated financial statements and notes have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America (“U.S. GAAP”). The condensed consolidated financial statements include the assets, liabilities and results of operations of the Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries. In the opinion of management, the accompanying unaudited condensed consolidated financial statements include all normal recurring adjustments necessary for a fair statement of the Company’s financial position, results of operations, and cash flows for the periods presented. All material intercompany transactions and balances have been eliminated in consolidation. The condensed consolidated balance sheet as of December 31, 2022 (Successor) is derived from the audited consolidated financial statements of the Company but does not include all disclosures required by GAAP. The condensed consolidated financial statements should be read in conjunction with the audited consolidated financial statements and related notes thereto included in our Annual Report for the year ended December 31, 2022 (Successor).

Subsection Title: (In thousands of U.S. dollars, unless otherwise specified)
Subsubsection Text: Accounting policies used in the preparation of these condensed consolidated financial statements are consistent with the accounting policies described in the audited consolidated financial statements and the related notes thereto for the year ended December 31, 2022 (Successor) included in the annual report, except as described below relating to interest rate swap arrangements and the adoption of Accounting Standards Codification (“ASC”) Topic 326, Measurement of Credit Losses on Financial Instruments. -----

Subsection Title: (In thousands of U.S. dollars, unless otherwise specified)
Subsubsection Text: The preparation of condensed consolidated financial statements and related disclosures in accordance with U.S. GAAP requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the condensed consolidated financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting periods. Significant estimates and assumptions include, but are not limited to, the accounting for business combinations, the useful lives and recoverability of tangible and intangible assets, the valuation of goodwill and other indefinite-lived intangible assets, loss contingencies, and income taxes. Management’s estimates and assumptions are evaluated on an ongoing basis and are based on historical experience, current conditions, and available information. Actual results may differ from estimated amounts. Estimates are revised as additional information becomes available.

Subsection Title: (In thousands of U.S. dollars, unless otherwise specified)
Subsubsection Text: The Company uses derivative instruments as part of the overall strategy to manage exposure to market risk associated with fluctuations in interest rates. The Company is exposed to interest rate risk related to its borrowing arrangements and obligations. The Company regularly monitors the financial stability and credit standing of the counterparties to derivative instruments. The Company does not enter into derivative financial instruments for trading or speculative purposes. The Company enters into interest rate contracts to provide predictability in the Company's overall cost structure and to manage the balance of fixed-rate and variable-rate debt. The Company records all derivatives at fair value. On the date the derivative contract is entered into, the Company designates the derivative as one of the following: a hedge of a forecasted transaction or the variability of cash flows to be paid (“Cash Flow Hedge”), a hedge of the fair value of a recognized asset or liability (“Fair Value Hedge”), or an undesignated hedge instrument. The Company had no derivative instruments as of December 31, 2022 (Successor). As of September 30, 2023 (Successor), all of the Company’s derivative instruments were interest rate caps, and none are designated as hedge instruments. The Company entered into two separate interest rate swap arrangements, each with a notional amount of $200.0 million and an effective date of April 28, 2023, to mitigate the interest rate risk associated with interest rate payments related to its variable debt. The two swap arrangements have fixed rates of 4.03% and 4.06%, respectively. The two swap arrangements require quarterly settlements of the difference between the stated fixed rate and current variable rate, and mature April 30, 2025. A natural hedging relationship exists in which changes in the fair value of the instruments act as an economic offset to changes in the fair value of the underlying items. Neither interest rate swap qualifies for hedge accounting since the Company did not contemporaneously document the hedging relationship, and as a result the changes in the fair value of the swap arrangements are reflected in current period earnings in "interest expense, net" within the condensed consolidated statements of operations. The fair value of interest rate contracts is determined based on inputs that are readily available in public markets or can be derived from information available in publicly quoted markets. Interest rate contracts are valued using models based primarily on readily observable market parameters, such as Secured Overnight Financing Rate ("SOFR") forward rates, for all substantial terms of the Company's contracts and credit risk of the counterparties. The fair value of the interest rate swap arrangements as of September 30, 2023 (Successor) is $7.2 million and included in "other assets" within the condensed consolidated balance sheet. The Company recognized $7.2 million in unrealized gains, net from the change in the fair value of the swap arrangements in "interest expense, net" within the condensed consolidated statement of operations for the year-to-date period ended September 30, 2023 (Successor).

Subsection Title: (In thousands of U.S. dollars, unless otherwise specified)
Subsubsection Text: On January 1, 2023, the Company adopted Accounting Standards Update ("ASU") No. 2016-13, "Financial Instruments - Credit Losses (Topic 326): _Measurement of Credit Losses in Financial Instruments" and the subsequent amendments to the initial guidance issued in April 2019 within ASU No. 2019-04, May 2019 within ASU No. 2019-05, and February 2020 within ASU No. 2020-02 (collectively "ASU 326"). These ASUs replace the incurred loss methodology with an expected loss methodology that is referred to as the Current Expected Credit Loss ("CECL") methodology. The guidance primarily affects financial assets and net investment in leases that are not accounted for at fair value through net income but excludes operating lease receivables. The guidance primarily applies to our trade receivables and any future financial assets that have the contractual right to receive cash that we may acquire in the future. ----- The Company adopted Topic 326 using the modified retrospective method for all financial assets measured at amortized cost. Results for reporting periods beginning after January 1, 2023 are presented under Topic 326 while prior period amounts continue to be reported in accordance with previously applicable U.S. GAAP. The adoption of this standard did not have a material impact on the Company, and no adjustment was required to member's equity (deficit) as of January 1, 2023 for the cumulative effect of adopting Topic 326. #### Note 2 — Significant Transaction On August 1, 2022 ("Transaction Date"), the Company's controlling interest was sold to Purchaser, and through Carnelian, a merger was effected resulting in a change of control event due to a new majority interest holder. The change of control event was accounted for as a business combination under ASC 805, Business Combinations, and accounted by Carnelian and pushed down to the Company by allocating the total purchase price consideration to the assets acquired and liabilities assumed based on their estimated fair value. Goodwill is expected to be partially deductible for U.S. tax purposes. The aggregate purchase consideration was $1,113.6 million. To finance a portion of the purchase price, a $410.0 million term loan debt instrument was used. Purchaser, through Carnelian, arranged the debt instrument on behalf of the Company, with Intermediate as ultimate borrower. In addition, the Company used part of the proceeds to extinguish its and Intermediate's existing debt. Refer to Note 9 for further information. Results of the Significant Transaction also included extinguishing existing debt and other obligations, extinguishment and settlement of vested Class A Units, the cancellation of unvested B Units and the distribution of vested B Units. The Company also settled $14.9 million of Predecessor Period related contingent consideration obligations as a result of the Significant Transaction on August 1, 2022. The following table summarizes the purchase price allocation of consideration transferred as of August 1, 2022: Cash consideration $ 405,820 Non-cash consideration 157,458 Repayment of Predecessor debt 550,325 Total purchase consideration $ 1,113,603 Allocation of consideration to assets acquired and liabilities assumed: Cash $ 5,410 Accounts receivable 30,056 Inventories 22,139 Other current assets 7,886 Property, plant and equipment 90,482 Right-of-use assets - operating 286,516 Right-of-use assets - finance 8,920 Customer relationships 251,400 Trade name 389,400 Other assets 50 Accounts payable (54,596) Accrued expenses (38,259) Customer deposits (13,114) Operating lease liabilities (291,534) Finance lease liabilities (8,976) Financing obligation (2,053) Deferred tax liability (5,738) Contingent consideration (121) Other liabilities (79) Total identifiable assets, net 677,789 Goodwill 435,814 Total net assets acquired $ 1,113,603 ----- In addition, $21.2 million in total transaction costs were recognized, comprised of $7.2 million and $14.0 million for the period from August 1, 2022 through September 30, 2022 (Successor) and the period from January 1, 2022 through July 31, 2022 (Predecessor), respectively, in "transaction expense" within the condensed consolidated statements of operations. #### Note 3 — Business Combinations During the Successor and Predecessor periods, the Company acquired 100% interests in vehicle collision repair facilities located throughout the United States. The facilities provide vehicle repair collision services. The results of operations were included in the condensed consolidated financial statements since the respective acquisition dates. Acquisitions are financed with cash on hand funded by debt financing, and at times, equity units, convertible notes, seller financed notes and contingent consideration. The future earnouts were estimated as meeting or exceeding a forecasted gross sales target threshold over a certain post-acquisition period and expected to be earned and paid within a twenty-four-month or thirty-six-month period post-acquisition date. At each respective acquisition date, the Company evaluated the probability of future payments by comparing the forecasted gross sales to the contractual earnout requirements and determined the amount and likelihood of payment based on information available at this point in time. The one-time payments are fixed and not linear and range from $0.3 million to $2.0 million. At each subsequent reporting period end until either payment occurs or the future earnout period expires, the Company reassesses the probability of future payments and measures at fair value accordingly. The acquisitions were accounted for as a business combination under ASC 805, Business Combinations. Tangible and identifiable intangible assets acquired and liabilities assumed were recorded at their respective fair values. The goodwill recognized is primarily attributable to synergies that are expected to be achieved from the integration and represents the excess of consideration transferred resulting from the acquisition less the fair value of all acquired identified assets and liabilities assumed. Goodwill is expected to be partially deducted for U.S. tax purposes. The Company completed 9 business combinations and acquired 15 vehicle collision repair facilities on various dates during the year-to-date period ended September 30, 2023 (Successor), including certain acquired assets and assumed liabilities for an aggregate purchase price of $50.6 million, subject to customary post-closing working capital adjustments, of which $19.8 million in aggregate purchase price related to one business combination that was a multi-shop acquisition in January 2023 that had 4 vehicle repair facilities. Total identifiable assets associated with the January 2023 multi-shop business combination were $7.5 million, which included $1.2 million attributable to property, plant and equipment and $6.3 million attributable to customer relationships. The acquisitions were financed with cash funded by debt financing, rollover equity and seller notes. The following table represents the allocation of assets acquired and liabilities assumed during the year-to-date period ended September 30, 2023 (Successor): Total purchase consideration $ 50,550 Allocation of fair value of assets acquired and liabilities assumed: Inventories 30 Property, plant and equipment 2,752 Intangible assets 16,176 Total identifiable assets, net 18,958 Goodwill 31,592 Total net assets acquired $ 50,550 Total cash consideration was approximately $45.4 million and non-cash consideration was approximately $5.2 million, consisting of rollover equity and seller notes. In addition, the Company recognized $0.5 million in transaction costs in the condensed consolidated statement of operations for the year-to-date period ended September 30, 2023 (Successor). ----- The Company completed 11 business combinations and acquired 42 vehicle collision repair facilities on various dates during the period from August 1, 2022 through September 30, 2022 (Successor), including certain acquired assets and assumed liabilities for an aggregate purchase price of $255.1 million, subject to customary postclosing working capital adjustments, of which $200.5 million in aggregate purchase price related to three business combinations that were multi-shop acquisitions that had 29 vehicle repair facilities. Total identifiable assets associated with these three multi-shop business combinations were $101.9 million, which included $10.5 million attributable to property, plant and equipment and $78.2 million attributable to customer relationships. The acquisitions were financed with cash funded by debt financing under the Successor Credit Agreement, convertible notes issued by Carnelian, and contingent consideration. The following table represents the allocation of assets acquired and liabilities assumed during the period from August 1, 2022 through September 30, 2022 (Successor): Total purchase consideration $ 255,081 Allocation of fair value of assets acquired and liabilities assumed: Cash 3,623 Accounts receivable 1,454 Inventories 1,228 Other current assets 672 Property, plant and equipment 13,318 Right-of-use assets - operating 6,114 Customer relationships 95,643 Other assets 94 Accounts payable (1,604) Accrued expenses (1,718) Customer deposits (202) Operating lease liabilities (5,158) Deferred tax liability (11,773) Total identifiable assets, net 101,691 Goodwill 153,390 Total net assets acquired $ 255,081 Total cash consideration was approximately $229.0 million and non-cash consideration was approximately $26.1 million, consisting of $1.1 million in contingent consideration and $25.0 million in Carnelian issued convertible notes. In addition, the Company recognized $1.9 million in transaction costs in the condensed consolidated statements of operations for the period from August 1, 2022 through September 30, 2022 (Successor). The Company completed 22 business combinations and acquired 27 vehicle collision repair facilities on various dates during the period from January 1, 2022 through July 31, 2022 (Predecessor), including certain acquired assets and assumed liabilities for an aggregate purchase price of $88.7 million, subject to customary post-closing working capital adjustments. The acquisitions were financed with cash funded by debt financing under the Predecessor Credit Agreement and by the Company's issuance of Class A units measured at fair value, estimated using a hybrid of income and market approach methodologies. Total Class A units issued was 81. ----- The following table represents the allocation of assets acquired and liabilities assumed during the period from January 1, 2022 through July 31, 2022 (Predecessor): Total purchase consideration $ 88,749 Allocation of fair value of assets acquired and liabilities assumed: Inventories 52 Property, plant and equipment 4,013 Right-of-use assets - operating 2,035 Trade name 8,313 Operating lease liabilities (1,952) Total identifiable assets, net 12,461 Goodwill 76,288 Total net assets acquired $ 88,749 Total cash consideration was approximately $87.1 million and non-cash consideration was approximately $1.6 million, consisting of $0.9 million in contingent consideration and $0.7 million in the Company issued equity units. The Company recognized $1.9 million in transaction costs in the condensed consolidated statements of operations for the period from January 1, 2022 through July 31, 2022 (Predecessor). #### Note 4 — Revenue Recognition

Subsection Title: (In thousands of U.S. dollars, unless otherwise specified)
Subsubsection Text: During the Successor Period, the Company changed its revenue recognition policy to revenue recognized at a point in time, when the vehicle repairs are complete, and the customer accepts the vehicle. The impact of the change in revenue recognition policy was immaterial due to the short duration of repair orders. During the Predecessor Period, the Company recognized revenue over time and used the input method based on the labor hours on the repair orders as a percentage of total labor hours at the time of order completion to estimate the revenue on the in-process vehicles.

Subsection Title: (In thousands of U.S. dollars, unless otherwise specified)
Subsubsection Text: The Company derives its revenue primarily from providing automobile collision repair services to customer-owned vehicles, including paint and refinishing, glass repair and replacement, vehicle alignment, paintless dent repair, on-site car rentals and towing, with a lifetime warranty provided for all services. The Company's customer base consists of insurance carriers and retail customers. Payment terms are net 30 days. Due to the short-term nature of the average repair cycle revenues are recognized when the repair is completed, in the amount that reflects the consideration the Company expects to be entitled to in exchange for those services. Sales and other taxes the Company collects concurrent with revenue-producing activities are excluded from revenue. Vendor rebates are accounted for as a reduction of the cost of products purchased. The Company estimates the reduction to sales and cost of sales for allowances based on current sales levels and historical experience. Such amounts are immaterial to the condensed consolidated financial statements. The Company does not have any significant financing components as payment is received at or shortly after the repair is completed and the repaired vehicle is available to the customer. Costs incurred to obtain or fulfill a contract are expensed as incurred when the amortization period is less than a year.

Subsection Title: (In thousands of U.S. dollars, unless otherwise specified)
Subsubsection Title: Disaggregation of Revenue From Contracts With Customers
Subsubsection Text: The Company's revenue is generated from one service line consisting of automobile collision repair services. In addition, revenue is not disaggregated, and all revenue is derived in the United States. The collision repair cycle is short in duration and varies based on the extent of work to be performed. The Company has direct repair program agreements with major insurance carriers, but no long-term contracts associated with specific repair service orders. -----

Subsection Title: (In thousands of U.S. dollars, unless otherwise specified)
Subsubsection Text: The Company recognizes revenue when control of the promised service is transferred to the Company's customers in an amount that reflects the consideration the Company expects to be entitled to in exchange for those services, at a point in time when the repair service is completed, and the vehicle is available to the customer. Therefore, there are no contract assets in the condensed consolidated balance sheets. Contract liabilities primarily relate to upfront payments received from customers prior to completion of the repair. Payments received for work not yet completed are deferred until the work is finished. Deferred revenue representing payments received from customers prior to completion of the repair is included in "customer deposits" within the condensed consolidated balance sheets.

Subsection Title: (In thousands of U.S. dollars, unless otherwise specified)
Subsubsection Text: Each collision repair service is a single performance obligation that includes both the parts and labor associated with the service. Payment for the collision repair services is due upon the completion of the service, which is generally completed within a short time from contract inception. The transaction price for the collision repair services is based on the parts used, the number of labor hours applied and the standardized hourly labor rates. The Company satisfies its performance obligations and recognizes revenue when the promised repair services are completed, and the control of the repaired vehicles are transferred to the customer.

Subsection Title: (In thousands of U.S. dollars, unless otherwise specified)
Subsubsection Text: Warranty costs include materials and labor expenses and are recorded as incurred to "cost of sales" in the condensed consolidated statements of operations. The Company provides a lifetime warranty for all vehicles repaired. Based on actual historical warranty costs incurred, over 90% of warranty costs are incurred within 90 days after completion of the repair. The Company determines if a warranty reserve is necessary based on management's best estimate of the future cost of honoring obligations under the lifetime warranty plan. This estimate is based on historical experience. Warranty costs are immaterial, and the Company does not have a warranty reserve as of September 30, 2023 (Successor) and December 31, 2022 (Successor). #### Note 5 — Inventories Inventories consisted of the following: ----- #### Note 6 — Property, Plant and Equipment, Net Property, plant, and equipment, net consisted of the following:

Subsection Title: (In thousands of U.S. dollars, unless otherwise specified)
Subsubsection Text: #### Note 1 — Organization and Summary of Significant Accounting Policies

Goodwill is considered an indefinite-lived intangible asset. The Company accounts for goodwill as the excess of the purchase price over the net amount of identifiable assets acquired and liabilities assumed in a business combination measured at fair value. Goodwill is not subject to amortization; rather, the Company tests goodwill for impairment annually and whenever events occur or changes in circumstances indicate that impairment may have occurred. The Company recognized $31.6 million, $153.4 million, and $76.3 million of goodwill during the year-to-date period ended September 30, 2023 (Successor), the period from August 1, 2022 through September 30, 2022 (Successor), and the period from January 1, 2022 through July 31, 2022 (Predecessor), respectively, due to business combination shop acquisitions. Refer to Note 3 for further information.

The Company's trade name is an indefinite-lived intangible asset. Trade name as of September 30, 2023 (Successor) and December 31, 2022 (Successor) was $389.4 million. Finite-lived intangible assets, net consisted of the following:

As part of the Significant Transaction, the Company entered into the Successor Credit Agreement with various financial institutions maturing on August 1, 2029, consisting of an initial term loan ("Initial Term Loan"), delayed draw term loans (“DDTLs”), and a revolving credit facility ("Revolving Credit Facility"), initially bearing interest of 6.25% per annum for Term SOFR Rate Loans and 5.25% per annum for Base Rate Loans. The proceeds from borrowings under the Successor Credit Agreement were used to finance the Significant Transaction, the related transaction costs, and Successor Period acquisitions. The Revolving Credit Facility provides for maximum aggregate borrowings of up to $60.0 million. As of September 30, 2023 (Successor) and December 31, 2022 (Successor), there were no borrowings outstanding. Principal installments include 0.25% of the aggregate principal amount of the Initial Term Loan plus the aggregate principal amount of DDTLs funded at least two full quarters prior to such date. Interest is due and payable quarterly. All unpaid aggregate principal amounts for any outstanding Initial Term Loan and DDTLs are due at maturity. Prepayments of Initial Term Loan and DDTLs are permitted in whole or in part without premium or penalty, except if prepaid prior to the first anniversary of the close date then a 2.00% prepayment premium of the principal amount applies, or if prepaid prior to the second anniversary of the close date then a 1.00% prepayment premium of the principal amount applies. No prepayment premium is required if prepaid in conjunction with a qualified initial public offering ("IPO") or change of control event. In November 2022, the Company entered into the First Amendment to the Successor Credit Agreement ("Amended Successor Credit Agreement"), consisting of an additional Term Loan ("Additional Term Loan") of $149.7 million. From and after the amendment date, the Initial Term Loan, DDTLs, and the Additional Term Loan bear interest of 7.00% per annum for Term SOFR Rate Loans and 6.00% per annum for Base Rate Loans. The Additional Term Loan requires consecutive quarterly principal installments equal to 0.25% of the aggregate initial principal amount on the Amended Credit Agreement. All unpaid aggregate principal amounts for any outstanding Additional Term Loan are due at maturity. Interest is due and payable quarterly. Prepayments of Additional Term Loan are permitted in whole or in part without premium or penalty, except if prepaid prior to the first anniversary of the close date then a 2.00% prepayment premium of the principal amount applies, or if prepaid prior to the second anniversary of the close date then a 1.00% prepayment premium of the principal amount applies. No prepayment premium is required if prepaid in conjunction with a qualified IPO or change of control event. Total interest expense recognized was $67.8 million and $7.7 million for the year-to-date period ended September 30, 2023 (Successor) and the period from August 1, 2022 through September 30, 2022 (Successor), respectively.

In December 2022, the Company entered into a seller financed note as part of consideration for an acquisition in the amount of $6.0 million, bearing interest of 8.00% per annum, maturing on December 1, 2025. Interest payments are due quarterly, and one balloon payment of $6.0 million of outstanding principal is due at maturity. The Company entered into two seller financed notes as part of consideration for acquisitions completed during the year-to-date period ended September 30, 2023 (Successor) for a total amount of $2.2 million, each bearing interest of 8.00% per annum and maturing in January 2026. Interest payments are due quarterly. One seller financed note requires annual principal installments, while the other requires one balloon payment of outstanding principal due at maturity. In May 2023, the Company entered into a $20.0 million line of credit through Truist Equipment Finance Corp. to finance shop equipment. As of September 30, 2023 (Successor), the Company has drawn $1.8 million related to the equipment financing. -----

The Company's Predecessor Credit Agreement with various financial institutions matures on August 5, 2025, and consists of Term Loans, DDTLs and a Revolving Credit Facility, bearing interest at Base Rate plus a spread between 3.50% to 4.25%, or LIBOR Rate plus a spread between 4.50% to 5.25%, corresponding to the applicable Total Net Debt to EBITDA Ratio. The Predecessor Credit Agreement is secured by substantially all of the assets of the Company, and requires certain financial covenants are met, including total net debt to EBITDA covenant. The Revolving Credit Facility provides for maximum aggregate borrowings of up to $10.0 million. The Term Loan and the DDTLs require quarterly principal payments totaling 0.25% of the outstanding principal balances, and interest payments are due quarterly. On April 1, 2022, May 13, 2021, July 30, 2021, and December 3, 2021, the Company modified its Predecessor Credit Agreement (collectively, the “Amended Agreements”) with various financial institutions maturing on August 5, 2025, consisting of two additional Term Loans of $70.0 million and $50.0 million, and DDTLs in the aggregate of $242.5 million. The proceeds from borrowings under the Amended Agreements were used to fund acquisitions and capital improvements. On August 1, 2022, a portion of the proceeds from the Significant Transaction was used to redeem $485.9 million in aggregate principal of the outstanding Term Loans and DDTLs and pay $3.1 million in accrued interest. Total interest expense recognized was $20.1 million for the period from January 1, 2022 through July 31, 2022 (Predecessor).

The Company entered into a credit agreement (“Senior Note”) on March 29, 2021, maturing on March 29, 2026, and which was amended on July 29, 2021. The Company pays interest on the unpaid principal amount of each Senior Note for the period commencing on the date of such Senior Note until such Senior Note is paid in full at a rate per annum equal to ten and one-half percent (10.5%) in payment in kind interest (“PIK Interest”), payable each fiscal quarter and at maturity. Any unpaid interest is added to the principal balance. The proceeds from borrowings under the Senior Note were used to fund acquisitions and capital improvements. On August 1, 2022, a portion of the proceeds from the Significant Transaction was used to redeem $58.9 million in aggregate principal of the outstanding Senior Note and pay $0.5 million in accrued interest. A penalty payment on the early extinguishment of $1.8 million is not reflected in either the Predecessor or Successor Consolidated Statement of Operations but are instead presented “on the black line” as the penalty was contingent on the consummation of the Significant Transaction. Total interest expense recognized was $3.5 million for the period from January 1, 2022 through July 31, 2022 (Predecessor). #### Note 10 — Leases The Company determines if an arrangement is a lease at inception. A contract is or contains a lease if the contract conveys the right to control the use of an identified asset for a period of time in exchange for consideration. The Company leases vehicle collision repair facilities, administrative offices and equipment under operating leases, and leases vehicles and equipment under finance leases. Leases have remaining lease terms of less than one year to twenty years. The Company estimates the incremental borrowing rate to discount lease payments based on information available at lease commencement. Leases with an initial term of 12 months or less are not recorded in the condensed consolidated balance sheet, as the Company recognizes lease expense on a straightline basis over the lease term. The Company does not consider options to extend or terminate lease contracts at lease inception. ----- The components of lease expense included in the condensed consolidated statements of operations consisted of the following:

In June 2023, the Company entered into a Requirements Agreement ("RA") with BASF Corporation ("BASF") in which BASF will be the Company's exclusive paint vendor. Under the RA, the Company is subject to a total minimum purchase over a ten-year period in exchange for cash incentives. The incentives included a $42.0 million advance payment for paint materials purchase rebates (prebate) received by the Company upon execution of the RA. The deferred paint incentive represents the long-term portion of the prebate received upon execution of the RA and will be amortized to "cost of sales" over the life of the contract. #### Note 12 — Employee Retirement and Incentive Plans The Company provides an employee 401(k) retirement plan (the "Plan") that covers substantially most of its employees. Under the Plan, employees can defer a portion of their gross pay and contribute to the Plan. Employer contributions are discretionary and vest over six years. Employer contributions of $1.6 million, $0.7 million, and $1.5 million were made to the plan for the year-to-date period ended September 30, 2023 (Successor), the period from August 1, 2022 through September 30, 2022 (Successor), and the period from January 1, 2022 through July 31, 2022 (Predecessor), respectively. In January 2023, Carnelian established a long-term cash incentive plan (“LTIP”) for the Company. The LTIP was designed to align certain individual’s interests with the long-term success of Carnelian by (a) promoting the longterm financial interests and growth of its subsidiaries and the Carnelian by attracting and retaining management and other key personnel, (b) motivate management and other key personnel by means of growth-related incentives to achieve long-range goals, and (c) further the alignment of interests of LTIP participants with those of the partners of Carnelian. LTIP participants may be entitled to a one-time cash payment upon the resolution of a future contingent event. As the Carnelian profits interest do not represent a substantive class of equity for accounting purposes, the LTIP will be accounted for under ASC 710, _Compensation-General and ASC 450,_ _Contingencies. The Company has concluded that payout of these awards is not probable until the occurrence of a liquidity event such as a merger, acquisition, or IPO ("Transaction Event"). The Company has not allocated an amount to a cash bonus pool for the LTIP, and the amount of the payment is at the discretion of the Company and will not be determined until the Transaction Event occurs. Accordingly, pursuant to ASC 450, no compensation expense has been recorded as of September 30, 2023 (Successor). #### Note 13 — Income Taxes The Company is not a tax-paying entity for federal income tax purposes. The corporate members are required to report their distributive share of the Company’s realized income, gain, loss, deductions, or credits on their corporate income tax returns. The Company is not a tax-paying entity in the states in which it conducts business, with the exception of Texas. The Company is subject to the Texas Margin Tax based on income imposed on companies with nexus in the state. ----- #### Note 14 — Related-Party Transactions The Company enters into transactions with affiliates who are under common control of Carnelian. During August 2022, the Company entered into a services agreement with one of these affiliates to provide various services to one another or their subsidiaries, which included management services, reimbursement of costs, and calibration and scanning services. The Company recognized $9.3 million in sales related to calibration and scanning services for the year-to-date period ended September 30, 2023 (Successor). There were no calibration and scanning sales for the period from August 1, 2022 through September 30, 2022 (Successor) and the period from January 1, 2022 through July 31, 2022 (Predecessor). Related party transactions included within the condensed consolidated balance sheets as of September 30, 2023 (Successor) was approximately $4.9 million, net due to affiliate, recognized in "accounts payable" within the condensed consolidated balance sheets, and as of December 31, 2022 (Successor) was approximately $4.9 million, net due from affiliate, recognized in "other current assets" within the condensed consolidated balance sheets. As of September 30, 2023 (Successor) and December 31, 2022 (Successor), the Company had 113 and 106, respectively, related party leases. Total lease costs were $22.4 million, $3.6 million, and $10.5 million for the yearto-date period ended September 30, 2023 (Successor), the period from August 1, 2022 through September 30, 2022 (Successor), and the period from January 1, 2022 through July 31, 2022 (Predecessor), respectively, recognized in "selling, general and administrative expenses" within the condensed consolidated statements of operations. Each lease was entered into at prevailing market rates, and certain lease contracts include scheduled increases in rental payments and renewal options. As of September 30, 2023 (Successor), lease obligations of $8.3 million were recognized in "current portion of operating lease liabilities" and $187.6 million were recognized in "long-term operating lease liabilities, less current portion", respectively, in the condensed consolidated balance sheets. As of December 31, 2022 (Successor), lease obligations of $7.2 million were recognized in "current portion of operating lease liabilities" and $179.9 million were recognized in "long-term operating lease liabilities, less current portion", respectively, in the condensed consolidated balance sheets. The CEO of the Company owns a towing company that provides towing services to customers. Total costs were $0.7 million, $0.2 million, and $0.5 million for the year-to-date period ended September 30, 2023 (Successor), the period from August 1, 2022 through September 30, 2022 (Successor), and the period from January 1, 2022 through July 31, 2022 (Predecessor), respectively, recognized in "cost of sales" within the condensed consolidated statements of operations. Clearlake Capital Partners ("Clearlake") provides management related services to the Company during the Successor Period governed under a services agreement. The Company recognized $2.6 million and $0.6 million for the year-to-date period ended September 30, 2023 (Successor) and the period from August 1, 2022 through September 30, 2022 (Successor), respectively, in "selling, general and administrative expenses" within the condensed consolidated statements of operations. As of September 30, 2023 (Successor) and December 31, 2022 (Successor), $3.8 million and $1.4 million, respectively, was due to Clearlake, recognized in "accounts payable" and "accrued expenses" within the condensed consolidated balance sheets. A&M Capital ("A&M"), the former majority equity owner, provided management and consulting services to the Company during the Predecessor Period governed under a services agreement. The Company recognized $0.5 million and $1.1 million for the period from August 1, 2022 through September 30, 2022 (Successor), and the period from January 1, 2022 through July 31, 2022 (Predecessor), respectively, in "selling, general and administrative expenses" within the condensed consolidated statements of operations. In addition, $3.7 million in transaction fees were recognized in the condensed consolidated statements of operations for the period from January 1, 2022 through July 31, 2022 (Predecessor). As of December 31, 2022 (Successor), $1.2 million was due to A&M, recognized in "accrued expenses" within the condensed consolidated balance sheets. There were no costs recognized for the year-to-date period ended September 30, 2023 (Successor) or due as of September 30, 2023 (Successor). ----- #### Note 15 — Supplemental Cash Flow Information The following table includes the supplemental cash flow disclosures for non-cash investing and financing activities for the periods and years ended:

Subsubsection Text: During 2023, the Company began using a combination of insurance and self-insurance with stop-loss coverages for employee health care utilizing high deductibles. Reserves are established for both identified claims and incurred but not reported (“IBNR”) claims. Such amounts are accrued for when claim amounts become probable and estimable. Reserves for identified claims are based upon the Company’s historical claims experience and third-party estimates of settlement costs. Reserves for IBNR claims are based on the Company’s claims history, actuarial determined loss development factors and qualitative considerations, such as claims management activities. Total claims reserves were $6.4 million as of September 30, 2023 (Successor), recognized in "accrued expenses" within the condensed consolidated balance sheets.

Subsubsection Text: In the normal course of the Company’s business, it is at times subject to pending and threatened legal actions, in some cases for which the relief or damages sought may be substantial. Although the Company is not able to predict the outcome of such actions, after reviewing all pending and threatened actions with counsel and based on information currently available, management believes that the outcome of such actions, individually or in the aggregate, will not have a material adverse effect on the Company’s results of operations or financial position. However, it is possible that the ultimate resolution of such matters, if unfavorable, may be material to the Company’s results of operations in a particular future period as the time and amount of any resolution of such actions and its relationship to the future results of operations are not currently known. The Company accrues losses when they are probable of occurrence and such losses are reasonably estimable. The Company completed 3 business combinations consisting of 8 vehicle collision repair facilities for an aggregate purchase price of $20.9 million between October and December 2023. The business combinations were funded with a combination of cash on hand and financing from the Revolving Credit Facility, that has borrowings outstanding of $26.0 million as of January 12, 2024. The Company is currently evaluating the accounting for these business combinations. The Company concluded that no other events have occurred that would require recognition or disclosure in the condensed consolidated financial statements. ----- ## New SK HoldCo Sub, LLC and Subsidiaries For the 171 days ended December 31, 2022 (Successor), the 193 days ended July 13, 2022 (Predecessor), and the fiscal years ended January 1, 2022 (Predecessor) and January 2, 2021 (Predecessor) ----- ##### INDEPENDENT AUDITOR’S REPORT To the Board of Directors and Members of  Carnelian Point Holdings, L.P. Opinion We have audited the consolidated financial statements of New SK HoldCo Sub, LLC and subsidiaries (the “Company”), which comprise the consolidated balance sheets as of December 31, 2022 (Successor Company balance sheet) and January 1, 2022 (Predecessor Company balance sheet), and the related consolidated statements of operations, comprehensive loss, member’s equity (deficit), and cash flows for the 171 days ended December 31, 2022 (Successor Company operations) and the 193 days ended July 13, 2022, and the fiscal years ended January 1, 2022 and January 2, 2021 (Predecessor Company operations), and the related notes to the consolidated financial statements (collectively referred to as the "financial statements"). In our opinion, the accompanying financial statements present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of the Company as of December 31, 2022 (successor) and January 1, 2022 (predecessor), and the results of its operations and its cash flows from July 14, 2022 to December 31, 2022 (successor), January 2, 2022 to July 13, 2022 (predecessor), and for the fiscal years ended January 1, 2022 (predecessor), and January 2, 2021 (predecessor), in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America. Basis for Opinion We conducted our audits in accordance with auditing standards generally accepted in the United States of America (GAAS). Our responsibilities under those standards are further described in the Auditor’s Responsibilities for the Audit of the Financial Statements section of our report. We are required to be independent of the Company and to meet our other ethical responsibilities, in accordance with the relevant ethical requirements relating to our audits. We believe that the audit evidence we have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our audit opinion. Emphasis of Matter As discussed in Note 1 and Note 2 to the Financial Statements, on July 14, 2022, based upon agreed‐upon terms an out of court financial restructuring was consummated by Carnelian Point Holdings, L.P., the Company’s ultimate parent. This resulted in a change of control. Accordingly, the accompanying financial statements have been prepared in conformity with FASB Accounting Standard Codification 805, Business Combinations, for the Successor Company as a new entity with assets, liabilities, and a capital structure having carrying values not comparable with prior periods to the financial statements. Our opinion is not modified with respect to this matter. ----- ##### Responsibilities of Management for the Financial Statements Management is responsible for the preparation and fair presentation of the financial statements in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America, and for the design, implementation, and maintenance of internal control relevant to the preparation and fair presentation of financial statements that are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error. In preparing the financial statements, management is required to evaluate whether there are conditions or events, considered in the aggregate, that raise substantial doubt about the Company’s ability to continue as a going concern for one year after the date that the financial statements are issued. Auditor’s Responsibilities for the Audit of the Financial Statements Our objectives are to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements as a whole are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error, and to issue an auditor’s report that includes our opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance but is not absolute assurance and therefore is not a guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with GAAS will always detect a material misstatement when it exists. The risk of not detecting a material misstatement resulting from fraud is higher than for one resulting from error, as fraud may involve collusion, forgery, intentional omissions, misrepresentations, or the override of internal control. Misstatements are considered material if there is a substantial likelihood that, individually or in the aggregate, they would influence the judgment made by a reasonable user based on the financial statements. In performing an audit in accordance with GAAS, we:  Exercise professional judgment and maintain professional skepticism throughout the audit.  Identify and assess the risks of material misstatement of the financial statements, whether due to fraud or error, and design and perform audit procedures responsive to those risks. Such procedures include examining, on a test basis, evidence regarding the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements.  Obtain an understanding of internal control relevant to the audit in order to design audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the Company’s internal control. Accordingly, no such opinion is expressed.  Evaluate the appropriateness of accounting policies used and the reasonableness of significant accounting estimates made by management, as well as evaluate the overall presentation of the financial statements.  Conclude whether, in our judgment, there are conditions or events, considered in the aggregate, that raise substantial doubt about the Company’s ability to continue as a going concern for a reasonable period of time. We are required to communicate with those charged with governance regarding, among other matters, the planned scope and timing of the audit, significant audit findings, and certain internal control‐related matters that we identified during the audit. ----- ##### Other Information Included in the Annual Report Management is responsible for the other information included in the annual report. The other information comprises the information included in the annual report but does not include the financial statements and our auditor’s report thereon. Our opinion on the financial statements does not cover the other information, and we do not express an opinion or any form of assurance thereon. In connection with our audits of the financial statements, our responsibility is to read the other information and consider whether a material inconsistency exists between the other information and the financial statements, or the other information otherwise appears to be materially misstated. If, based on the work performed, we conclude that an uncorrected material misstatement of the other information exists, we are required to describe it in our report. Subsection Title: (In thousands of U.S. dollars, unless otherwise specified)
Subsubsection Text: New SK Holdco Sub, LLC (the "Company") was formed on July 5, 2022 and is wholly owned by New SK Holdco, Inc. ("New SK Holdco"), also formed on July 5, 2022. New SK Holdco is wholly owned by Carnelian Point Holdings, L.P. (“Carnelian”), the Company's ultimate parent. On May 27, 2022, SK Holdco, LLC (“SK Holdco” or "Predecessor") and certain of its subsidiaries entered into an agreement for an out-of-court financial restructuring of SK Holdco and its subsidiaries (the “Restructuring Transaction”). The Restructuring Transaction closed on July 14, 2022. SK Holdco transferred all of the assets and obligations of Service King Paint & Body, LLC and its wholly owned subsidiaries, Sterling Collision Centers, LLC, and Service King Northwest Paint & Body, LLC, (together “SK Opco”), to the Company in exchange for 100% equity interest of the Company. Refer to Note 2 for additional information.

Subsubsection Text: The Restructuring Transaction is considered a business combination under Accounting Standards Codification ("ASC") 805, _Business Combinations_ and was accounted for using the acquisition method of accounting, as Carnelian was determined to be the accounting acquirer. The Company, as a subsidiary of Carnelian, elected to apply push-down accounting to its separate financial statements. References to "Successor" or "Successor Period" relate to the consolidated financial position and results of operations of the Company subsequent to July 14, 2022, the date when the Restructuring Transaction was completed. References to "Predecessor" or "Predecessor Period" relate to the consolidated financial position and results of operations of the Company prior to July 14, 2022. The Successor and Predecessor periods have been separated by a vertical line on the face of the condensed consolidated financial statements to highlight the fact that the financial information for such periods has been prepared under two different historical cost bases of accounting, and the Successor being presented with assets, liabilities, and a capital structure having carrying values not comparable with prior periods to the financial statements. In the accompanying notes, references to "the Company" relate to Successor and Predecessor for the same periods.

Subsection Title: (In thousands of U.S. dollars, unless otherwise specified)
Subsubsection Text: The Company provides collision repair services primarily to auto insurers. The Company operated 328 repair facilities as of September 30, 2023 (Successor) throughout the United States.

Subsection Title: (In thousands of U.S. dollars, unless otherwise specified)
Subsubsection Title: Basis of Presentation and Principles of Consolidation
Subsubsection Text: The accompanying unaudited condensed consolidated financial statements and notes have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America (“U.S. GAAP”). The Predecessor's fiscal year consisted of 52 or 53 weeks ending on the Saturday closest to December 31. The Company as Successor changed its fiscal year to a calendar year end of December 31. This change did not have a material impact on the condensed consolidated financial statements. The condensed consolidated financial statements include the assets, liabilities and results of operations of the Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries. In the opinion of management, the accompanying unaudited condensed consolidated financial statements include all normal recurring adjustments necessary for a fair statement of the Company’s financial position, results of operations, and cash flows for the periods presented. All material intercompany transactions and balances have been eliminated in consolidation. The condensed consolidated balance sheet as of December 31, 2022 (Successor) is derived from the audited consolidated financial statements of the Company but does not include all disclosures required by GAAP. The condensed consolidated financial statements should be read in conjunction with the audited consolidated financial statements and related notes thereto included in our Annual Report for the year ended December 31, 2022 (Successor). -----

Subsection Title: (In thousands of U.S. dollars, unless otherwise specified)
Subsubsection Text: Accounting policies used in the preparation of these condensed consolidated financial statements are consistent with the accounting policies described in the audited consolidated financial statements and the related notes thereto for the year ended December 31, 2022 (Successor) included in the annual report, except as described below relating to the adoption of Accounting Standards Codification (“ASC”) Topic 326, _Measurement of Credit _Losses on Financial Instruments._

Subsection Title: (In thousands of U.S. dollars, unless otherwise specified)
Subsubsection Text: The preparation of condensed consolidated financial statements and related disclosures in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America ("U.S. GAAP") requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the condensed consolidated financial statements and the reported amounts of revenue and expenses during the reporting periods. Significant estimates and assumptions include, but are not limited to, the accounting for business combinations, the useful lives and recoverability of tangible and intangible assets, the valuation of goodwill and other indefinite-lived intangible assets, self-insurance, warranty reserves, and loss contingencies. Actual results could vary from those estimated amounts. Estimates are revised as additional information becomes available.

Subsection Title: (In thousands of U.S. dollars, unless otherwise specified)
Subsubsection Text: On January 1, 2023, the Company adopted Accounting Standards Update ("ASU") No. 2016-13, "Financial Instruments - Credit Losses (Topic 326): _Measurement of Credit Losses in Financial Instruments" and the subsequent amendments to the initial guidance issued in April 2019 within ASU No. 2019-04, May 2019 within ASU No. 2019-05, and February 2020 within ASU No. 2020-02 (collectively "ASU 326"). These ASUs replace the incurred loss methodology with an expected loss methodology that is referred to as the Current Expected Credit Loss ("CECL") methodology. The guidance primarily affects financial assets and net investment in leases that are not accounted for at fair value through net income but excludes operating lease receivables. The guidance primarily applies to our trade receivables and any future financial assets that have the contractual right to receive cash that we may acquire in the future. The Company adopted Topic 326 using the modified retrospective method for all financial assets measured at amortized cost. Results for reporting periods beginning after January 1, 2023 are presented under Topic 326 while prior period amounts continue to be reported in accordance with previously applicable U.S. GAAP. The adoption of this standard did not have a material impact on the Company, and no adjustment was required to member's equity (deficit) as of January 1, 2023 for the cumulative effect of adopting Topic 326. #### Note 2 — Restructuring Transaction The Restructuring Transaction was a combination of extinguishing and modifying certain debt instruments, certain equity holders exiting, and the addition of a new equity partner, resulting in a change of control event on July 14, 2022, the date Carnelian completed the acquisition of the Company. The Restructuring Transaction resulted in a change in ownership and control and was recorded under the acquisition method of accounting by Carnelian and pushed down to the Company by allocating the total purchase price consideration to the assets acquired and liabilities assumed based on their estimated fair values. The excess of the consideration transferred over the estimated fair values of assets acquired and liabilities assumed by Carnelian resulted in goodwill, which was recognized by the Company through push-down accounting, and primarily relates to the value of the existing workforce, unidentifiable intangible assets and the fair value of expected synergies. Goodwill is not expected to be deductible for U.S. tax purposes. The outstanding Predecessor debt was settled in exchange for equity interests in the Company through the issuance of convertible securities held at Carnelian. As part of the Restructuring Transaction, the Company's Second Amended and Restated Credit Agreement ("Amended Senior Facilities") was restated. Refer to Note 8 for additional information. In addition, the Company's restricted cash of $30.0 million was released for general corporate purposes. Immediately subsequent to the change of control event, Carnelian contributed $125.0 million in cash to the Company and with the proceeds the Company immediately paid down the remaining $66.3 million of the senior secured revolving credit facility and other transaction costs. ----- The Company recognized $33.8 million in total transaction costs, comprised of $14.4 million and $19.4 million for the period July 14, 2022 through September 30, 2022 (Successor) and for the period January 2, 2022 through July 13, 2022 (Predecessor), respectively, as "transaction expense" within the condensed consolidated statements of operations.
