Subsection Title: (In thousands of U.S. dollars, unless otherwise specified)
Subsubsection Text: The Company derives its revenue primarily from providing automobile collision repair services to customer-owned vehicles, including paint and refinishing, glass repair and replacement, vehicle alignment, paintless dent repair, on-site car rentals and towing, with a lifetime warranty provided for all services. The Company's customer base consists of insurance carriers and retail customers. Payment terms are net 30 days. Due to the short-term nature of the average repair cycle, revenues are recognized when the repair is completed, in the amount that reflects the consideration the Company expects to be entitled to in exchange for those services. Sales and other taxes the Company collects concurrent with revenue-producing activities are excluded from revenue. The Company does not have any significant financing components as payment is received at or shortly after the repair is completed and the repaired vehicle is available to the customer. Costs incurred to obtain or fulfill a contract are expensed as incurred when the amortization period is less than a year. The Company’s revenues are largely derived from the insurers of its customers, who are generally the automobile owners. Formal relationships with insurance companies, such as Service King Direct Repair Programs ("DRPs"), play an important role in generating sales for the Company. Typically, vehicle owners have the freedom to choose the repair provider and can be influenced by the insurance companies. -----

Subsection Title: (In thousands of U.S. dollars, unless otherwise specified)
Subsubsection Title: Disaggregation of Revenue From Contracts With Customers
Subsubsection Text: The Company's revenue is generated from one service line consisting of automobile collision repair services. In addition, revenue is not disaggregated, and all revenue is derived in the United States. The collision repair cycle is short in duration and varies based on the extent of work to be performed. The Company has direct repair program agreements with major insurance carriers, but no long-term contracts associated with specific repair service orders.

Subsection Title: (In thousands of U.S. dollars, unless otherwise specified)
Subsubsection Text: The Company recognizes revenue when control of the promised service is transferred to the Company's customers in an amount that reflects the consideration the Company expects to be entitled to in exchange for those services, at a point in time when the repair service is completed and the vehicle is available to the customer. Therefore, there are no contract assets in the condensed consolidated balance sheets. Contract liabilities primarily relate to upfront payments received from customers prior to completion of the repair. Payments received for work not yet completed are deferred until the work is finished. Deferred revenue representing payments received from customers prior to completion of the repair is included in "accrued expenses and other liabilities" in the condensed consolidated balance sheets.

Subsection Title: (In thousands of U.S. dollars, unless otherwise specified)
Subsubsection Text: Each collision repair service is a single performance obligation that includes both the parts and labor associated with the service. Payment for the collision repair services is due upon the completion of the service, which is generally completed within a short time from contract inception. The transaction price for the collision repair services is based on the parts used, the number of labor hours applied and the standardized hourly labor rates. The Company satisfies its performance obligations and recognizes revenue when the promised repair services are completed, and the control of the repaired vehicles are transferred to the customer.

Subsection Title: (In thousands of U.S. dollars, unless otherwise specified)
Subsubsection Text: Warranty costs include materials and labor expenses and are recorded as incurred to "cost of sales" in the condensed consolidated statements of operations. The Company provides a lifetime warranty for all vehicles repaired. Based on actual historical warranty costs incurred, over 90% of warranty costs are incurred within 90 days after completion of the repair. The Company maintains a reserve that reflects management's best estimate of the future cost of honoring obligations under the lifetime warranty plan. This estimate is based on historical experience. Warranty reserves of $0.5 million and $0.4 million are included in "accrued expenses and other liabilities" within the condensed consolidated balance sheets as of September 30, 2023 (Successor) and December 31, 2022 (Successor), respectively. #### Note 4 — Inventories Inventories consisted of the following: ----- #### Note 5 — Property, Plant and Equipment - Net Property, plant and equipment consisted of the following:

Subsection Title: (In thousands of U.S. dollars, unless otherwise specified)
Subsubsection Text: #### Note 1 — Business and Summary of Significant Accounting Policies #### Note 1 — Business and Summary of Significant Accounting Policies

The Restructuring Transaction is considered a business combination under ASC 805, Business Combinations and will be accounted for using the acquisition method of accounting, as Carnelian was determined to be the accounting acquirer. The Company, as a subsidiary of Carnelian elected to apply pushdown accounting to its separate financial statements. References to "Successor" relate to the consolidated financial position and results of operations of New SK HoldCo Sub, LLC subsequent to July 14, 2022, the date when the Restructuring Transaction was completed. References to "Predecessor" relate to the consolidated financial position and results of operations of SK HoldCo between January 2, 2022 through July 13, 2022, and the fiscal years ended January 1, 2022 and January 2, 2021. The Predecessor and Successor periods have been separated by a vertical line on the face of the consolidated financial statements to highlight the fact that the financial information for such periods has been prepared under two different historical cost bases of accounting and the Successor Company being presented with assets, liabilities, and a capital structure having carrying values not comparable with prior periods to the financial statements. In the accompanying notes references to "the Company" relate to Successor and Predecessor for the same periods.
The Company provides collision repair services primarily to auto insurers. The Company is headquartered in Richardson, Texas, and operates 329 repair facilities throughout the United States.

Subsubsection Title: Basis of Presentation and Principles of Consolidation
Subsubsection Text: The accompanying consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America ("U.S. GAAP"). The Predecessor's fiscal year consisted of 52 or 53 weeks ending on the Saturday closest to December 31. References to years in the consolidated financial statements relate to fiscal years rather than calendar years during the Predecessor period. The Company as Successor changed its fiscal year to a calendar year end of December 31. This change does not have a material impact on the consolidated financial statements. ----- The accompanying consolidated financial statements include the accounts of the Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries. All material intercompany transactions and balances have been eliminated in consolidation.

The preparation of consolidated financial statements and related disclosures in accordance with U.S. GAAP requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the consolidated financial statements and the reported amounts of revenue and expenses during the reporting periods. Significant estimates and assumptions include, but are not limited to, the accounting for acquisitions, the useful lives and recoverability of tangible and intangible assets, the valuation of goodwill and other indefinite-lived intangible assets, self-insurance, warranty reserves, and loss contingencies. Actual results could vary from those estimated amounts. Estimates are revised as additional information becomes available.

The Company considers cash and highly liquid investments with an original maturity of three months or less to be cash and cash equivalents. Cash and cash equivalents are stated at cost, which approximates or equals fair value due to their short-term nature.

Cash and cash equivalents that are restricted as to withdrawal or use under the terms of certain contractual agreements are recorded as restricted cash in the Company’s consolidated balance sheets. As of December 31, 2022 (Successor) the Company had no restricted cash. As of January 1, 2022 (Predecessor), the Company's restricted cash was $75.0 million. Restricted cash represented proceeds from the Amended Senior Facilities as defined in Note 2, which are held in a segregated account and only used to prepay, repay, redeem, purchase or defease the Senior Notes.

Subsubsection Title: Accounts Receivable and Allowance for Doubtful Accounts
Subsubsection Text: Accounts receivable consist of trade receivables carried at the original invoice amount. The Company routinely assesses the financial strength of its customers and believes that its trade receivables credit risk exposure is limited. An allowance for doubtful accounts is provided for known and anticipated credit losses and disputed amounts, as determined by management in the course of regularly evaluating individual customer receivables. This evaluation takes into consideration a customer’s financial condition and credit history, as well as current economic conditions. Amounts are written-off if and when they are determined to be uncollectible.

Inventories are valued at the lower of cost or net realizable value (on a first-in, first-out basis). Inventories consist of paint and other repair materials and supplies. Work in process consists of estimated labor, parts, and services attributable to repair orders that are in process as of the consolidated balance sheets date.

Property, plant, and equipment ("PP&E") is recorded at cost, net of accumulated depreciation. Construction in progress is also recorded at cost. Depreciation and amortization are provided at rates designed to distribute the cost of assets over their estimated service lives or, for leasehold improvements, the shorter of their estimated service lives or the remaining terms of the related leases. Depreciation of assets recorded under finance leases is included in depreciation expense. The following table represents the estimated lives and method: |Type|Col2|Life in years Method| |---|---|---| |Buildings 39 years Straight line Furniture and equipment 1 - 7 years Straight line Leasehold improvements 10 years Straight line Software 3 - 7 years Straight line Vehicles 1 - 5 years Straight line||| ----- Property, plant, and equipment is evaluated for impairment at the asset group level. If a triggering event suggests that a potential impairment has occurred, recoverability of these assets is assessed by evaluating whether or not future estimated undiscounted net cash flows are less than the carrying amount of the assets. If the estimated cash flows are less than the carrying amount, the assets are written down to their fair value through an impairment loss recognized as a non-cash component of “operating income (loss)” within the consolidated statements of operations. The Company did not recognize an impairment charge related to long-lived assets, including Right-of-Use ("ROU") Assets during the periods July 14, 2022 through December 31, 2022 (Successor) and January 2, 2022 through July 13, 2022 (Predecessor). During the years ended January 1, 2022 (Predecessor) and January 2, 2021 (Predecessor), the Company recognized $0.1 million and $1.8 million, respectively, related to impairment of ROU Assets due to permanent store closures.

The Company capitalizes certain costs associated with computer software developed or obtained for internal use and includes it in property, plant, and equipment in the consolidated balance sheets. This policy provides for the capitalization of certain payroll and payroll-related costs for employees who are directly associated with internal use computer software projects along with external costs incurred. Costs associated with preliminary project stage activities, training, maintenance, and all other post implementation stage activities are expensed as incurred. The Company also expenses internal costs related to minor upgrades and enhancements, as it is impractical to separate these costs from normal maintenance activities. Capitalized costs related to computer software developed for internal use are amortized on a straight-line basis over a three-year to seven-year period, reflecting the estimated period during which these assets will remain in service. The net book value of capitalized internal-use software cost was $2.9 million and $2.2 million as of December 31, 2022 (Successor) and January 1, 2022 (Predecessor), respectively. Amortization expense related to capitalized internal-use software costs was $1.2 million for the period July 14, 2022 through December 31, 2022 (Successor), $0.7 million for the period January 2, 2022 through July 13, 2022 (Predecessor), $1.4 million and $1.6 million in the years ended January 1, 2022 (Predecessor) and January 2, 2021 (Predecessor), respectively.

Goodwill represents the excess of purchase price over the fair value of identifiable assets acquired in a business combination, and was to one reporting unit. Goodwill is not subject to amortization; rather, the Company tests goodwill for impairment annually October 1 and whenever events occur or changes in circumstances indicate that impairment may have occurred. Impairment testing is performed by first assessing qualitative factors to see if further testing of goodwill is required. If the Company concludes that it is more likely than not that a reporting unit’s fair value is less than its carrying amount based on the qualitative assessment, then a quantitative test is required. The Company may also choose to bypass the qualitative assessment and perform the quantitative test. If the estimated fair value of a reporting unit exceeds the carrying value, the Company considers that goodwill is not impaired. If the carrying value exceeds estimated fair value, there is an impairment of goodwill and an impairment loss is recorded as a non-cash component of "Operating income (loss)". The Company calculates the impairment loss by comparing the fair value of its one reporting unit less the carrying amount, including goodwill. Goodwill impairment would be limited to the carrying value of the goodwill. There were no impairment charges for the periods July 14, 2022 through December 31, 2022 (Successor), January 2, 2022 through July 13, 2022 (Predecessor), and the years ended January 1, 2022 (Predecessor) and January 2, 2021 (Predecessor). Refer to Note 6 for additional information.

Amortizable intangible assets include trade names and customer relationships. The Company does not have any indefinite lived intangible assets other than goodwill. The intangible assets are being amortized on a straight-line basis over the estimated useful lives, which range from 2 to 20 years, reflecting the pattern in which the economic benefits are consumed or otherwise used up. The Company evaluates whether events or circumstances have occurred that warrant a revision to the remaining useful lives of intangible assets. In cases where a revision is deemed appropriate, the remaining carrying amounts of the intangible assets are amortized over the revised remaining useful lives. ----- The Company evaluates amortizable intangible assets for potential impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amounts of the assets may not be fully recoverable. If a triggering event suggests that a potential impairment has occurred, recoverability of these assets is assessed by evaluating the probability that future estimated undiscounted net cash flows will be less than the carrying amount of the longlived assets. If the estimated cash flows are less than the carrying amount of the long-lived assets, the assets are written down to their fair value through an impairment loss recognized as a non-cash component of “Operating income (loss)”. There were no impairment charges for the periods July 14, 2022 through December 31, 2022 (Successor), January 2, 2022 through July 13, 2022 (Predecessor), and the years ended January 1, 2022 (Predecessor) and January 2, 2021 (Predecessor). Refer to Note 6 for additional information.

The Company has recorded deferred financing costs incurred in conjunction with its debt obligations. The Company amortizes debt issuance costs over the remaining life of the related debt using the effective interest method. Deferred financing costs, net of accumulated amortization, are presented as other assets (non-current) in the consolidated balance sheets, insofar as they relate to the Amended Revolver and Restated Revolving Credit Facility. Deferred financing costs related to the remaining debt instruments are recorded as a reduction of long-term debt – less current portion in the consolidated balance sheets. Refer to Note 10 for additional information.

The Company derives its revenue primarily from repairing collision damage to customer owned automobiles. Direct materials, labor, and services are deferred as work-in-process inventory until the applicable repair work is completed. Payments received for work not yet completed are deferred until the work is finished. Due to the short term nature of the average repair cycle revenue is recognized when the repair work is completed and the repaired automobile is available for pick up by the customer. Direct materials, labor, and services are recorded as cost of sales at the time the repair work is completed. The Company presents revenue net of sales taxes. The Company provides lifetime warranty for all vehicles repaired. See Note 3.

The Company determines if an arrangement is or contains a lease at inception. The Company enters into leases primarily for collision repair facilities, administrative offices, and equipment under varying terms and conditions. The Company early adopted Accounting Standards Update ("ASU") ASU No. 2016-02, _Leases, issued by the Financial Accounting Standards Board ("FASB") on December 29, 2019. The Company evaluates lease contracts and determines the lease term and classification. Favorable and unfavorable leases resulting from business combinations are amortized over the term of the related lease. The net carrying amounts of favorable and unfavorable leases are included in operating lease right-of-use assets, net of accumulated amortization in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets. See Note 11.

Advertising costs included in selling, general and administrative expenses are expensed as incurred and totaled $0.7 million, $0.6 million, $2.0 million and $2.2 million for the period July 14, 2022 through December 31, 2022 (Successor), January 2, 2022 through July 13, 2022 (Predecessor), and for the years ended January 1, 2022 (Predecessor), and January 2, 2021 (Predecessor), respectively.
Maintenance and repairs are charged to expense as incurred while improvements that increase the value of the property and extend the useful life are capitalized.

During the Predecessor period, the Company uses derivative financial instruments for the purpose of hedging exposures to fluctuations in interest rates. The Company recognizes all derivatives at fair value, whether designated in hedging relationships or not, in the consolidated balance sheets as either an asset or liability. If certain conditions are met, a derivative may be specifically designated as a hedge, the objective of which is to match the timing of gain or loss recognition on the hedging derivative with the recognition of the earnings effect of ----- the hedged forecasted transaction. For a derivative designated as a cash flow hedge, the effective portion of the derivative’s change in fair value is initially recorded as a component of accumulated other comprehensive loss and is recognized in the consolidated statements of operations when the hedged item affects earnings. The ineffective portion of the mark to fair value associated with all hedges is reported in operations immediately. Derivatives that do not qualify as a hedge are marked to fair value with gains and losses immediately recorded in the consolidated statements of operations. In the consolidated statements of cash flows, derivative activities are classified based on the items being hedged. The Company does not enter into derivative contracts for speculative purposes.

Fair value is defined as the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date. The fair value is a market-based measurement that should be determined based on assumptions that market participants would use in pricing an asset or liability. As a basis for considering assumptions, the Company follows a three-tier fair value hierarchy which prioritizes the inputs used in measuring fair value as follows: Level 1 - Quoted prices for identical assets or liabilities in active markets. Level 2 - Quoted prices for similar assets or liabilities in active markets, quoted prices for identical or similar instruments in markets that are not active, and model-derived valuations in which all significant inputs are observable in active markets. Level 3 - Unobservable inputs in which there is little or no market data, which require the reporting entity to develop its own assumptions. See Note 14.

The Company accounts for income taxes under the asset and liability method, which requires the recognition of deferred tax assets and liabilities for the expected future tax consequences of events that have been included in the financial statements. Under this method, deferred tax assets and liabilities are determined on the basis of the differences between the financial statement and tax bases of assets and liabilities using enacted tax rates in effect for the year in which the differences are expected to reverse. The effect of a change in tax rates on deferred tax assets and liabilities is recognized in income in the period that includes the enactment date. The Company recognizes deferred tax assets to the extent that it believes these assets are more likely than not to be realized. In making such a determination, the Company considers all available positive and negative evidence including future reversals of existing taxable timing temporary differences, projected future taxable income, taxplanning strategies and recent results of operations. If the Company determines that it is not able to realize the deferred tax assets in the future, the Company will make an adjustment to the deferred tax asset valuation allowance. The Company records uncertain tax positions on the basis whether it is more likely than not that the tax positions will be sustained and for those tax positions that meet the more-likely-than-not recognition threshold, we recognize the largest amount of tax benefit that is more than 50 percent likely to be realized upon settlement with the related tax authority. The Company recognizes interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits within the income tax expense line in the consolidated statement of operations. Accrued interest and penalties are included within the related tax liability line in the consolidated balance sheets.

The Company follows fair value method accounting for equity-based compensation. Under the fair value method, compensation cost is measured at the grant date based on the fair value of the award and is recognized on a straight-line basis over the vesting period. Stock based compensation is recognized only for awards that are expected to vest and the periodic accrual of compensation is based on the estimated number of awards expected to vest. In conjunction with the Restructuring Transaction, the equity-based compensation plans were terminated on July 14, 2022. See Note 17 for additional information. -----

In June 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-13, Financial Instruments—Credit Losses (Topic 326), and issued subsequent amendments to the initial guidance in May 2019 within ASU No. 2019-05 and in November 2019 within ASU Nos. 2019-10 and 2019-11. This standard changes the methodology for measuring credit losses on financial instruments and the timing of when such losses are recorded. The standard will result in the immediate recognition of an estimate of credit losses that are expected to occur over the life of the financial instruments that are within the scope of the guidance, including trade receivables, which changes the methodology for measuring credit losses on financial instruments and the timing of when such losses are recorded. The standard is effective beginning with our 2023 fiscal year. The Company is currently evaluating the impact of the adoption of this standard and do not expect the standard to have a material impact on the consolidated financial statements. #### Note 2 — Significant Transaction The Restructuring Transaction was a combination of extinguishing and modifying certain debt instruments, certain equity holders exiting and the addition of a new equity partner, resulting in a change of control event on July 14, 2022, the date Carnelian completed the acquisition of New SK HoldCo Sub, LLC. The Senior Notes and the Series 2022 Incremental Term Loan as defined in Note 10 were settled in exchange for equity interests in the Company through the issuance of convertible securities held at Carnelian, and the Term Loan - Related Party was merged into the Amended Senior Facilities. As part of the Restructuring Transaction, the Company's Second Amended and Restated Credit Agreement ("Amended Senior Facilities") was restated. Refer to Note 10 for additional information on the debt extinguishment and modification. In addition, the Company's restricted cash of $30.0 million was released for general corporate purposes, and the Company's Master Sales Agreement ("MSA") with Axalta Coating Systems, LLC ("Axalta"), was cancelled and replaced with a new agreement. Refer to Note 12 for additional information. Immediately subsequent to the change of control event Carnelian contributed $125.0 million in cash to the Company and with the proceeds the Company immediately paid down the remaining $66.3 million of the senior secured revolving credit facility and other transaction costs. The Company recognized $33.8 million in total transaction costs, comprised of $14.4 million and $19.4 million for the period July 14, 2022 through December 31, 2022 (Successor) and for the period January 2, 2022 through July 13, 2022 (Predecessor), respectively, as transaction expense within the consolidated statements of operations. -----

The Restructuring Transaction resulted in a change in ownership and control and was recorded under the acquisition method of accounting by Carnelian and pushed-down to New SK HoldCo Sub, LLC by allocating the total purchase price consideration to the assets acquired and liabilities assumed based on their estimated fair values. The following table summarizes the preliminary purchase price allocation of consideration transferred (in thousands):

New SK HoldCo Sub, LLC (the "Company" or "Successor"), a Delaware limited liability company, was formed on July 5, 2022 pursuant to the terms of a Transaction Service Agreement ("TSA"). The Company is wholly owned by New SK Holdco, Inc. ("New SK Holdco"), a Delaware general corporation formed on July 5, 2022. New SK Holdco is wholly owned by Carnelian Point Holdings, L.P. (“Carnelian”), the Company's ultimate parent. On May 27, 2022, SK Holdco, LLC (“SK Holdco” or "Predecessor") and certain of its subsidiaries entered into a TSA. The TSA contemplated agreed-upon terms for an out of court financial restructuring of SK Holdco and its subsidiaries (the “Restructuring Transaction”). The Restructuring Transaction closed on July 14, 2022, which is considered the acquisition date. Pursuant to the TSA, SK Holdco transferred all of the assets and obligations of Service King Paint & Body, LLC and its wholly owned subsidiaries, Sterling Collision Centers, LLC, a Delaware limited liability company and Service King Northwest Paint & Body, LLC, a Delaware limited liability company (together “SK Opco”), to the Company in exchange for 100% equity interest of the Company. At the point of transfer, both entities were under common control. Immediately following the transfer of assets and obligations to the Company, SK Holdco indirectly transferred 100% of the equity interest in the Company to the holders of the Senior Notes in exchange for the cancellation of the outstanding Senior Notes. Refer to Note 2 and Note 10 for additional information.

The Company derives its revenue primarily from providing automobile collision repair services to customer owned vehicles, including paint and refinishing, glass repair and replacement, vehicle alignment, paintless dent repair, on-site car rentals and towing, with a lifetime warranty provided for all services. The Company's customer base consists of insurance carriers and retail customers. Payment terms are net 30 days. Due to the short term nature of the average repair cycle revenues are recognized when the repair is completed, in the amount that reflects the consideration the Company expects to be entitled to in exchange for those services. Sales and other taxes the Company collects concurrent with revenue-producing activities are excluded from revenue. The Company does not have any significant financing components as payment is received at or shortly after the repair is completed and the repaired vehicle is available to the customer. Costs incurred to obtain or fulfill a contract are expensed as incurred when the amortization period is less than a year. The Company treats variable consideration, including rebates and discounts to insurance carriers as a decrease in the transaction price, reducing revenue. These variable amounts are generally credited or paid to the insurance carriers based on either contractually negotiated discount rates or achieving other agreed-upon key performance metrics, including customer survey results, rental days, the severity of the repair and other criteria. When the discount or rebate cannot immediately be determined based on a specific value, the Company estimates the rebates using “the expected value” method at the end of each fiscal month. Revenue is presented net of rebates or discounts.

Subsubsection Title: Disaggregation of revenue from contracts with customers
Subsubsection Text: The Company's revenue is generated from one service line consisting of automobile collision repair services. In addition, revenue is not disaggregated and all revenue is derived in the United States. The collision repair cycle is short in duration and varies based on the extent of work to be performed. The Company has direct repair program agreements with major insurance carriers but no long term contracts associated with specific repair service orders.

The Company recognizes revenue when control of the promised service is transferred to the Company's customers in an amount that reflects the consideration the Company expects to be entitled to in exchange for those services, at a point in time when the repair service is completed and the vehicle is available to the customer. Therefore, there are no contract assets on the Company's consolidated financial statements for all periods presented. Contract liabilities primarily relate to upfront payments received from customers prior to completion of the repair. Payments received for work not yet completed are deferred until the work is finished. Deferred revenue representing payments received from customers prior to completion of the repair is included in accrued expenses and other liabilities in the consolidated balance sheets. See Note 8 for customer deposits at December 31, 2022 (Successor) and January 1, 2022 (Predecessor).

Each collision repair service is a single performance obligation that includes both the parts and labor associated with the service. Payment for the collision repair services are due upon the completion of the service, which is generally completed within a short time from contract inception. The transaction price for the collision repair services is based on the parts used, the number of labor hours applied and the standardized hourly labor rates. The Company satisfies its performance obligations and recognizes revenue when the promised repair services are completed and the control of the repaired vehicles are transferred to the customer.

Warranty costs include materials and labor expenses and are recorded as incurred to cost of sales in the consolidated statements of operations. The Company provides lifetime warranty for all vehicles repaired. Warranty costs included in cost of goods sold were $1.4 million, $1.1 million, $2.1 million and $2.2 million for the period July 14, 2022 through December 31, 2022 (Successor), the period January 2, 2022 through July 13, 2022 (Predecessor), and the years ended January 1, 2022 (Predecessor), and January 2, 2021 (Predecessor), respectively. ----- Based on actual historical warranty costs incurred, over 90% of warranty costs have been incurred within 90 days after completion of the repair. The Company maintains a reserve that reflects management's best estimate of the future cost of honoring obligations under the lifetime warranty plan. This estimate is based on historical experience and is reviewed and updated quarterly. Warranty reserves of $0.4 million and $0.3 million are included in accrued expenses and other liabilities in the consolidated balance sheets as of December 31, 2022 (Successor) and January 1, 2022 (Predecessor), respectively. #### Note 4 — Inventories Inventories consisted of the following (in thousands):

In September 2018 (Predecessor), the Company amended its long term MSA with Axalta. The Company uses Axalta as its exclusive paint vendor. Under the MSA, the Company was subject to certain minimum purchases in exchange for cash incentives intended to assist the Company in scaling its business. The incentives included a $40.0 million advance payment for paint materials purchase rebates ("prebate") received by the Company immediately upon execution of the agreement, an additional prebate of $30.0 million received on October 31, 2018 (Predecessor) and a third and final prebate payment of $30.0 million was received on January 3, 2019 (Predecessor). The deferred paint contract incentive represents the long-term portion of the remaining incentives received under the MSA. The benefit recognized was $0.7 million, $1.1 million, and $1.3 million, for the period January 2, 2022 through July 13, 2022 (Predecessor), and the years ended January 1, 2022 (Predecessor), and January 2, 2021 (Predecessor), respectively. As a result of the Restructuring Transaction, the MSA with Axalta was terminated and replaced with an Indirect Incentive Agreement ("IIA"), effective July 14, 2022. The IIA permits the Company to remain liable for $33.0 million of the $100.0 million advanced funds received from Axalta under the MSA. The Company is required to remit $250,000 monthly installment payments during the eighty-four month term, with the balance of approximately $12.0 million due at the IIA expiration date of July 13, 2029. The IIA does not contain minimum purchase commitments and permits a flat purchase discount subject to annual price escalations. The total benefit recognized under the IIA was $1.5 million for the period July 14, 2022 through December 31, 2022 (Successor). #### Note 13 — Derivative Financial Instruments

On December 22, 2020, the Company entered into the Second Amended and Restated Credit Agreement ("Amended Senior Facilities") in order to execute a refinancing of the existing obligations and commitments under the certain Amended and Restated Credit Agreement. The Amended Senior Facilities includes (a) $775.0 million senior secured term loan facility (the “Amended Term Loan”), with an original maturity date of December 22, 2025, subject to springing to the 91st day prior to the maturity date of the Senior Notes to the extent more than $135.0 million of Senior Notes remains outstanding on such date, and (b) $91.0 million senior secured revolving credit facility ("Extended Revolver"), with an original maturity date of May 22, 2024, except that up to $10.0 million of the revolving commitments will maintain its original maturity date of August 18, 2021 (the “Non-Extended Revolver” and, together with the Extended Revolver, the “Amended Revolver”) and subject to springing to the 121st day prior to the maturity date of the Senior Notes to the extent more than $135.0 million of Senior Notes remains outstanding on such date. The Non-Extended Revolver was voluntarily terminated on August 16, 2021. As of January 1, 2022 (Predecessor) $75.0 million is held in a segregated account for use of payment, redemption, purchase or defease the Senior Notes, and is included within restricted cash in the consolidated balance sheets. As of January 1, 2022 (Predecessor), the Company had $0.1 million of availability under the Amended Revolver and $8.6 million of letters of credit outstanding. |Successor|Predecessor| |---|---| |December 31, 2022|January 1, 2022| |$ 806,177 — — — —|$ 782,993 375,000 72,330 15,288 5,152| |806,177 (8,029) —|1,250,763 (385,409) (14,456)| |$ 798,148|$ 850,898| ----- On July 14, 2022, the Second Amended and Restated Credit Agreement (“Amended Senior Facilities”) was restated due to the Restructuring Transaction, and includes (a) $803 million senior secured term loan facility (the “Restated Term Loan”), with a maturity date of June 30, 2027, and (b) $57 million senior secured revolving credit facility (the “Restated Revolving Credit Facility”), with a maturity date of December 31, 2026. Immediately prior to the restatement of the Amended Senior Facilities, the outstanding balance on the senior secured revolving credit facility of $66.3 million was paid in full. The Amended Senior Facilities resulted in the Restated Term Loan and Restated Revolving Credit Facility outstanding principal balance of $802.9 million. Borrowings under the Restated Term Loan bear interest of the Secured Overnight Financing Rate (“SOFR”) plus 8.25% (with 1.5% per annum payable as Paid-in-Kind ("PIK") interest). SOFR under the Restated Term Loan is subject to a floor of 0.75% annually. As of December 31, 2022 (Successor), the Restated Term Loan annual interest rate was 12.3%. Mandatory PIK interest of 1.5% under the Restated Term Loan was $5.3 million, for the period July 14, 2022 through December 31, 2022 (Successor), and was included in the principal balance of the Restated Term Loan as of December 31, 2022 (Successor). Payment terms include quarterly installments equal to 0.25% of the original principal amount, with the remaining amount payable at maturity. The Company paid $2.0 million on the principal amount for the period July 14, 2022 through December 31, 2022 (Successor). Borrowings under the Restated Revolving Credit Facility bear interest ranging between SOFR plus 6.5% to SOFR plus 7.5%. The range is based upon the average outstanding amount of revolving credit loans for the most recently completed quarter. As of December 31, 2022 (Successor), the Company had no borrowings outstanding and $48.4 million of availability under the Restated Revolving Credit Facility. The Company had $8.6 million of letters of credit outstanding under the Restated Revolving Credit Facility as of December 31, 2022 (Successor). The Company was in compliance with all restrictive and financial covenants under its credit agreements as of December 31, 2022 (Successor) and January 1, 2022 (Predecessor).

Subsubsection Title: Incremental Amendment to Senior Secured Credit Facilities
Subsubsection Text: On March 28, 2022 (Predecessor), the Company entered into an incremental term loan (“Series 2022 Incremental Term Loan”), with certain incremental term lenders for $35.0 million. On July 14, 2022, the Series 2022 Incremental Term Loan was settled as part of the Restructuring Transaction. The outstanding principal balance settled in exchange for equity interests, as disclosed in Note 2 was $34.9 million.

On September 24, 2014, Midas Intermediate Holdco II, LLC and Midas Intermediate Holdco II Finance, Inc., as co-issuers, completed an offering of 7.875% Senior Notes due October 1, 2022 (the “initial notes”) in an aggregate principal amount of $200.0 million. On February 6, 2015, Midas Intermediate Holdco II, LLC and Midas Intermediate Holdco II Finance, Inc., as co-issuers, completed an offering of 7.875% Senior Notes due October 1, 2022 (the “2015 notes”) in an aggregate principal amount of $100.0 million. On August 11, 2016, Midas Intermediate Holdco II, LLC and Midas Intermediate Holdco II Finance, Inc., as co-issuers, completed an offering of 7.875% Senior Notes due October 1, 2022 (the “new notes”) in an aggregate principal amount of $75.0 million. The new notes form part of a single class of securities together with the initial notes and 2015 notes for all purposes under the indenture governing the notes, (collectively the "Senior Notes"). On July 14, 2022, the Senior Notes were settled as part of the Restructuring Transaction. The outstanding principal balance of $375.0 million of Senior Notes in exchange for equity interests, as disclosed in Note 2, was $372.5 million, with the remaining $2.5 million settled in cash.

On September 30, 2021 (Predecessor), the Company entered into a secured term loan for $15.0 million funded by former owners of owners of equity interests, maturing on December 31, 2025. On July 14, 2022, as part of the Restructuring Transaction, 100% of the lenders of the secured term loan exchanged their secured term loans of $15.9 million for a pro-rata share of the Restated Term Loan.

As part of the Restructuring Transaction, the Company incurred $0.9 million in deferred financing fees related to the Restated Revolving Credit Facility, and is included within other assets in the consolidated balance sheets. The deferred financing fees will continue to be amortized over the remaining term of the loan. ----- The Company recognized financing fees of $0.1 million, $3.4 million, $3.1 million, and $2.9 million for the period July 14, 2022 through December 31, 2022 (Successor), the period January 2, 2022 through July 13, 2022 (Predecessor), fiscal years ended January 1, 2022 (Predecessor) and January 1, 2022 (Predecessor), respectively, which is included in interest expense within the consolidated statements of operations. As of December 31, 2022, (Successor), the remaining deferred loan costs, net of accumulated amortization, was $1.0 million, in other assets within the consolidated balance sheets. As of January 1, 2022 (Predecessor), the remaining deferred loan costs, net of accumulated amortization, were $8.0 million, of which $0.9 million was reflected in the consolidated balance sheets in other assets and $7.1 million is reflected in the consolidated balance sheets as a reduction of long-term debt. #### Note 11 — Leases The Company determines if an arrangement is or contains a lease at the inception date. The Company enters into leases primarily for collision repair facilities, administrative offices and equipment under varying terms and conditions. Leases have remaining lease terms of less than one year to twenty years. Some leases contain renewal options that may be exercised to extend the leases for up to twenty-five years. If extensions are reasonably certain at commencement, the term of the extension is included in the original lease term at commencement. Leases with an initial term of twelve months or less are not recorded in the consolidated balance sheets, and are recognized as short-term lease expense on a straight-line basis over the lease term within the consolidated statements of operations. Certain lease agreements include variable lease payments, generally based on consumer price indices or a percentage of sales. Variable lease payments that are assigned to an index are determined based on the initial index at commencement, and the variability based on changes in the index are included in variable lease cost. Leases with index based variable components are not remeasured for changes in indices unless other lease terms are amended. Variable lease payments based on a percentage of sales are not included in the initial measurement of the ROU asset or lease liability due to the uncertainty of the payment amount and are recorded as variable lease expense in the period incurred. The lease agreements do not contain material residual value guarantees or material restrictive covenants. Many of lease agreements contain non-lease components such as maintenance, property taxes and other similar costs, which are generally accounted for separately and allocated on a relative stand-alone price basis. ROU assets represent the Company's right to use an underlying asset for the lease term and lease liabilities represent the contractual obligation to remit lease payments. Operating and finance ROU assets and the corresponding liabilities are recognized based on the present value of the lease payments over the lease term at the commencement date. When available, the Company uses the rate implicit in the lease, otherwise the Company uses a collateralized incremental borrowing rate ("IBR"), calculated based on the weighted average of estimated current borrowing rate for secured financing, using a risk free U.S. Treasury rate spread between five and twenty years. The IBR is based on lease tenor of five to thirty years, and is updated quarterly. Lease costs are recognized on a straight-line basis over the lease term. ROU assets-operating and the associated current and long term liabilities are separately identified in the consolidated balance sheets. ROU assets-finance are included in property, plant and equipment and the associated finance lease current and long-term liabilities are identified separately in the consolidated balance sheets. During the year ended January 2, 2021 (Predecessor), the Company withheld portions of and/or delayed payments to certain landlords as the Company sought to renegotiate payment terms, in order to further maintain liquidity due to the economic impact of COVID-19. In some instances, certain lease contracts were negotiated resulting in abated rent, rent deferrals and lease term adjustments. The Company recognized abated rent as a reduction in lease expense during the concession period, and continued to recognize lease expense on a straightline basis for rent deferrals, and recognized adjustments in the payment period. As of December 31, 2022 (Successor) and January 1, 2022 (Predecessor), deferred payments resulting from rent concessions were less than $0.1 million and $0.8 million, respectively, and were included in accrued expenses and other liabilities in the consolidated balance sheets. During the year ended January 1, 2022 (Predecessor), the Company entered into a purchase and sale agreement to sell and lease-back twenty-one vehicle repair facilities. The initial term is fifteen years with up to four, five-year extension options, and classified as an operating lease. The Company received net proceeds of $64.4 million and ----- recorded approximately $49.2 million of ROU assets and lease liabilities, and recognized a $29.0 million gain on disposal of property, plant and equipment within the consolidated statements of operations. As of December 31, 2022 (Successor), twenty-three leases were modified and reassessed in accordance with Topic 842. One lease was reclassified from operating to finance leases for a total of $2.4 million and one lease was reclassified from finance to operating leases for a total of $2.7 million. During the year ended January 1, 2022 (Predecessor), twenty-seven leases were modified and reassessed in accordance with Topic 842. Two leases were reclassified from operating to finance leases for a total of $2.5 million and four leases were reclassified from finance to operating leases for a total of $ 9.1 million. During the year ended January 2, 2021 (Predecessor), the Company modified the existing lease on its corporate headquarters due to terminating two of the three occupied suites. The lease modification resulted in a reduction of ROU assets of $7.0 million, a reduction of lease liabilities of $10.2 million and a net gain of $0.3 million for lease termination recorded as a loss on disposal of property, plant and equipment, recognized within the consolidated statement of operations. During the year ended January 1, 2022 (Predecessor), the remaining suite was terminated and the Company recognized a gain on lease termination of $1.3 million within the (gain) loss on disposal of property, plant and equipment within the consolidated statements of operations. During the years ended January 1, 2022 (Predecessor) and January 2, 2021 (Predecessor), the Company recognized $0.1 million and $1.2 million, respectively, related to impairment of ROU assets due to permanent store closures within (gain) loss on disposal of property, plant and equipment within the consolidated statements of operations.  During the periods July 14, 2022 through December 31, 2022 (Successor) and January 2, 2022 through July 13, 2022 (Predecessor), the Company did not incur or recognize impairment charges to ROU assets. The Company may recognize transfers between levels in the fair value hierarchy as of the end of the reporting period for all of its financial instruments. Any changes to market liquidity conditions, the availability of observable inputs or changes in the economic structure of a security marketplace may require a transfer of the instruments between levels. There were no transfers between levels during the years ended January 1, 2022 (Predecessor) and January 2, 2021 (Predecessor). The fair value of interest rate caps are measured with the assistance of a third-party valuation specialist. The Company incorporates credit valuation adjustments to appropriately reflect the Company’s own nonperformance risk and the respective counterparties' nonperformance risk in the fair value measurements where appropriate. Although the Company has determined that the majority of inputs used to value the interest rate caps fall within Level 2, as the derivative instruments are traded over the counter and valued using internal models based on observable market inputs, the credit valuation adjustment utilizes Level 3 inputs, such as estimates of current credit spreads to evaluate the likelihood of default by the Company and its counterparties. However, as of January 2, 2021 (Predecessor), the Company assessed the significance of the impact of the credit valuation adjustments on the overall valuation and determined that the credit valuation adjustments are not significant to the overall valuation of the interest rate caps. As a result, the Company classified the derivative instruments in Level 2 in their entirety. For further information about the Company’s derivative instruments, see Note 13. The Company uses a combination of insurance and self-insurance with stop-loss coverages for employee health care utilizing high deductibles. Reserves are established for both identified claims and incurred but not reported (“IBNR”) claims. Such amounts are accrued for when claim amounts become probable and estimable. Reserves for identified claims are based upon the Company’s historical claims experience and third-party estimates of settlement costs. Reserves for IBNR claims are based on the Company’s claims history, actuarial determined loss development factors and qualitative considerations, such as claims management activities. Total claims reserves were $5.1 million and $5.0 million as of December 31, 2022 (Successor) and January 1, 2022 (Predecessor), respectively, which was recorded in accrued expenses and other liabilities in the consolidated balance sheets.

On December 22, 2020, the Company entered into the Second Amended and Restated Credit Agreement ("Amended Senior Facilities") in order to execute a refinancing of the existing obligations and commitments under the certain Amended and Restated Credit Agreement. The Amended Senior Facilities included $775.0 million senior secured term loan facility (the “Amended Term Loan”), with an original maturity date of December 22, 2025. On July 14, 2022, the Amended Senior Facilities was restated and includes (a) $803.0 million senior secured term loan facility (the “Restated Term Loan”), with a maturity date of June 30, 2027, and (b) $57.0 million senior secured revolving credit facility (the “Restated Revolving Credit Facility”), with a maturity date of December 31, 2026. Borrowings under the Restated Term Loan bear interest of the Secured Overnight Financing Rate (“SOFR”) plus 8.25% (with 1.5% per annum payable as paid-in-kind ("PIK") interest). SOFR under the Restated Term Loan is subject to a floor of 0.75% annually. As of September 30, 2023 (Successor) and December 31, 2022 (Successor), the Restated Term Loan annual interest rate was 13.7% and 12.3%, respectively. Mandatory PIK interest of 1.5% under the Restated Term Loan was $9.3 million and $2.2 million for the year-todate period ended September 30, 2023 (Successor) and for the period July 14, 2022 through September 30, 2022 (Successor), respectively, and was included in the principal balance of the Restated Term Loan. Payment terms include quarterly installments equal to 0.25% of the original principal amount, with the remaining amount payable at maturity. The Company paid $6.0 million of the principal amount during the year-to-date period ended September 30, 2023 (Successor). Borrowings under the Restated Revolving Credit Facility bear interest ranging between SOFR plus 6.5% to SOFR plus 7.5%. The range is based upon the average outstanding amount of revolving credit loans for the most recently completed quarter. As of September 30, 2023 (Successor) and December 31, 2022 (Successor), the Company had no borrowings outstanding and $48.4 million of availability under the Restated Revolving Credit Facility. The Company had $8.6 million of letters of credit outstanding under the Restated Revolving Credit Facility as of September 30, 2023 (Successor) and December 31, 2022 (Successor). The Company was in compliance with all restrictive and financial covenants under its credit agreements as of September 30, 2023 (Successor) and December 31, 2022 (Successor). -----

The Company recognized financing fees of $0.2 million, $0.1 million, and $3.4 million for the year-to-date period ended September 30, 2023 (Successor), for the period July 14, 2022 through September 30, 2022 (Successor), and for the period January 2, 2022 through July 13, 2022 (Predecessor), respectively, included in "interest expense, net" within the condensed consolidated statements of operations. As of September 30, 2023 (Successor) and December 31, 2022 (Successor), the remaining deferred loan costs, net of accumulated amortization, was $0.8 million and $1.0 million, respectively, included in "other assets" within the condensed consolidated balance sheets. #### Note 9 — Leases The Company determines if an arrangement is or contains a lease at the inception date. The Company leases vehicle collision repair facilities, administrative offices and equipment under operating leases, and leases vehicles and equipment under finance leases. Leases have remaining lease terms of less than one year to twenty years. Some leases contain renewal options that may be exercised to extend the leases for up to twenty-five years. If extensions are reasonably certain at commencement, the term of the extension is included in the original lease term at commencement. Leases with an initial term of twelve months or less are not recorded in the condensed consolidated balance sheets and are recognized as short-term lease expense on a straight-line basis over the lease term within the condensed consolidated statements of operations. Certain lease agreements include variable lease payments, generally based on consumer price indices or a percentage of sales. Variable lease payments that are assigned to an index are determined based on the initial index at commencement, and the variability based on changes in the index are included in variable lease cost. Leases with index-based variable components are not remeasured for changes in indices unless other lease terms are amended. Variable lease payments based on a percentage of sales are not included in the initial measurement of the right-of-use ("ROU") asset or lease liability due to the uncertainty of the payment amount and are recorded as variable lease expense in the period incurred. The lease agreements do not contain material residual value guarantees or material restrictive covenants. Many of the lease agreements contain non-lease components such as maintenance, property taxes and other similar costs, which are generally accounted for separately and allocated on a relative stand-alone price basis. ROU assets represent the Company's right to use an underlying asset for the lease term and lease liabilities represent the contractual obligation to remit lease payments. Operating and finance ROU assets and the corresponding liabilities are recognized based on the present value of the lease payments over the lease term at the commencement date. When available, the Company uses the rate implicit in the lease, otherwise the Company uses a collateralized incremental borrowing rate ("IBR"), calculated based on the weighted average of estimated current borrowing rate for secured financing, using a risk-free U.S. Treasury rate spread between five and twenty years. The IBR is based on lease tenor of five to thirty years and is updated quarterly. Lease costs are recognized on a straight-line basis over the lease term. ROU assets - operating and the associated current and long-term liabilities are separately identified in the condensed consolidated balance sheets. ROU assets - finance are included in property, plant and equipment and the associated current and long-term liabilities are identified separately in the condensed consolidated balance sheets. On May 19, 2023, the Company entered into a purchase and sale agreement to sell and lease back thirteen shop locations to an unrelated party. The initial term of the lease is for fifteen years, with up to four, five-year extension options. On June 2, 2023, the Company sold eleven of thirteen properties and received net proceeds of $53.0 million and recorded approximately $30.9 million and $26.5 million of ROU assets and lease liabilities, respectively, which are classified as operating leases within the condensed consolidated balance sheets. As a result of the transaction, the Company recognized a gain of $11.3 million which is included within "(gain) loss on disposal of property, plant and equipment" in our condensed consolidated statements of operations. On July 20, 2023, the Company sold the final two of thirteen properties and received net proceeds of $16.9 million and recorded approximately $9.9 million and $8.5 million of ROU assets and lease liabilities, respectively, which are classified as operating leases within the condensed consolidated balance sheets. As a result of the transaction, the Company recognized a gain of $7.0 million which is included within "(gain) loss on disposal of property, plant and equipment" in our condensed consolidated statements of operations. ----- The components of lease expense included in the condensed consolidated statements of operations consisted of the following: Operating lease cost $ 51,733 $ 15,147 $ 36,302 Finance lease cost: Amortization of right-of-use assets 5,182 1,475 3,706 Interest on lease obligation 5,456 1,621 4,095 Total finance lease cost 10,638 3,096 7,801 Short-term lease cost 81 20 57 Variable lease cost 2,197 407 1,012 Sublease income (5,446) (1,866) (5,221) Total lease cost $ 59,203 $ 16,804 $ 39,951 |Successor|Predecessor| |---|---| |9 Months Ended July 14, 2022 through September 30, 2023 September 30, 2022|January 2, 2022 through July 13, 2022| |$ 51,733 $ 15,147 5,182 1,475 5,456 1,621|$ 36,302 3,706 4,095| |10,638 3,096|7,801| |81 20 2,197 407 (5,446) (1,866)|57 1,012 (5,221)| |$ 59,203 $ 16,804|$ 39,951| Future maturities of lease liabilities excluding subleases as of September 30, 2023 (Successor), consisted of the following:

The Company used Axalta Coating Systems, LLC ("Axalta") as its exclusive paint vendor. As a result of the Restructuring Transaction, the Master Sales Agreement ("MSA") with Axalta was terminated and replaced with an Indirect Incentive Agreement ("IIA"), effective July 14, 2022. The IIA permits the Company to remain liable for $33.0 million of the $100.0 million advanced funds received from Axalta under the MSA. The Company is required to remit $250,000 monthly installment payments during the eighty-four-month term, with the balance of approximately $12.0 million due at the IIA expiration date of July 13, 2029. The IIA does not contain minimum purchase commitments and permits a flat purchase discount subject to annual price escalations. The total benefit recognized under the IIA was $1.8 million and $0.8 million for the year-to-date period ended September 30, 2023 (Successor) and for the period July 14, 2022 through September 30, 2022 (Successor), respectively. The IIA was terminated in August 2023 and in October 2023, a settlement agreement was executed with Axalta related to the termination. The settlement agreement included the repayment of the remaining outstanding prebate liability as of the settlement date of approximately $30.0 million, and $10.1 million as a contract termination and settlement, both included in "accrued expenses and other liabilities" within the condensed consolidated balance sheets. The settlement was primarily funded with proceeds received in conjunction with a new paint contract entered into by the Company. The repayment of the remaining outstanding prebate liability and the settlement payment were paid in October 2023.

In June 2023, the Company entered into a Requirements Agreement ("RA") with BASF Corporation ("BASF") in which BASF will be the Company's exclusive paint vendor. Under the RA, the Company is subject to a total minimum purchase over a ten-year period in exchange for cash incentives. The incentives included a $28.0 million advance payment for paint materials purchase rebates (prebate) received by the Company upon execution of the RA. The deferred paint incentive represents the long-term portion of the prebate received upon execution of the RA and will be amortized to "cost of sales" over the life of the contract. #### Note 11 — Employee Benefit and Incentive Plans The Company offers a qualified 401(k) profit-sharing plan (the "Plan"). The Plan allows for elective wage deferrals by all employees meeting minimum age and length of service requirements with the Company. The Company matches 50% of an employee's salary deferral up to 8% of the employee's compensation. The Company's matching contributions, net of forfeitures, was $3.6 million, $1.3 million, and $3.0 million for the year-to-date period ended September 30, 2023 (Successor), for the period July 14, 2022 through September 30, 2022 (Successor), and for the period January 2, 2022 through July 13, 2022 (Predecessor), respectively. In January 2023, Carnelian established a long-term cash incentive plan (“LTIP”) for the Company. The LTIP was designed to align certain individual’s interests with the long-term success of Carnelian by (a) promoting the longterm financial interests and growth of its subsidiaries and the Carnelian by attracting and retaining management and other key personnel, (b) motivate management and other key personnel by means of growth-related incentives to achieve long-range goals, and (c) further the alignment of interests of LTIP participants with those of the partners of Carnelian. LTIP participants may be entitled to a one-time cash payment upon the resolution of a future contingent event. As the Carnelian profits interest do not represent a substantive class of equity for accounting purposes, the LTIP will be accounted for under ASC 710, _Compensation-General and ASC 450,_ _Contingencies. The Company has concluded that payout of these awards is not probable until the occurrence of a liquidity event such as a merger, acquisition, or IPO. Accordingly, pursuant to ASC 450, no compensation expense has been recorded as of September 30, 2023 (Successor). #### Note 12 — Income Taxes The Company is not a tax-paying entity for federal income tax purposes. The individual members are required to report their distributive share of the Company’s realized income, gain, loss, deductions, or credits on their individual income tax returns. The Company is not a tax-paying entity in the states in which it conducts business, with the exception of Texas and Tennessee. The Company is subject to the Texas Margin Tax and the Tennessee Excise Tax, both privilege taxes are based on income imposed on companies with nexus in the state. ----- The Company's income tax expense was $0.9 million, $0.2 million, and $0.7 million for the year-to-date period ended September 30, 2023 (Successor), for the period July 14, 2022 through September 30, 2022 (Successor), and for the period January 2, 2022 through July 13, 2022 (Predecessor), respectively. The Company maintained its full valuation allowance of $2.0 million against the deferred tax asset balance as of September 30, 2023 (Successor). #### Note 13 — Commitments and Contingencies

The Company uses a combination of insurance and self-insurance with stop-loss coverages for employee health care utilizing high deductibles. Reserves are established for both identified claims and incurred but not reported (“IBNR”) claims. Such amounts are accrued for when claim amounts become probable and estimable. Reserves for identified claims are based upon the Company’s historical claims experience and third-party estimates of settlement costs. Reserves for IBNR claims are based on the Company’s claims history, actuarial determined loss development factors and qualitative considerations, such as claims management activities. Total claims reserves were $5.2 million and $5.1 million as of September 30, 2023 (Successor) and December 31, 2022 (Successor), respectively, recognized in "accrued expenses and other liabilities" within the condensed consolidated balance sheets.

In the normal course of the Company's business, it is at times subject to pending and threatened legal actions, in some cases for which the relief or damages may be substantial. Although the Company is not able to predict the outcome of such actions, after reviewing all pending and threatened actions with counsel and based on information currently available, management believes that the outcome of such actions, individually or in the aggregate, will not have a material adverse effect on the Company's results of operations or financial position. However, it is possible that the ultimate resolution of such matters, if unfavorable, may be material to the Company's results of operations in a particular future period as the time and amount of any resolution of such actions and its relationship to the future results of operations are not currently known. The Company accrues losses when they are probable of occurrence and such losses are reasonably estimable. Legal costs expected to be incurred are accounted for as incurred. In May 2022, a class action lawsuit was filed against the Company alleging that the Company used a biometric device for attendance and payroll purposes without obtaining consent from its employees. Subsequent to September 30, 2023 (Successor), a settlement agreement was reached for approximately $1.6 million, which was accrued as of September 30, 2023 (Successor) and included in "accrued expenses and other liabilities" within the condensed consolidated balance sheets. In June 2019, four separate California class action lawsuits against the Company were consolidated into one action. The lawsuit alleges failure to pay certain wages and to provide required meal and rest periods to our current and former hourly and commissioned employees in California, as well as certain wage statement defects. During the Predecessor Period, the Company entered into a settlement with plaintiffs to resolve the outstanding matter and recognized a $4.8 million obligation included in "other liabilities" within the condensed consolidated balance sheets. ----- #### Note 14 — Supplemental Cash Flow Information The following table includes the supplemental cash flow disclosures for non-cash investing and financing activities:
